src_text.1713: Quoniam igitur, uti paulo ante monstratum est, omne quod scitur non ex sua sed ex conprehendentimn natura cognoscitur, iutueamur nunc quantum fas est, quis sit diuinae substantiae status, ut quaenam etiam scientia eius sit, possimus agnoscere.

src_text.1721: Quod igitur temporis patitur condicionem, licet illud, sicuti de mundo censuit Aristoteles, nec coeperit umquam esse nec desinat uitaque eius cum temporis infinitate tendatur, nondum tamen tale est ut aeternum esse iure credatur.
src_text.1722: Non enim totum simul infinitae licet uitae spatium comprehendit atque complectitur, sed futura nondum transacta iam non habet.
src_text.1723: Quod igitur interminabilis uitae plenitudinem totam pariter comprehendit ac possidet, cui neque futuri quidquam absit nec praeteriti fluxerit, id aeternum esse iure perhibetur, idque necesse est et sui compos praesens sibi semper adsistere et infinitatem mobilis temporis habere praesentem.
src_text.1724: Vnde non recte quidam, qui cum audiunt uisum Platoni mundum hunc nec habuisse initium temporis nec habiturum esse defectum, hoc modo conditori conditum mundum fieri coaeternum putant.

src_text.1733: Itaque si praesentiam pensare uelis qua cuncta dinoscit, non esse praescientiam quasi futuri sed scientiam numquam deficientis instantiae rectius aestimabis j unde non praeuidentia sed prouidentia potius dicitur, quod porro ab rebus infimis constituta quasi ab excelso rerum cacumine cuncta prospiciat.
src_text.1734: Quid igitur postulas ut necessaria fiant quae diuino lumine lustrentur, cum ne homines quidem necessaria faciant esse quae uideant?

src_text.1738: Quare haec diuina praenotio naturam rerum proprietatemque non mutat taliaque apud se praesentia spectat qualia in tempore olim futura prouenient.
src_text.1739: Nec rerum iudicia confundit unoque suae mentis intuitu tam necessarie quam non necessarie uentura dinoscit;

src_text.1741: Quo fit ut hoc non sit opinio sed ueritate potius nixa cognitio, cum exstaturum quid esse cognoscit quod idem exsistendi necessitate carere non nesciat.

src_text.1746: Hanc enim necessitatem non propria facit natura sed condicionis adiectio;

src_text.1749: Atqui deus ea futura quae ex arbitrii libertate proueniunt praesentia contuetur.
src_text.1750: Haec igitur ad intuitum relata di uinum necessaria fiant per condicionem diuinae notionis;

src_text.1753: Quid igitur refert non esse necessaria, cum propter diuinae scientiae condicionem modis omnibus necessitatis instar eueniet?

src_text.1755: Quae dum fiunt, non fieri non possunt;

src_text.1757: Ita etiam quae praesentia deus habet, dubio procul exsistent, sed eorum hoc quidem de rerum necessitate descendit, illud uero de potestate facientium.
src_text.1758: Haud igitur iniuria diximus haec si ad diuinam notitiam referantur necessaria, si per se considerentur necessitatis esse nexibus absoluta;

tgt_text.114: AT the time when the Goths of the country of Scythia made war against the empire of the Romans, and with their kings, who were called Rhadgast and Alaric, sacked the Roman city, and reduced to subjection all the kingdom of Italy, which is between the mountains and the island of Sicily, and then, after the before-mentioned kings, Theodoric obtained posses­ sion of that same kingdom:
tgt_text.115: Theodoric was of the race of the Amali;
tgt_text.116: he was a Christian, but he persisted in the Arian heresy.
tgt_text.117: He promised to the Romans his friendship, so that they might enjoy their ancient rights.
tgt_text.118: But he very ill per­ formed that promise, and speedily ended with much wicked­ ness;

tgt_text.172: So does also the moon with his pale light, which obscures the bright stars in the heaven:
tgt_text.173: and sometimes bereaves the sun of her light, when he is betwixt us and her;
tgt_text.174: and sometimes the bright star which we call the morning star;
tgt_text.175: the same we call by another name, the evening star.
tgt_text.176: Thou, who to the winter days givest short times, and to the summer's days, longer!
tgt_text.177: Thou, who the trees, by the stark north-east wind in harvest-time, of their leaves bereavest;
tgt_text.178: and again in spring, other leaves givest, through the mild south-west wind!
tgt_text.180: do all creatures obey thee, and keep the institutions of thy com­ mandments, except man alone, who is disobedient ?
tgt_text.181: 0, thou almighty maker and governor of all creatures, help now thy miserable mankind.
tgt_text.182: Wherefore, 0 Lord, ever wouldest thou, that fortune should so vary ?
tgt_text.183: She afflicts the innocent, and afflicts not the guilty.
tgt_text.184: The wicked sit on high seats, and trample the holy under their feet.
tgt_text.185: Bright virtues lie hid, and the wicked deride the virtuous.
tgt_text.186: Wicked oaths in no wise injure men, nor the false lot which is with fraud con­ cealed.
tgt_text.187: Therefore almost all mankind will now proceed in doubt, if fortune may thus vary according to the will of evil men, and thou wilt not control her.
tgt_text.188: 0, my Lord, thou who overseest all creatures, look now mercifully on this miserable earth, and also on all mankind:
tgt_text.189: because it now all struggles in the waves of this world,§ I. WHILST the Mind was uttering such sorrow, and was singing this lay, Wisdom and Reason looked on him with cheerful eyes;
tgt_text.190: and be was nothing disturbed on account of the Mind's lamentation, but said to the Mind:
tgt_text.191: As soon as I first saw thee in this trouble, thus complaining, I perceived that thou wast departed from thy father's country, that is from my precepts.
tgt_text.192: Thou departedst therefrom when thou didst abandon thy fixed state of mind, and tboughtest that Fortune governed this world according to her own pleasure, without God's counsel, and his permission, and men's deserts.
tgt_text.193: I knew that thou wast departed, but I knew not how far, until thou thyself toldest it to me, by thy lamentations.
tgt_text.194: But though thou art now farther than thou wast, thou art not nevertheless entirely driven from the country;
tgt_text.196: Nor, moreover, could any other man lead thee into error, except thyself, through thine own negligence.
tgt_text.197: Nor could any one thus believe it of thee, when thou wouldest call to mind, of what families thou wast, and of what citizens, as to the world:
tgt_text.198: or again, spiritually, of what society thou wast in thy mind, and in thy reason:
tgt_text.199: that is that thou art one of the just, and of those who will rightly, who are the citizens of the heavenly Jerusalem.
tgt_text.200: Thence no one was ever driven against his own will, that is from his right will.
tgt_text.201: Wheresoever he might be, he had this always with him;
tgt_text.202: when he had this with him, wheresoever he might be, he was with his own kin, and with his own citizens, in his own land, when he was in the company of the just.
tgt_text.203: Whosoever, then, is worthy of this, that be may be in their service, he is in the highest freedom.
tgt_text.204: I shun not this inferior, and this unclean place, if I find thee well in­ structed.
tgt_text.205: I am not desirous of walls wrought with glass, or of thrones ornamented with gold and with jewels;
tgt_text.206: nor am I so desirous of-books written with gold, as I am desirous of a right will in thee.
tgt_text.207: I seek not here books, but that which books are profitable for, that I may make thy mind perfectly right.
tgt_text.208: Thou complainedest of evil fortune, both on account of the height of unjust power, and on account of my mean­ ness and dishonour;
tgt_text.209: and also on account of the uncontrolled license of the wicked, with respect to these worldly goods.
tgt_text.210: But as very great trouble has now come upon thee, both from thine anger and from thy sorrow, I may not yet answer thee, before the time for it arrives.§ II.
tgt_text.211: For whatsoever any one begins out of season, has no good end.
tgt_text.212: When the sun's brightness in the month of August hottest shines;
tgt_text.213: then does he foolishly, who will at that time sow any seed in the dry furrows.
tgt_text.214: So also does he, who will seek flowers in the storms of winter.
tgt_text.215: Nor canst thou press wine at mid-winter, though thou be desirous of warm must.§ III.
tgt_text.217: May I now inquire a little concerning the fixedness of thy mind, that I may thereby discover whence and how I may effect thy cure ?
tgt_text.218: Then answered the Mind, and said:
tgt_text.221: Dost thou believe that Fortune governs this world, or that aught of good can be thus made, without the Maker ?
tgt_text.222: Then answered the Mind, and said:
tgt_text.223: I do not believe that it could be made so full of order;
tgt_text.224: but I know forsooth that God is governor of his own work, and I never swerved from this true belief.
tgt_text.225: Then answered Wisdom again, and said:
tgt_text.226: About that very thing thou wast singing a little while ago, and saidst, that every creature from God knew its right time, and fulfilled its right institution, except man alone.
tgt_text.227: Therefore I wonder beyond measure, what it can be, or what thou meanest, now thou hast this belief.
tgt_text.228: We must, however, inquire still more deeply concerning it.
tgt_text.229: I do not know very well about what thou still doubtest.
tgt_text.230: Tell me, since thou sayest that thou doubtest not that God is governor of this world, how He, then, would that it should he.
tgt_text.231: Then answered the Mind, and said:
tgt_text.232: I can scarcely understand thy questions, and yet thou sayest that I must answer thee.
tgt_text.234: Dost thou think that I am ignorant of the severity of thy trouble, that thou art encompassed with P But tell me, to what end does every beginning tend ?
tgt_text.235: Then answered the Mind, and said:
tgt_text.236: I remembered it formerly, but this grief has deprived me of the recollection.
tgt_text.238: Dost thou know whence every creature came ?
tgt_text.239: Then answered the, Mind, and said:
tgt_text.240: I know that every creature came from God.
tgt_text.242: How can it be, that now thou knowest the beginning, thou knowest not also the end P for grief may agitate the mind, but it cannot bereave it of its faculties.
tgt_text.243: But I desire that thou wouldest inform me, whether thou knowest what thou thyself art.
tgt_text.245: I know that I am of living men, and rational, and neverthe­ less of mortal.
tgt_text.247: Knowest thou anything else, to say of thyself, besides what thou hast now said ?
tgt_text.251: I have now learned thy mental disease, since thou knowest not what thou thyself art:
tgt_text.252: but I know how I must cure thy disease.
tgt_text.253: For this reason thou saidst thou wert an exile, and bereaved of all good, because thou knewest not what thou wert.
tgt_text.254: Thou showedst that thou didst not know to what end every beginning tended, when thou thoughtest that outrageous and reckless men were happy and powerful in this world:
tgt_text.255: and moreover thou showedst that thou didst not know with what government God rules this world, or how He would that it should be, when thou saidst that thou thoughtest that this inconstant Fortune changes this world without God's counsel.
tgt_text.256: But it was a very great peril that thou shouldest so think.
tgt_text.257: Not only wast thou in immoderate trouble, but thou hadst well-nigh altogether perished.
tgt_text.258: Thank God, there­ fore, that he has assisted thee, so that I have not entirely for­ saken thy mind.
tgt_text.259: We have already the chief part of the fuel for thy cure, now thou believest that Fortune cannot of her­ self, without God's counsel, change this world.
tgt_text.260: Now thou hast no need to fear anything, for from the little spark which thou hast caught with this fuel, the light of life will shine upon thee.
tgt_text.261: But it is not yet time that I should animate thee more highly:
tgt_text.262: for it is the custom of every mind, that as soon as it forsakes true sayings, it follows false opinions.
tgt_text.263: From hence, then, begin to grow the mists which trouble the mind, and withal confound the true sight, such mists as are now on thy mind..
tgt_text.264: But I must dispel them first, that I may afterwards the more easily bring upon thee the true light.
tgt_text.265: LOOK now at the sun, and also at the other heavenly bodies;
tgt_text.266: when the swarthy clouds come before them, they cannot give their light.
tgt_text.267: So also, the south wind sometimes with a great storm troubles the aea, which before, in serene weather, was transparent as glass to behold.
tgt_text.268: When it then is so mingled with the billows it is very quickly unpleasant, though it before was pleasant to look upon.
tgt_text.269: So also is the brook, though it be strong in its right course, when a great stone rolling down from the high mountain falls into it, and divides it, and hinders it from its right course.
tgt_text.270: In like manner does the darkness of thy trouble now withstand my enlightened precepts.
tgt_text.271: But if thou art desirous with right faith to know the true light;
tgt_text.272: put away from thee evil and vain joys, and also the vain sorrows, and the evil fear of this world:
tgt_text.273: that is, that thou lift not up thyself with arrogance, in thy health, and in thy prosperity;
tgt_text.274: nor again, despair of any good in any adversity.
tgt_text.275: For the Mind is ever bound with misery, if either of these two evils reigns.§
tgt_text.276: I. THEN was Wisdom silent a little while, till he per­ ceived the Mind's thoughts.
tgt_text.277: When he had perceived them, then said he:
tgt_text.278: If I have rightly understood thy trouble, nothing affects thee more than this, that thou hast lost the worldly prosperity which thou formerly hadst, and now lamentest because it is changed.
tgt_text.279: I perceive clearly enough that worldly goods with many an allurement very deceitfully flatter the minds which they intend at last utterly to betray:
tgt_text.280: and then at length, when they least expect it, scornfully leave them in the deepest sorrow.
tgt_text.281: If thou now desirest to know whence they come, then mayest thou learn that they come from worldly covetousness.
tgt_text.282: If thou then wilt know their manners, thou mayest learn that they are not faithful to any man.
tgt_text.283: Hence thou mayest understand that thou hadst no pleasure when thou hadst them;
tgt_text.284: nor again, didst lose .any when thou didst lose them.
tgt_text.285: I thought that I had formerly instructed thee, so that thou mightest know them ;
tgt_text.286: and I knew that thou despisedst them when thou hadst them, though thou didst use them.
tgt_text.287: I knew that thou, against their will, didst often repeat my sayings.
tgt_text.288: But I know that no custom can be changed in any man without the mind being in some measure disquieted.
tgt_text.289: Therefore thou art also now moved from thy tranquillity.§ If. 0 Mind, what has cast thee into this care, and into these lamentations ?
tgt_text.290: Is it something unusual that has bap­ pened to thee, so that the same before ailed not other men ?
tgt_text.291: If thou then thinkest that it is on thy account that worldly goods are so changed towards thee, then art thou in error:
tgt_text.293: They kept towards thee their own nature, and in their changeableness they show their con­ stant state.
tgt_text.294: They were exactly, when they most allured thee, such as they are now, though they flattered thee with false happiness.
tgt_text.295: Thou hast now understood the unstable promises of this blind pleasure.
tgt_text.296: These promises which are now ex­ posed to thee, are yet to many others concealed.
tgt_text.297: Thpu now knowest what manners worldly goods have, and how they change.
tgt_text.298: If thou, then, art desirous to be their servant, and their manners are pleasing to thee, wherefore mournest thou so much?
tgt_text.299: Why changest thou not also with them?
tgt_text.300: But if thou wouldst avoid their deceits, then despise them, and drive them from thee, for they seduce thee to thy ruin.
tgt_text.301: The same things which have now occasioned to thee these lamenta­ tions, because thou hadst them, would have suffered thee to be in tranquillity if thou never hadst obtained them.
tgt_text.302: The same things have now forsaken thee, of their own will, not of thine, which never forsake any man without occasioning sorrow.
tgt_text.303: Do these things now seem to thee very dear and very precious, which are neither constant to possess, nor yet easy to relinquish :
tgt_text.304: but when they are departing from any one, he shall with the greatest sorrow of his mind relinquish therm?
tgt_text.305: Since, then, thou canst not, according to thy wish, have them faithful to thee, and they will bring thee into mourning when they depart from thee;
tgt_text.306: for what else then do they come, but for a token of care and unmixed sorrow ?
tgt_text.307: The worldly goods are not alone to be thought about which we at the time pos­ sess, but every prudent mind observes what end they have;
tgt_text.308: and forewarns itself both against their threats, and against their allurements.
tgt_text.309: But if thou choosest to be their servant, then oughtest thou willingly to bear whatever belongs to their service, and to their manners, and to their will.
tgt_text.310: If thou, then, art desirous that they should, on thy account, assume other manners than their will and custom is;
tgt_text.311: dost thou not then dishonour thyself, inasmuch as thou rebellest against the government which thou thyself hast chosen ?
tgt_text.312: and nevertheless thou canst not change their custom or their nature.
tgt_text.313: Besides, thou knowest that if thou spreadest the sail of thy ship to the wind, thou then leanest all thy course to the power of the wind.
tgt_text.314: So, if thou hast given up thyself to the power of worldly goods, it is right that thou shouldest also follow their manners.
tgt_text.315: Thinkest thou, that thou canst turn back the revolving wheel when it moves in its course ?
tgt_text.316: No more canst thou alter the inconstancy of worldly pros­ perity.§ III.
tgt_text.317: I am still desirous that we should discourse further concerning worldly goods.
tgt_text.318: Why didst thou, just now, up­ braid me that thou hadst lost them on ray account?
tgt_text.319: Why dost thou complain against me, as if thou, for my advantage, wert deprived of thine own ;
tgt_text.320: either of thy riches or thy dig­ nity ?
tgt_text.321: both of which formerly came to thee from me, when they were lent thee.
tgt_text.322: Let us now speak before such judge as thou wilt;
tgt_text.323: and if thou art able to prove that any mortal man possessed anything of this kind as his own, I will give thee again all that thou canst say was thine own.
tgt_text.324: I received thee ignorant and uninstructed, when thou first earnest to man's estate, and then taught and instructed thee, and im­ parted to thee wisdom, whereby thou obtainedst the worldly possessions which thou now sorrowing hast lost.
tgt_text.325: Thou mayest therefore be thankful that thou hast well enjoyed my gifts.
tgt_text.326: Nor canst thou say that thou hast lost aught of thine own.
tgt_text.328: Have I in any wise de­ prived thee of those thy gifts which came to thee from me?
tgt_text.329: All true wealth and true dignity, are mine own servants, and wheresoever I am, they are with me.
tgt_text.330: Know thou for truth, if the riches which thou art lamenting that thou hast lost them, had been thine own, thou couldest not have lost them, 0, how unjustly do many worldly men act towards me, in that I may not govern mine own servants!
tgt_text.331: The heaven may bring light days, and again obscure the light with darkness:
tgt_text.332: the year may bring blossoms, and the same year again take them away.
tgt_text.333: The sea may enjoy calm waves ;
tgt_text.334: and all creatures may keep their custom and their will, except me alone.
tgt_text.335: I alone am deprived of my manners, and am allured to manners foreign to me, through the insatiable covetousness of worldly men.
tgt_text.336: Through covetousness have they deprived me of my name, which I should rightly have.
tgt_text.337: This name I should rightly have, that I am wealth and dignity:
tgt_text.338: but they have taken it from me, and in their pride they have given and drawn me to their false riches;
tgt_text.339: so that I may not, with my servants, exercise my employments as all other creatures may.
tgt_text.340: My servants are wisdom, and virtues, and true riches.
tgt_text.341: With these servants was always my pastime;
tgt_text.342: with these servants I am encompassing all the heaven, and the lowest I bring to the highest, and the highest to the lowest;
tgt_text.343: that is, I bring humility to the heavens, and heavenly blessings to the humble.
tgt_text.344: But when I ascend with my servants, then look we down on this stormy world, like the eagle, when he soars above the clouds in stormy weather, that the storms may not hurt him.
tgt_text.345: In like manner, I am desirous, 0 Mind, that thou shouldest ascend to us, if thou art willing:
tgt_text.346: on the condition that thou wilt again with us seek the earth for the advantage of good men.
tgt_text.347: Dost thou not know my manners ?
tgt_text.349: I always was concerning the wants of good men ?
tgt_text.350: Knowest thou how mindful I was of the necessity of Crœsus, the Grecian king, when Cyrus, king of Persia, had seized him, and would burn him ?
tgt_text.351: When they cast him into the fire, I delivered him with heavenly rain.
tgt_text.352: But thou, on account of thy virtue, wast over-confident;
tgt_text.353: and thoughtest that because of thy good intention nothing unjust could befal thee:
tgt_text.354: as if thou wouldest have the reward of all thy good works in this world !
tgt_text.355: How couldest thou dwell in the midst of the common country, without suffering the same as other men ?
tgt_text.356: How couldest thou be in the midst of this changeable state, with­ out also feeling some evil through adversity ?
tgt_text.357: What else do the poets sing concerning this world, but the various changes of this world ?
tgt_text.358: What is there peculiar to thee, that thou shouldest not change therewith ?
tgt_text.359: Why carest thou how it may change, when I am always with thee ?
tgt_text.360: This change was to thee more tolerable, because thou didst not too much desire these worldly goods, and because thou didst not, more­ over, place greater confidence in them.
tgt_text.362: Though to the covetous man come as many riches as there are grains of sand by the sea-cliffs, or stars which in dark nights shine;
tgt_text.363: he nevertheless will not cease from com­ plaints, so as not to lament his poverty.
tgt_text.364: Though God fulfil the wishes of wealthy men with gold, and with silver, and with all precious things, nevertheless the thirst of their avarice will not be satisfied, but the unfathomable gulf will have very many waste holes to gather into.
tgt_text.365: Who can give enough to the insane miser ?
tgt_text.366: The more any one gives to him, the more he covets.§
tgt_text.367: V. How wilt thou now answer worldly goods, if they say to thee:
tgt_text.369: why art thou angry with us ?
tgt_text.370: in what have we offended thee ?
tgt_text.371: Indeed thou wast desirous of us, not we of thee!
tgt_text.372: Thou didst set us on the seat of thy Maker, when thou didst look to us for that good which thou shouldest have sought from him.
tgt_text.373: Thou gayest that we have betrayed thee;
tgt_text.374: but we may rather say that thou hast betrayed us, since through thy desire, and through thy covetousness, the Maker of all creatures will abhor us.
tgt_text.375: Thou art therefore more guilty than we, both on account of thine own wicked desire, and also because, through thee, we cannot perform our Maker's will.
tgt_text.376: For he lent us to thee, to be en­ joyed according to his commandments, not to fulfil the desire of thine evil covetousness.
tgt_text.377: Answer us now, said Wisdom, as thou wilt:
tgt_text.379: THEN said the Mind, I perceive myself every way guilty;
tgt_text.380: but I am so greatly oppressed with this loathsome sorrow, that I cannot answer you.
tgt_text.382: It is still thy fault that thou art almost despairing.
tgt_text.383: But I am unwilling that thou shouldest despair:
tgt_text.384: I would rather that thou wert ashamed of such error;
tgt_text.385: for he who despairs is dis­ tracted;
tgt_text.386: but he who is ashamed is in repentance.
tgt_text.387: If thou now wilt call to mind all the honours, in respect of this world, which thou hast had since thou first wert born, until this day;
tgt_text.388: if thou wilt now reckon all the enjoyments against the sor­ rows;
tgt_text.389: thou canst not very easily say that thou art miserable and unhappy.
tgt_text.390: For I took charge of thee unexperienced, and uninstructed;
tgt_text.391: and adopted thee as my child, and inured thee to my discipline.
tgt_text.392: Who can then say aught else, but that thou wert most happy, when thou wert beloved by me ere known;
tgt_text.393: and sooner than thou knewest my discipline and my manners :
tgt_text.394: and I taught thee young such wisdom as is to many other older minds denied:
tgt_text.395: and improved thee with mine instruc­ tions, until thou wert chosen a judge ?
tgt_text.396: If thou now sayest, that thou art not happy, because thou hast not the temporary honours and the enjoyments which thou formerly hadst, still thou art not unhappy :
tgt_text.397: for the sorrows wherein thou now art, will in like manner pass away, as thou sayest the enjoyments formerly did.
tgt_text.398: Thinkest thou now, that to thee alone such change and such sorrow happen, and that the like could happen to no other mind, either before thee, or after thee ?
tgt_text.399: Or thinkest thou that to any human mind there can be any thing constant, without change ?
tgt_text.400: Or if it for a time to any man firmly remain, death at .least will take it away, so that it may not be where it before was.
tgt_text.401: What are worldly goods, but an emblem of death ?
tgt_text.402: For death comes for nothing else, but that it may take away life.
tgt_text.403: So also worldly goods come to the mind, in order that they may deprive it of that which is dearest to it in this world;
tgt_text.404: that is, when they depart from it.
tgt_text.405: Say, 0 Mind, whether thou judgest more wisely, seeing that naught of worldly -power can be constant and unchange­ able ?
tgt_text.406: Whether thou despisest them, and of thine own choice canst relinquish them without regret, so that thou canst abide it when they leave thee sorrowful ?
tgt_text.407: THEN began Wisdom to sing, and sung thus:
tgt_text.408: When the sun in the serene heaven brightest shines, then become dark all the stars, because their brightness is no brightness by reason of her.
tgt_text.409: When the south-west wind gently blows, then grow very quickly field flowers;
tgt_text.410: but when the stark wind cometh from the north-east, then does it very soon destroy the rose's beauty.
tgt_text.411: So oftentimes the north wind's tempest stirs the too tranquil sea.
tgt_text.413: that there is nothing of fast-standing work ever remaining in the world!
tgt_text.415: 0 Wisdom, thou who art the mother of all virtues, I cannot gainsay or deny that which thou hast said to me, because it is all true:
tgt_text.416: for I have now learned that those my felicities, and the prosperity, which I formerly thought should be happiness, are no happiness because they so speedily depart.
tgt_text.417: But this has most of all troubled me, when I most deeply think about that which I have clearly learned, that it is the greatest infelicity of this present life, that any one is first happy, and afterwards unhappy.
tgt_text.418: Then auswered Wisdom and Reason, and said:
tgt_text.419: Thou canst not with truth accuse thy fortune and thy happiness, as thou supposest, on account of the false unhappiness which thou art suffering.
tgt_text.420: It is a deception when thou imaginest that thou art unhappy.
tgt_text.421: But if it has so much troubled thee and made thee sad, that thou hast lost the false happiness;
tgt_text.422: then may I plainly tell thee, that thou well knowest that thou hast still the greatest part of thy felicities, which thou formerly hadst.
tgt_text.423: Tell me now, whether thou canst with justice complain of thy mis­ fortunes, as if thou hadst altogether lost thy happiness, since thou hast yet kept entire everything most precious, which thou wast anxious about?
tgt_text.424: How canst thou, then, lament the worse, and the more unworthy, when thou hast retained the more desirable ?
tgt_text.425: Thou knowest, however, that the orna­ ment of all mankind, and the greatest honour, yet lives;
tgt_text.427: He is yet hale and sound, and has enough of every good;
tgt_text.428: for I know that thou wouldest not be unwilling to give thine own life for him, if thou wert to see him in any difficulties.
tgt_text.429: For the man is full of wisdom and virtues, and sufficiently free, as yet, from all earthly fear.
tgt_text.430: He is very sorry for thy troubles, and for thy banishment.
tgt_text.432: is not thy wife also living, the daughter of the same Symmachus ?
tgt_text.433: and she is very prudent, and very modest.
tgt_text.434: She has surpassed all other wives in virtue.
tgt_text.435: All her excel­ lence I may sum up to thee in few words:
tgt_text.436: that is, that she is in all her manners like her father.
tgt_text.437: She now lives for thee, thee alone:
tgt_text.438: for she loves nothing else except thee.
tgt_text.439: Of all good she has enough in this present life, but she has despised it all, beside thee alone.
tgt_text.440: She renounces it all, because she has not thee.
tgt_text.441: Of this alone she feels the want.
tgt_text.442: Because of thy absence, everything which she has seems naught to her.
tgt_text.443: Therefore she is through love of thee, wasted, and almost dead with tears and with grief.
tgt_text.444: What shall we say concern­ ing thy two sons, who are noblemen and counsellors;
tgt_text.445: in whom is manifest the ability and all the virtues of their father, and of their grandfather, so far as young men may most resemble old men ?
tgt_text.446: Therefore I wonder why thou canst not understand, that thou art, as yet, very happy, since thou still livest and art hale.
tgt_text.447: This, indeed, is the greatest possession of mortal men, that they live and are hale;
tgt_text.448: and thou hast yet in addition, all that I have already mentioned to thee.
tgt_text.449: But I know that this is even more valuable than man's life:
tgt_text.450: for many a man would wish that he himself should die, rather than behold his wife and children dying.
tgt_text.451: Why toilest thou then in weeping without a cause ?
tgt_text.452: Thou canst not yet blame thy fortune, nor upbraid thy life:
tgt_text.453: nor art thou altogether brought to naught, as thou thinkest.
tgt_text.454: No unbearable misery has yet befallen thee, for thine anchor is still fast in the earth:
tgt_text.455: that is, the noblemen whom we before mentioned.
tgt_text.456: They suffer thee not to despair of this present life:
tgt_text.457: and again, thine own faith, and the divine love and hope;
tgt_text.458: these then suffer thee not to despair of the ever­ lasting life.
tgt_text.459: Then answered the sorrowful Mind, and said:
tgt_text.460: 0, that the anchors were so secure, and so permanent, both for God, and for the world, as thou sayest!
tgt_text.461: then might we the more easily bear whatsoever misfortunes come upon us.
tgt_text.462: They all seem the lighter to us, so long as the anchors are fast.
tgt_text.463: But thou mayest, nevertheless, perceive how my felici­ ties, and my dignity here, in respect of the world, is changed.§
tgt_text.464: I. THEN answered Wisdom and Reason, and said:
tgt_text.465: I think, however, that I have, in some measure, raised thee up from this sorrow;
tgt_text.466: and almost brought thee to the same dig­ nity which thou before hadst.
tgt_text.467: Only thou art yet too full of what thou hast relinquished, and art therefore grieved.
tgt_text.468: But I cannot endure thy lamentations for the little that thou hast lost.
tgt_text.469: For thou always, with weeping and with sorrow, mournest, if there be to thee a lack of anything desired, though it be of something little.
tgt_text.470: Who was ever in this present life, or who is now, or who shall be yet after us in this world, to whom nothing against his will may happen, either little or much ?
tgt_text.471: Very narrow, and very worthless, are human enjoyments:
tgt_text.472: for either they never come to a man, or they never constantly remain there such as they first came.
tgt_text.473: This I will hereafter more clearly show.
tgt_text.474: We know that some may have enough of all worldly wealth ;
tgt_text.475: but they have nevertheless shame of the wealth, if they are not so Noble in birth as they wish.
tgt_text.477: very noble and eminent on account of their birth, but they are oppressed and made sad by indigence and poverty, so that it were more desirable to them to be unnoble, than so poor, if it were in their power.
tgt_text.478: Many are, indeed, both full noble and full wealthy, and are nevertheless very unhappy, when they have either of these things;
tgt_text.479: either when they have wives as yoke-fellows with them, or have not yoke-fellows.
tgt_text.480: Many have married happily enough, but for want of children, they leave all the riches which they amass to strangers to enjoy, and they are there­ fore unhappy.
tgt_text.481: Some have children enough, but they are sometimes unhealthy, or evil and worthless, or soon depart, so that the parents therefore mourn all their life.
tgt_text.482: Hence no man can, in this present life, be altogether suited in respect of his fortune.
tgt_text.483: Though he have nothing at all to sorrow about, this is able to make him sorrowful, that he knows not what is about to happen to him, whether good or evil, any more than thou knewest;
tgt_text.484: and moreover he fears, that what he then happily enjoys, be may lose.
tgt_text.485: Show me now any man of those who appear to thee the happiest, and who is most distinguished for the enjoyment of his desires.
tgt_text.486: I tell thee at once, that thou mayest observe that he is often immo­ derately troubled for very trifling things:
tgt_text.487: if anything hap­ pens to him against his will, or contrary to his custom, though it be ever so little;
tgt_text.488: unless he may give his nod to every man to run at his will.
tgt_text.489: Wonderfully little can cause the happiest man of all, here in respect of the world, that he should think that his happiness is either much lessened, or entirely lost.
tgt_text.490: Thou now thickest that thou art very miser­ able :
tgt_text.491: and I know that to many a man, it would seem that he were exalted to the heavens, if he had any part of thy felicities, which thou hast still.
tgt_text.492: Moreover, the place wherein thou art now detained, and which thou callest thy place of exile, is the country of the men who were born there, and also of those who by their own will dwell there.
tgt_text.493: Nothing is evil, until a man thinks that it is evil:
tgt_text.494: and though it be now heavy and adverse, yet it will be happiness, if he acts willingly, and patiently bears it.
tgt_text.495: Scarcely any one is so pru­ dent when he is in impatience, as not to wish that his happi­ ness were destroyed.
tgt_text.496: With very much bitterness is the sweetness of this world mingled.
tgt_text.497: Though it seem pleasant to any one, he will be unable to hold it, if it begin to fly from him.
tgt_text.498: Is it not, then, very evident, how inconstant worldly goods are;
tgt_text.499: when they are not able to satisfy the poor, inasmuch as he always desires something of that which he has not;
tgt_text.500: neither do they always dwell with the patient and moderate.§
tgt_text.502: Why seek ye, then, around you the happiness which ye have placed within you by the divine power ?
tgt_text.503: But ye know not what ye do:
tgt_text.505: But I can, with few words, show you what is the roof of all happiness:
tgt_text.506: for which I know thou wilt strive until thou obtainest it:
tgt_text.508: Canst thou now discover whether thou hast anything more precious to thee than thyself?
tgt_text.509: I think, though, thou wilt say that thou hast nothing more precious.
tgt_text.510: I know, if thou badst full power of thyself, thou wouldest then have something in thyself, which thou never, with thine own con­ sent, wouldest relinquish, nor could Fortune take it from thee.
tgt_text.511: Therefore I advise thee, that thou learn, that there is no happiness in this present life.
tgt_text.512: But learn that nothing is better in this present life than reason:
tgt_text.513: because man cannot by any means lose it.
tgt_text.514: Therefore that wealth is better, which never can be lost, than that which may, and shall be lost.
tgt_text.515: Is it not, now, clearly enough proved to thee, that Fortune cannot give thee any happiness?
tgt_text.516: because each is insecure, both Fortune and happiness;
tgt_text.517: for these goods are very frail, and very perishable.
tgt_text.518: Indeed, every one who possesses these worldly goods, either knows that they are about to depart from him, or he is ignorant of it.
tgt_text.519: If, then, he is ignorant of it, what happiness has he in riches, when he is so foolish, and so unwise as to be ignorant of this ?
tgt_text.520: But if he knows it, then he dreads that they may be lost, and also is well aware that he must leave them.
tgt_text.521: Continual fear suffers not any man to be happy.
tgt_text.522: If then any man cares not whether he have that wealth, which be may not have, even when be has it;
tgt_text.523: truly that is for little happiness, or none, which a man may so easily lose.
tgt_text.524: I think, moreover, that I had formerly with sufficient clearness taught thee by many arguments, that the souls of men are immortal and eternal:
tgt_text.525: and it is so evident that no man need doubt it, that all men end in death, and also their riches.
tgt_text.526: Therefore I wonder why meu are so irra­ tional as to think that this present life can make man happy whilst he lives, seeing that it cannot, after it is ended, make him miserable.
tgt_text.527: But we certainly know of innumerable men who have sought eternal happiness, not by this alone, that they chose the bodily death, but they also willingly submitted to many grievous torments on account of the eternal life:
tgt_text.528: those were all the holy martyrs.
tgt_text.529: THEN began Wisdom to sing, and sung thus,—he prolonged with verse the speech that he before made, and said:
tgt_text.530: He who will build a firm house, must not set it upon the highest hill;
tgt_text.531: and he who will seek heavenly wisdom, must not seek it with arrogance.
tgt_text.532: And, again, he who is desirous to build a firm house, should not set it on sand-hills.
tgt_text.533: So also if thou art desirous to build wisdom, set it not on avarice..
tgt_text.534: For as thirsty sand swallows the rain, so avarice swallows the perishable riches of this middle-earth, because it is always thirsty after them.
tgt_text.535: A house cannot long stand on the high mountain, if a very violent wind press on it;
tgt_text.536: nor has it that which may stand on the thirsty sand for excessive rain.
tgt_text.537: Thus also the human mind is subverted, and moved from its place, when the wind of strong afflictions agitate it, or the rain of immoderate care.
tgt_text.538: But he who wishes to have eternal happi­ ness, should fly from the dangerous splendour of this middle- earth, and build the house of his mind on the firm rock of humility.
tgt_text.539: For Christ dwells in the vale of humility, and in the mind of wisdom.
tgt_text.540: Therefore the wise man ever leads all his life in joy, unchangeable and secure, when he despises both these earthly goods, and also the evils;
tgt_text.541: and hopes for the future, which are eternal.
tgt_text.542: For God preserves him every­ where, perpetually dwelling in the enjoyments of his mind:
tgt_text.543: though the wind of troubles, and the continual care of these worldly goods, blow upon him.
tgt_text.544: WHEN Wisdom and Reason had thus sung this lay, then began he again to make a speech, and thus said:
tgt_text.545: Methiuks that we may now argue more closely, and with profounder words;
tgt_text.546: for I perceive that my doctrine, in some degree, enters into thy mind, and thou understandest well enough what I say unto thee.
tgt_text.547: Consider, now, what is thine own of all these worldly possessions and riches;
tgt_text.548: or what of great price thou hast therein, if thou rationally examinest it.
tgt_text.549: What bast thou from the gifts and from the riches, which thou sayest fortune gives you, even though they were eternal ?
tgt_text.550: Tell me now, whether in thy judgment, this thy wealth, is so precious to thee from its own nature.
tgt_text.551: But I say to thee that it is from its own nature, not from thine.
tgt_text.552: If it, then, is from its own nature and not from thine, why art thou ever the better for its good ?
tgt_text.553: Tell me what of it seems to thee most precious:
tgt_text.556: But though it be good and precious, yet will he be more celebrated and more beloved, who gives it, than he who gathers, and takes it from others.
tgt_text.557: Riches, also, are more honourable, and more estimable when any one gives them, than they are when he gathers and keeps them.
tgt_text.558: Covetous­ ness, indeed, makes misers loathsome both to God and to men:
tgt_text.559: and liberality always makes them estimable, and famous, and worthy, both to God and to the men whom they befriend.
tgt_text.560: Since, then, wealth cannot be both with those who give it, and with those who receive it;
tgt_text.561: all wealth is therefore better and more precious given than held.
tgt_text.562: If even all the wealth of this middle-earth should come to one man, would not all other men be poor, except one?
tgt_text.563: It is sufficiently evident that the good word and good fame of every man is better and more precious than any wealth :
tgt_text.564: for this word fills the ears of all those who hear it, and yet is not the less with him who speaks it.
tgt_text.565: His heart's recess it opens, and the locked heart of another it penetrates, and in the way between them it is not lessened, nor can any one with sword slay it, nor with rope bind, nor does it ever perish.
tgt_text.566: But these your riches, if they were always yours, there does not the sooner seem to you enough of them;
tgt_text.567: and if ye may not give them to other men, ye never the more therewith satisfy their want and their de­ sire, Though thou divide them as small as dust, yet thou canat not satisfy all men equally:
tgt_text.568: and when thou hast divided all, thou wilt tLon be poor thyself.
tgt_text.569: Are the riches of this middle-earth worthy of a man when no one can fully have them ?
tgt_text.570: nor can they enrich any man, unless they bring another to poverty.
tgt_text.571: Does the beauty of gems attract your eyes to them, to wonder at them ?
tgt_text.572: I know that they do so.
tgt_text.573: But the excellence of the beauty which is in gems is theirs, not yours.
tgt_text.574: Wherefore I am excessively astonished why the good of the irrational creature seems to you better than your own good:
tgt_text.575: why ye so immoderately admire gems, or any of the insensible things which have not reason :
tgt_text.576: for they with no justice can deserve that ye should admire them.
tgt_text.577: Though they are God's creatures, they are not to be compared with you.
tgt_text.578: For either it is no good for yourselves, or at least for little good, compared with you.
tgt_text.579: We too much despise our­ selves when we love that which is beneath us, in our own power, more than ourselves, or the Lord who made us, and gave us all good things.
tgt_text.580: Do fair lands delight thee ?§ I. THEN answered the Mind to Reason, and said:
tgt_text.581: Why should not fair land delight me ?
tgt_text.582: Is not that the fairest part of God's creatures ?
tgt_text.583: Full often we rejoice at the serene sea, and also admire the beauty of the sun, and of the moon, and of all the stars.
tgt_text.584: Then answered Wisdom and Reason to the Mind, and thus said :
tgt_text.585: What belongs to thee of their fairness ?
tgt_text.586: Darest thou to boast that their fairness is thine ?
tgt_text.588: Dost thou not know that thou madest none of them ?
tgt_text.589: But if thou wilt glory, glory in God.
tgt_text.590: Dost thou rejoice in the fair blossoms of Easter, as if thou madest them ?
tgt_text.591: Canst thou then make anything of this kind, or hast thou any part in the work ?
tgt_text.594: Is it through thy power that the harvest is so rich in fruits ?
tgt_text.595: Do not 1 know that it is not through thy power ?
tgt_text.596: Why art thou then inflamed with such vain glory ?
tgt_text.597: or why lovest thou external goods so im­ moderately, as if they were thy own?
tgt_text.598: Thinkest thou that fortune can cause to thee, that those things should be thy own, which their own natures have made foreign to thee ?
tgt_text.600: It is not natural to thee that thou shouldest pos­ sess them;
tgt_text.601: nor is it their nature, that they should follow thee.
tgt_text.602: But heavenly things are natural to thee, not these earthly.
tgt_text.603: These earthly fruits are created for the food of cattle;
tgt_text.604: and worldly riches are created for a snare to those men who are like cattle, that is, vicious and intemperate.
tgt_text.605: To those, more­ over, they come ofteuest.
tgt_text.606: But if thou wouldest have the measure, and wouldest know what is needful;
tgt_text.607: then is it, meat and drink, and clothes, and tools for such craft as thou knowest, which is natural to thee, and which is right for thee to possess.
tgt_text.608: What advantage is it to thee, that thou shouldest desire these present goods beyond measure, when they can neither help thee nor themselves ?
tgt_text.609: With very little of them nature has enough.
tgt_text.610: With so much she has enough, as we before mentioned.
tgt_text.611: If thou givest her more, either it hurts thee, or it at least is unpleasant to thee, or inconvenient, or dangerous,—all that thou dost beyond measure.
tgt_text.612: If thou beyond measure eatest, or drinkest, or hast more clothes on thee, than thou needest, the superfluity becomes to thee either pain, or loathing, or inconvenience, or danger.
tgt_text.613: If thou thinkest that wonderful apparel is any honour, then ascribe I the honour to the artificer who made it, not to thee.
tgt_text.614: The artificer is God, whose skill I therein praise.
tgt_text.615: Thinkest thou that the multitude of thy men can make thee happy?
tgt_text.617: But if they are wicked and deceitful, then are they more dangerous, and more troublesome to thee, had, than not had:
tgt_text.618: for wicked thanes are always their lord's enemies.
tgt_text.619: But if they are good and faithful to their lord, and sincere, is not that, then, their good, not thine ?
tgt_text.620: How canst thou, then, appropriate to thyself their good?
tgt_text.621: If thou boastest of it dost thou not boast of their good, not of thine ?§ II.
tgt_text.622: It is now plainly enough shown to thee that none of those goods is thine which we have already spoken about, and thou didst think should be thine.
tgt_text.623: If, then, the beauty and wealth of this world is not to be desired, why dost thou re­ pine on account of what thou bast lost?
tgt_text.624: or wherefore dost thou long for what thou formerly hadst?
tgt_text.625: If it is fair, that is of their own nature, not of thine:
tgt_text.626: it is their fairness, not thine.
tgt_text.627: Why then dost thou delight in their fairness ?
tgt_text.628: what of it belongs to thee P Thou didst not make it, nor are they thine own.
tgt_text.629: If they are good and fair, then were they so made;
tgt_text.630: and such they would be, though thou never hadst them.
tgt_text.631: Thinkest thou that they are ever the more precious, because they were lent for thy use ?
tgt_text.632: But, because foolish men admire them,and they to them seem precious, therefore thou gatherest and keepest them in thy hoard.
tgt_text.633: How then dost thou hope to have happiness from anything of this sort ?
tgt_text.634: Believe me now, I say it unto thee, thou hast nought there­ from, except that thou toilest to avoid poverty, and therefore gatherest more than thou needest.
tgt_text.635: But nevertheless I very well know, that all which I here speak, is contrary to thy will.
tgt_text.636: But your goods are not what ye think they are:
tgt_text.637: for he who desires to have much and various provision, needs also much help.
tgt_text.638: The old saying is very true, which men for­ merly said;
tgt_text.639: that those need much, who desire to possess much, and those need very little, who do not desire more than enough.
tgt_text.640: But they hope by means of superfluity to satisfy their greediness;
tgt_text.642: I wot that ye think ye have no natural good or happiness within your­ selves, because ye seek them without you, from external creatures.
tgt_text.643: So is it perverted, that man, though he is divinely rational, thinks that he has not happiness enough in himself, unless he collects more of irrational creatures than he has need of, or than is suitable for him:
tgt_text.644: whilst the irrational cattle are desirous of no other wealth, but think that sum­ cient for them, which they have within their own skin, in addition to the fodder which is natural to them.
tgt_text.645: Whatsoever, then, though little, ye have of divine in your soul, is the un­ derstanding, and memory, and the rational will which delights in them both.
tgt_text.646: He therefore who has these three, has his maker's likeness, as much as any creature can at all have its maker's likeness.
tgt_text.647: But ye seek the happiuess of the exalted nature, and its dignity, from low and perishable things.
tgt_text.648: But ye understand not how great injury ye do to God your creator.
tgt_text.649: For he would that all men should be governors of all other creatures.
tgt_text.650: But ye degrade your highest dignity below the meanest creatures of all:
tgt_text.651: and thereby ye have shown that, according to your own judgment, ye make yourselves worse than your own possessions, now ye think that your false riches are your happiness, and are persuaded that all your worldly goods are superior to yourselves.
tgt_text.652: So indeed it is, when ye so will!§ III.
tgt_text.653: It is the condition of the life of men, that they then only are before all other creatures, when they themselves know what they are, and whence they are:
tgt_text.654: and they are worse than cattle, when they will not know what they are, or whence they are.
tgt_text.655: It is the nature of cattle that they know not what they are;
tgt_text.656: but it is a fault in meo, that they know not what they arc.
tgt_text.657: It is therefore very plain to thee, that ye are in error, when ye think that any one can be made honourable by ex­ ternal riches.
tgt_text.658: If any one is made honourable with any riches, and endowed with any valuable possessions, does not the honour then belong to that which makes him honourable ?
tgt_text.659: That is to be praised somewhat more rightly.
tgt_text.660: That which is adorned with anything else, is not therefore fairer, though the ornaments be fair, with which it is adorned.
tgt_text.661: If it before was vile, it is not on that account fairer.
tgt_text.662: Know thou, as­ suredly, that no good hurts him who possesses it.
tgt_text.663: Thou knowest that I lie not to thee, and also knowest that riches often hurt those who possess them, in many things :
tgt_text.664: and in this chiefly, that men become so lifted-up on account of riches, that frequently the worst man of all, and the most unworthy of all, thinks that he is deserving of all the wealth which-is in this world, if he knew how he might arrive at it.
tgt_text.665: He who has great riches, dreads many an enemy.
tgt_text.666: If he had no pos­ sessions, he would not need to dread any.
tgt_text.667: If thou wert travelling, and hadst much gold about thee, and thou then shouldest meet with a gang of thieves, then wouldest not thou be anxious for thy life ?
tgt_text.668: If thou hadst nothing of this kind, then thou wonldest not need to dread anything, but mightest go singing the old adage which men formerly sung, that the naked traveller fears nothing.
tgt_text.669: When thou then wert safe, and the thieves were departed from thee, then mightest thou scoff at these present riches, and mightest say, 0, how good and pleasant it is, that any one should possess great wealth, since he who obtains it is never secure!
tgt_text.670: WHEN Reason had made this speech, she began to sing, and thus said:
tgt_text.671: 0, how happy was the first age of this middle- earth, when to every man there seemed enough in the fruits of the earth!
tgt_text.672: There were not then splendid houses, nor various sweetmeats nor drinks;
tgt_text.673: nor were they desirous of costly apparel, for they as yet were not, nor did they see or hear anything of them.
tgt_text.674: They cared not for any luxury, but very temperately followed nature.
tgt_text.675: They always ate once in the day, and that was in the evening.
tgt_text.676: They ate the fruits of trees, and herbs.
tgt_text.677: They drank no pure wine, nor knew they how to mix any liquor with honey, nor cared they for silken garments of various colours.
tgt_text.678: They always slept out in the shade of trees.
tgt_text.679: They drank the water of the clear springs.
tgt_text.680: No merchant visited island or coast, nor did any man as yet hear of any ship-army, nor even the mention of any war.
tgt_text.681: The earth was not yet polluted with the blood of slain men, nor was any one even wounded.
tgt_text.682: They did not as yet look upon evil-minded men.
tgt_text.684: nor did any man love them.
tgt_text.685: Alas, that our times cannot now become such !
tgt_text.686: But now the covetousness of men is as burning as the fire in the hell, which is in the mountain that is called Ætna, in the island that is called Sicily.
tgt_text.687: The mountain is always burning with brimstone, and burns up all the near places thereabout.
tgt_text.688: Alas, what was the first avaricious man, who first began to dig the earth after gold, and after gems, and found the dan­ gerous treasure, which before was hid and covered with the earth!§
tgt_text.689: I. WHEN Wisdom had sung this lay, then began he again to speak, and thus said:
tgt_text.690: What more can I say to thee, concerning the dignity and concerning the power of this world ?
tgt_text.691: For power ye would raise yourselves up to heaven, if ye were able.
tgt_text.692: This is, because ye do not remember, nor understand, the heavenly power and the dignity which is your own, and whence ye came.
tgt_text.693: What, then, with regard to your wealth, and your power, which ye now call dignity, if it should come to the worst men of all, and to him that of all is unworthiest of it, as it lately did to this same Theodoric, and also formerly to Nero the Cæsar, and moreover fre­ quently to many like them ?
tgt_text.694: Will he not then do as they did, and still do ?
tgt_text.695: slay and destroy all the rich who are under, or anywhere near him, as the flame of fire does the dry heath field, or as the burning brimstone burneth the mountain which we call Ætna, which is in the island of Sicily ?
tgt_text.696: very like to the great flood which was formerly in Noab's days.
tgt_text.697: I think that thou mayest remember that your ancient Roman senators formerly, in the days of Tarquin the proud king, on account of his arrogance first banished the kingly name from the city of Rome.
tgt_text.698: And again, in like manner, the consuls who had driven them out, these they were afterwards desirous to expel on account of their arrogance (but they could not) ;
tgt_text.699: because the latter government of the consuls still less pleased the Roman senators, than the former one of the kings.
tgt_text.700: If, however, it at any time happens, as it very seldom does, happen, that power and dignity come to good men and to wise;
tgt_text.701: what is there then worthy of esteem, except the good and the dignity of him, the good king, not of the power?
tgt_text.702: For power never is good unless he is good who possesses it.
tgt_text.703: Therefore if power be good, it is the good of the man, not of the power.
tgt_text.704: Hence it is, that no man by his authority comes to virtues and to merit:
tgt_text.705: but by his virtues, and by his merit, he comes to authority and to power.
tgt_text.706: Therefore is no man for his power the better;
tgt_text.707: but for his virtues he is good, if he be good:
tgt_text.708: and for his virtues he is deserving of power, if he be deserving of it.
tgt_text.710: and when ye have learned it, do not then despise it.
tgt_text.711: Then I say to you, without all doubt, that ye may through it arrive at power, though ye be not desirous of power.
tgt_text.712: Ye need not be anxious for power, nor press after it.
tgt_text.713: If ye are wise and good, it will follow you, though.
tgt_text.714: ye are not desirous of it.
tgt_text.715: But tell me now, what is your most valuable wealth and power, which ye most desire ?
tgt_text.716: I know, however, that it is this present life, and this perishing wealth, which we before spoke about.§ II.
tgt_text.717: 0, ye beastlike men, do ye know what wealth is, and power, and worldly goods ?
tgt_text.718: They are your lords and your rulers, not ye theirs!
tgt_text.719: If ye now saw some mouse that was lord over other mice, and set them judgments, and subjected them to tribute, how wonderful would ye think it!
tgt_text.720: What scorn would ye have, and with what laughter would ye be moved!
tgt_text.721: How much greater, then, is man's body, compared with the mind, than the mouse compared with the man ?
tgt_text.722: Indeed, ye may easily conceive, if ye will carefully consider and examine it, that no creature's body is more tender than man's.
tgt_text.723: The least flies can injure it:
tgt_text.724: and the gnats with very little stings hurt it:
tgt_text.725: and also the small worms which corrupt the man both inwardly and outwardly, and sometimes make him almost dead.
tgt_text.726: Moreover the little flea sometimes kills him.
tgt_text.727: Such things injure him both inwardly and outwardly.
tgt_text.728: Wherein can any man injure another, except in his body?
tgt_text.729: or again in their riches, which ye call goods?
tgt_text.730: No man can injure the rational mind, or cause it that it should not be what it is.
tgt_text.731: This is very evidently to be known by a certain Roman nobleman, who was called Liherius.
tgt_text.732: He was put to many torments because he would not inform against his as­ sociates, who conspired with him against the king who had with injustice conquered them.
tgt_text.733: When he was led before the enraged king, and he commanded him to say who were his associates who had conspired with him, then bit he off his own tongue, and immediately cast it before the face of the tyrant.
tgt_text.734: Hence it happened that, to the wise man, that was the cause of praise and honour, which the unjust king ap­ pointed to him for punishment.
tgt_text.735: What is it, moreover, that any man can do to another, which he may not do to him in like manner ?
tgt_text.736: and if he may not, another man may.
tgt_text.737: We have learned also concerning the cruel Busiris, who was in Egypt.
tgt_text.738: This tyrant's custom was, that he would very honour­ ably receive every stranger, and behave very courteously to him when first he came.
tgt_text.739: But afterwards, before he departed from him, he would be slain.
tgt_text.740: And then it happened that Hercules, the son of Jove, came to him.
tgt_text.741: Then would he do to him, as he had done to many a stranger before:
tgt_text.742: he would drown him in the river which is called Nile.
tgt_text.743: Then was he stronger, and drowned him, very justly by God's judgment, as he many another before bad done!
tgt_text.744: So also, Regulus, the illustrious consul!
tgt_text.745: When he fought against the Africans, he obtained an almost indescribable victory over the Africans.
tgt_text.746: When he had grievously slain them, lie gave order to bind them, and lay them in heaps.
tgt_text.747: Then happened it very soon, that he was bound with their fetters.
tgt_text.749: What good is power, when he who possesses it, can in no wise, by his own strength, avoid suffering from other men the same evil which he before did to others ?
tgt_text.750: Is not, then, power in that case naught ?§ III.
tgt_text.752: If dignity and power were good of its own nature, and had power of itself, would it follow the most wicked men, as it now sometimes doth ?
tgt_text.753: Dost thou not know, that it is neither natural nor usual, that any contrary thing should be mixed with other contrary, or have any fellowship therewith P
tgt_text.754: But nature refuses it that they should be mixed together;
tgt_text.755: still more that good and evil should be together.
tgt_text.756: Hence it is very manifestly shown to thee, that this present authority, and these worldly goods, and this power, are not good of their own nature, and of their own efficacy, nor have any power of themselves:
tgt_text.757: since they are willing to cleave to the worst men, and permit them to be their lords.
tgt_text.758: There is not indeed any doubt of this, that often the most wicked men of all come to power and to dignity.
tgt_text.759: If power, then, were good of its own nature, and of its own efficacy, it never would be subservient to the evil, but to the good:
tgt_text.760: The same is to be thought with regard to all the goods which fortune brings in this present life, both of talents and possessions:
tgt_text.761: for they sometimes come to the most wicked.
tgt_text.762: We very well know that no man doubts of this, that he is powerful iu his strength, who is seen to perform laborious work:
tgt_text.763: any more than if he be anything, any one doubts that he is so.
tgt_text.764: Thus the art of music causes the man to be a musician, and medical knowledge to be a physician, and rhetoric causes him to be a rhetorician.
tgt_text.765: In like manner also the nature of things causes to every man that good cannot be mixed with evil, nor evil with good.
tgt_text.766: Though they are both in one man, yet is each in him separately.
tgt_text.767: Nature will never suffer anything contrary to mix, for each of them rejects the other, and each will be what it is.
tgt_text.768: Riches cannot cause the miser not to be a miser, or satisfy his boundless desires, nor can authority make its possessor powerful.
tgt_text.769: Since, then, every creature avoids that which is contrary to it, and very earnestly endeavours to repel it, what two things are.
tgt_text.770: more contrary to each other than good and evil ?
tgt_text.772: Hence thou mayest understand, that if the goods of this present life through themselves, had power of themselves, and were in their own nature good, then would they always cleave to him who did good with them, not evil.
tgt_text.773: But wheresoever they are good, they are good through the good of the good man, who works good with them, and he is good through God.
tgt_text.774: If, then, an evil man has it, it is evil through the man's evil, who doth evil with it, and through the devil.
tgt_text.775: What good is wealth, then, when it cannot satisfy the boundless desires of the miser ?
tgt_text.776: or power, when it cannot make its possessor powerful, but the wicked passions bind him, with their indissoluble chaius!
tgt_text.777: Though any one give to any evil man power, the power does not make him good nor meritorious, if he before were not:
tgt_text.778: but exposes his evil, if he before were evil, and makes it then manifest, if it before were not.
tgt_text.779: For though he formerly desired evil, he then knew not how he might so fully show it, before lie had full power.
tgt_text.780: It is through folly that ye are pleased, because ye can make a name, aDd call that happiness which is none, and that merit which is none:
tgt_text.781: for they show by their ending, when they come to an end, that neither wealth, nor power, nor dignity, is to be considered as the true happiness.
tgt_text.782: So is it most as­ suredly to be said concerning all the worldly goods that fortune brings;
tgt_text.783: that there is nothing therein which is to be desired, because there is nothing therein of natural good which comes from themselves.
tgt_text.784: This is evident from hence, that they do not always join themselves to the good, nor make the evil good, to whom they moat frequently join them­ selves.
tgt_text.786: When Wisdom had thus made this speech, then began he again to sing, and thus said:
tgt_text.787: We know what cruel- ties, and what ruins, what adulteries, and what wickedness, and what impiety, the unrighteous Cæsar, Nero, wrought.
tgt_text.788: He at one time gave order to burn all the city of Rome at once, after the example that formerly the city of Troy was burned!
tgt_text.789: He was desirous also to see how it would burn, and how long, and how light, in comparison of the other:
tgt_text.790: and besides gave order to slay all the wisest senators of the Ro­ mans, and also his own mother, and his own brother!
tgt_text.791: He moreover slew his own wife with a sword.
tgt_text.792: And for such things he was in.
tgt_text.793: no wise grieved, but was the blither, and re­ joiced at it!
tgt_text.794: And yet amid such crimes all this middle-earth was nevertheless subject to him, from eastward to westward, and again from southward to northward:
tgt_text.795: it was all in his power.
tgt_text.797: Power could not take away the empire from this unrighteous Cæsar, and cor­ rect this madness in him, if be would?
tgt_text.798: Yes, 0 yes, I know that be could, if he would!
tgt_text.800: how heavy a yoke did he lay on all those who in his times were living on the earth!
tgt_text.801: and how oft his sword was stained with innocent blood!
tgt_text.802: Was it not then sufficiently evident, that power of its own.
tgt_text.803: nature was not good, when he was not good to whom it came?
tgt_text.804: WHEN Wisdom had sung this lay he was silent, and the Mind then answered, and thus said:
tgt_text.805: 0 Reason, indeed thou knowest that covetousness and the greatness of this earthly power never well pleased me, nor did I altogether very much yearn after this earthly authority.
tgt_text.806: But nevertheless I was desirous of materials for the work which I was commanded to perform;
tgt_text.807: that was, that I might honourably and fitly guide and exercise the power which was committed to me.
tgt_text.808: More­ over, thou knowest that no man can show any skill, nor ex­ ercise or control any power, without tools and materials.
tgt_text.809: That is, of every craft the materials, without which man cannot exercise the craft.
tgt_text.810: This, then, is a king's materials and his tools to reign with:
tgt_text.811: that he have his land well peopled;
tgt_text.812: he must have prayer-men, and soldiers, and work­ men.
tgt_text.813: Thou knowest that without these tools no king can show his craft.
tgt_text.814: This is also his materials which he must have besides the tools;
tgt_text.817: land to inhabit, and gifts and weapons, and meat, and ale, and clothes, and whatsoever is necessary for the three classes.
tgt_text.818: He cannot without these preserve the tools, nor without the tools accomplish any of those things which he is commanded to perform.
tgt_text.819: Therefore I was desirous of materials wherewith to exercise the power, that my talents and power should not be forgotten and con­ cealed.
tgt_text.820: For every craft and every power soon becomes old, and is passed over in silence, if it be without wisdom :
tgt_text.821: for no man can accomplish any craft without wisdom.
tgt_text.822: Because whatsoever is done through folly, no one can ever reckon for craft.
tgt_text.823: This is now especially to be said;
tgt_text.824: that I wished to live honourably whilst I lived, and after my life, to leave to the men who were after me, my.
tgt_text.825: memory in good works.§ I. WHEN this was spoken, the Mind remained silent, and Reason began to speak, and thus said:
tgt_text.826: 0, Mind, one evil is very greatly to be shunned;
tgt_text.827: that is, that which very con­ tinually and very grievously deceives the minds of all those men, who are in their nature excellent, and nevertheless are not yet arrived at the roof of perfect virtues.
tgt_text.828: This, then, is the desire of false glory, and of unrighteous power, and of unbounded fame of good works among all people.
tgt_text.829: Many men are desirous of power, because they would have good fame, though they be unworthy of it:
tgt_text.830: and even the most wicked of all are desirous of the same.
tgt_text.831: But he who will wisely and diligently inquire concerning fame, will very soon perceive how little it is, and how slender and how frail, and how destitute of all good.
tgt_text.832: If thou wilt now studiously in­ quire, and wilt understand concerning the circumference of all this earth, from the eastward of this middle-earth to the westward, and from the southward to the northward, as thou hast learned in the book which is called Astrologium ;
tgt_text.833: then mayest thou perceive that it is all, compared with the heaven, like a little point on a broad board, or the boss on.
tgt_text.834: a shield, according to the opinion of wise men.
tgt_text.835: Dost thou not know what thou hast learned in the books of Ptolemy, who wrote of the measure of all this middle-earth in one book ?
tgt_text.836: Therein thou migbtest see that all mankind, and all cattle, do not occupy anywhere nigh the fourth part of this earth, which meu are able to go over.
tgt_text.837: For they cannot inhabit it all;
tgt_text.838: some part for heat, some for cold;
tgt_text.839: and the greatest part of it the sea has covered.
tgt_text.840: Take, then, from this fourth part, in thy mind, all that the sea has covered of it, and all the shards which it has taken from it;
tgt_text.841: and all that fens and moors have taken of it, and all that in all countries lies waste,, then mayest thou understand, that, of the whole, there is not more left for men to inhabit, than as it were a small enclosure.
tgt_text.842: It is, then, in foolish labour that ye toil all your life, because ye wish beyond measure to spread your fame over such an en­ closure as that is which men inhabit in this world;
tgt_text.843: almost like a point compared with the other!
tgt_text.844: But what of spacious, or of great, or of honourable, has this your glory, when ye therein inhabit the fifth part halved of land and desert ?
tgt_text.845: so is it narrowed with sea, with fen, and with all!
tgt_text.846: Wherefore desire ye, then, too immoderately, that ye should spread your name over the tenth part, since there is not more of it, with sea, with fen, and with all!§ II.
tgt_text.847: Consider also that in this little park which we before have spoken about, dwell very many nations, and various, and very unlike both in speech, and in mauners, and in all the customs of all the nations, which ye now very immoderately desire that ye should spread your name over.
tgt_text.848: This ye never can do, because their language is divided into seventy-two;
tgt_text.849: and every one of these languages is divided among many nations, and they are separated and divided by sea, and by woods, aud by mountains, and by fells, and by many and various wastes, and impassable lands, so that even merchants do not visit it.
tgt_text.850: But how, then, can any great man's name singly come there, when no man there hears even the name of the city, or of the country, of which he is an inhabitant?
tgt_text.851: Therefore I know not through what folly ye desire that ye should spread your name over all the earth !
tgt_text.852: That ye cannot do, nor even anywhere nigh.
tgt_text.853: Moreover, thou knowest how great the power of the Romans was in the days of Marcus, the consul, who was by another name called Tullius, and by a third Cicero.
tgt_text.854: But he has shown in one of his books, that, as then, the Roman name had not passed beyond the moun­ tains that we call Caucasus, nor had the Scythians who dwell on the other side of those mountains even heard the name of the city or of the people:
tgt_text.855: but at that time it had first come to the Parthians, and was then very new.
tgt_text.856: But nevertheless it was very terrible thereabout to many a people.
tgt_text.857: Dosye not then perceive how narrow this your fame will be, which ye labour about, and unrighteously toil to spread ?
tgt_text.858: How great fame, and how great honour, dost thou think one Roman could have in that land, where even the name of the city was never heard, nor did the fame of the whole people ever come ?
tgt_text.859: Though any man immoderately and unreasonably desire that he may spread his fame over all the earth, he cannot bring it to pass, because the manners of the nations are very unlike, and their institutions very various;
tgt_text.860: so that in one country that pleases best which is at the same time in another deemed most reprehensible, and moreover deserving of great punish­ ment.
tgt_text.861: Therefore no man can have the same praise in every land, because in every land that pleases not, which in another pleases.§ III.
tgt_text.862: Therefore every man should be well contented with this, that he be approved in his own country.
tgt_text.863: Though he be desirous of more, he cannot, indeed, bring it to pass:
tgt_text.864: because it is seldom that aught in any degree pleases many men;
tgt_text.865: on which account the praise of a good man is frequently con­ fined within the same country where he is an inhabitant;
tgt_text.866: and also because it has often very unfortunately happened, through the misconduct of writers, that they from their sloth, and from negligence, and from carelessness, have left un­ written the manners of the men, and their deeds, who in their days were most famous, and most desirous of honour.
tgt_text.867: And even if they had written the whole of their lives and of their actions, as they ought if they were honest, would not the writings nevertheless wax old and perish, as often as it was done, even as the writers did, and those about whom they wrote ?
tgt_text.868: And yet it seems to you that ye have eternal honour, if ye can, in all your life, earn that ye may have good fame, after your days!
tgt_text.869: If thou now comparest the duration of this present life, and this temporal, with the duration of the never-ending life, what is it then ?
tgt_text.870: Compare now the length of the time wherein thou mayest wink thine eye, with ten thousand winters;
tgt_text.871: then have the times somewhat of like, though it be little;
tgt_text.872: that is, that each of them has an end.
tgt_text.873: But compare these ten thousand years, and even more if thou wilt, with the eternal and the never-euding life;
tgt_text.874: then wilt thou not find there anything of like, because the ten thousand years, though it seem long, will shorten:
tgt_text.875: but of the other there never will come an end.
tgt_text.876: Therefore it is not to be com­ pared, the ending with the never ending!
tgt_text.877: If thou even reckon from the beginning of this middle-earth to the end, and then compare the years with that which has no end, there will be nothing of like.
tgt_text.878: So is also the fame of celebrated men.
tgt_text.879: Though it sometimes may be long and endure many years, it is nevertheless very short compared with that which never ends!§
tgt_text.881: And ye nevertheless care not whether ye do any good, on any other account, than for the little praise of the people, and for the short fame which we have before spoken about.
tgt_text.882: Ye labour for this, and overlook the excellences of your mind, and of your understanding, and of your reason, and would have the reward of your good works from the re­ port of strangers!
tgt_text.883: Ye desire to obtain then the reward which ye should seek from God!
tgt_text.884: But thou hast heard that it long ago happened, that a very wise man, and very noble, began to try a philosopher, and scoffed at him, because he so arrogantly lifted himself up, and proclaimed this, that he was a philoso­ pher.
tgt_text.885: He did not make it known by any talents, but by false and proud boasting.
tgt_text.886: Then the wise man would prove him, whether he were as wise as he himself thought that he was.
tgt_text.887: He therefore began to revile, and speak ill of him.
tgt_text.888: Then the philosopher heard very patiently the wise man's words for some time.
tgt_text.889: But after he had heard his reviling, he then de- fended himself against him very impatiently, though he before pretended that he was a philosopher, and asked him again, whether he thought him to be a philosopher or not.
tgt_text.890: Then answered the wise man to him, and said:
tgt_text.891: I would say that thou wert a philosopher, if thou wert patient, and able to be silent.
tgt_text.892: How lasting was to him the fame which he before falsely sought!
tgt_text.893: How did be not immediately burst because of one answer!
tgt_text.894: What has it then availed the best men who were before us, that they so greatly desired vain glory and fame after their death ?
tgt_text.895: Or what does it profit those who now are ?
tgt_text.896: Therefore it were to every man more needful that he were desirous of good actions thau of deceitful fame.
tgt_text.897: What has he from this fame, after the separation of the body and the soul ?
tgt_text.898: Do we not know that all men bodily die, and yet the soul is living ?
tgt_text.899: But the soul goes very freely to the heavens, after it is set loose and liberated from the prison of the body.
tgt_text.900: It then despises all these earthly things, and re­ joices in this, that it may enjoy the heavenly, after it is taken away from the earthly.
tgt_text.901: Then the mind will itself be a witness of God's will.
tgt_text.902: WHEN Wisdom had made this speech, then began he again to sing, and thus singing, said:
tgt_text.903: Whosoever desires to have vain fame and unprofitable glory, let him behold on the four sides of him, how spacious the expanse of the heaven is, and how narrow the space of the earth is, though it seem large to us!
tgt_text.904: Then may it shame him of the spreading of his fame, because he cannot even spread it over the narrow earth alone!
