tgt_text.905: 0, ye proud, why are ye desirous to sustain with your necks this deadly yoke ?
tgt_text.906: or why are ye in such vain labour, because ye would spread your fame over so many nations ?
tgt_text.907: Though it even happen that the farthest nations exalt your name, and praise you in many a language;
tgt_text.908: and though any one with great nobleness add to his birth, and prosper in all riches, and in all splendour, death nevertheless cares not for things of this sort, but he despises nobility, and devours the rich and the poor alike, and thus levels the rich and the poor!
tgt_text.909: What are now the bones of the celebrated and the wise goldsmith, Weland?
tgt_text.910: I have therefore said the wise, because to the skilful his skill can never be lost, nor can any man more easily take it from him than he can turn aside the sun from her place.
tgt_text.911: Where are now the bones of Weland ?
tgt_text.912: or who knows now where they were ?
tgt_text.913: Or where is now the illus­ trious and the patriotic consul of the Romans, who was called Brutus, by another name Cassius ?
tgt_text.914: or the wise and inflexible Cato, who was also a Roman consul ?
tgt_text.916: Were not these long ago departed ?
tgt_text.917: and no one knows where they are now.
tgt_text.918: What of them is now remaining, except the small fame and the name written with a few letters ?
tgt_text.919: And it is yet worse that we know of many mUll trious and memorable men departed, of whom very few per­ sons have ever heard.
tgt_text.920: But many lie dead, entirely forgotten, so that fame does not even make them known!
tgt_text.921: Though ye now think and desire that ye may live long here in the world, what is it to you then the better ?
tgt_text.922: Does not death come, though he come late, and take you away from this world ?
tgt_text.923: And what then does glory profit you ?
tgt_text.924: at least those whom the second death seizes, and for ever binds ?
tgt_text.925: WHEN Wisdom had sung this lay, then began he to speak, and thus said :
tgt_text.926: Do not suppose that I too obstinately attack fortune.
tgt_text.927: I myself have no dread of it, because it frequently happens that deceitful fortune can neither render aid to a man, nor cause any injury.
tgt_text.928: Therefore she is deserving of no praise, because she herself shows that she' is nothing.
tgt_text.929: But she reveals her fountain when she discloses her manners.
tgt_text.930: I think, nevertheless, that thou dost not yet understand what I say to thee:
tgt_text.931: for what I wish to say is wonderful, and I can hardly explain it with words as I would.
tgt_text.932: It is, that I know that adverse fortune is more useful to every man than prosperous.
tgt_text.933: For the prosperous always lies and dissembles, that men may think that she is the true happiness.
tgt_text.934: But the adverse is the true happiness, though to any one it may not seem so, for she is constant and always promises what is true.
tgt_text.935: The other is false, and deceives all her followers;
tgt_text.936: for she herself shows it by her changeableness, that she is very un­ stable :
tgt_text.937: but the adverse improves and instructs every one to whom she joins herself.
tgt_text.938: The other binds every one of the minds which enjoy her, through the appearance which she feigns of being good:
tgt_text.939: but the adverse unbinds, and frees every one of those whom she adheres to, in that she discloses to them how frail these present goods are.
tgt_text.940: But prosperity goes confusedly as the wind's storm;
tgt_text.941: while adversity is always faultless, and is saved from injury by the experience of her own danger.
tgt_text.942: In fine, the false happiness necessarily draws those who are associated with her, from the true felicities, by her flattery:
tgt_text.943: but adversity often necessarily draws all those who are subjected to her, to the true goods, as a fish is caught by a hook.
tgt_text.944: Does it then seem to thee little gain, and little addition to thy felicities, which this severe and this horrible adversity brings to thee:
tgt_text.945: that is, that she very quickly lays open to thee the minds of thy true friends, and.
tgt_text.946: also of thine enemies, that thou'mayest very plainly dis­ tinguish them?
tgt_text.947: But these false goods, when they depart from thee, then take they their men with them, and leave thy few faithful cues with thee.
tgt_text.948: How wouldest thou now buy, or when thou wert happiest, and it seemed to thee that fortune proceeded most according to thy will, with how much money wouldest thou then have bought, that thou mightest clearly distinguish thy friend and thy foe ?
tgt_text.949: I know, how­ ever, that thou wouldest have bought it with much money that thou mightest well know how to distinguish them.
tgt_text.950: Though it now seem to thee that thou hast lost precious wealth, thou hast nevertheless therewith bought much more precious, that is, true friends, whom thou art now able to distinguish, and knowest what of them thou hast.
tgt_text.951: But this is the most valuable wealth of all.
tgt_text.952: WHEN Wisdom had made this speech, then began he to sing, and thus singing, said:
tgt_text.953: There is one creator beyond all doubt, and he is also governor of heaven and earth, and of all creatures, visible and invisible.
tgt_text.955: Him serve all those creatures which serve, both those which have understanding, and those which have not understand­ ing:
tgt_text.956: both those which know it that they serve him, and those which know it not.
tgt_text.957: The same has appointed un- changeable customs and habits, and also natural agreement, to all his creatures, when be would, and so long as he would, which now shall stand for ever.
tgt_text.958: The motion of the moving creatures cannot be stayed, nor yet turned from the course aud from the order that is set to them.
tgt_text.959: But the governor has so with his bridle caught hold of, and restrained, and ad­ monished, all his creatures, that they neither can be still, nor yet move farther than he the space of his rein allows to them.
tgt_text.960: So has the Almighty God controlled all his creatures by his power, that each of them strives with another, and yet sup­ ports another, so that they cannot slip asunder, but are turned again to the same course which they before ran, and thus become again renewed.
tgt_text.961: So are they vane, that con­ trary creatures both strive with each other, and also hold firm agreement with each other.
tgt_text.964: and many other creatures, which will ever be as discordant between themselves, as they are;
tgt_text.965: and yet they are so accordant that not only they may be com­ panions, but moreover, that even no one of them without another can exist.
tgt_text.966: But ever must the contrary the other contrary moderate.
tgt_text.967: So has now the Almighty God very wisely and very fitly appointed change to all his creatures.
tgt_text.969: In spring it groweth, and in harvest it ripens.
tgt_text.971: In summer it is warm, and in winter cold.
tgt_text.972: So also the sun bringeth light days, and the moon gives light in the night, through the power of the same God.
tgt_text.973: The same warns the sea that it may not overstep the threshold of the earth:
tgt_text.974: but he has so fixed their limits, that it may not extend its boundary over the still earth.
tgt_text.975: By the same government is ordered a very like change of the flood and the ebb.
tgt_text.976: This appointment, then, he allows to.
tgt_text.977: stand as long as he wills.
tgt_text.978: But whenever he shall let go the rein of the bridles with which he has now bridled the creatures, that contrariety which we before mentioned, if be shall allow these to be re­ laxed, then will they forsake the agreement which they now keep, arid strive, each of them with other, after its own will, and forsake their companionship, and destroy all this middle- earth, and bring themselves to naught.
tgt_text.979: The same God joins people together with friendship, and uuites families with virtuous love.
tgt_text.980: He brings together friends and companions, that they faithfully hold their agreement and their friendship.
tgt_text.981: O, how happy would this mankind be, if their minds were as right, and as established, and as ordered, as the other creatures are!
tgt_text.982: Here endeth the second consolation-book of Boethius, and beginnetb the third.
tgt_text.983: Boethius was by another name called Severinus:
tgt_text.984: he was a consul of the Romans.§
tgt_text.985: I. WHEN Wisdom had sung this lay, then had he bound me with the sweetness of his song, so that I was greatly ad­ miring it, and very desirous to hear him with inward mind:
tgt_text.986: and immediately thereupon I spoke to him, and thus said:
tgt_text.987: 0, Wisdom, thou who art the highest comfort of all weary minds!
tgt_text.988: how hast thou comforted me, both with thy profound discourse and with the sweetness of thy song!
tgt_text.989: So much hast thou now corrected and overcome me with thy reason­ ing, that it now seems to me that not only am I able to bear this misfortune which has befallen me, but even if still greater peril should come upon me, I will never more say that it is without deserving:
tgt_text.990: for I know that I were deserving of more, and heavier.
tgt_text.991: But I am desirous to hear something more of the medicine of these thine instructions.
tgt_text.992: Though thou just now saidst that thou thoughtest that they would seem very bitter to me, I am not now afraid of them, but I am very anxious after them, both to hear, and also to observe:
tgt_text.993: and very earnestly entreat thee that thou wouldest perform to me, as thou a little while ago promisedst me.
tgt_text.995: I knew immediately when thou didst so well keep silence, and so willingly heardest my doctrine, that thou wouldest with inward mind receive and consider it.
tgt_text.996: There­ fore I waited very well till I knew what.
tgt_text.997: thou wouldest, and how thou wouldest understand it;
tgt_text.998: and, moreover, I very earnestly endeavoured that thou mightest understand it.
tgt_text.999: But I will now tell thee what the medicine of my doctrine is, which thou askest of me.
tgt_text.1000: It is very bitter in the mouth, and it irritates thee in the throat, when thou first triest it:
tgt_text.1001: but it grows sweet after it enters in, and is very mild in the stomach, and pleasant to the taste.§ II.
tgt_text.1002: But when thou shouldest perceive whither I now design to lead thee, I knew that thou wouldest very anxiously tend thither, and be very greatly inflamed with that desire.
tgt_text.1003: For I heard what thou before saidst, that thou wast very de­ sirous to bear it.
tgt_text.1005: Whither wilt thou now especially lead me ?
tgt_text.1007: I propose that I should lead thee to the true goods, about which thy mind often meditates, and is greatly moved:
tgt_text.1008: and thou hast not yet been able to find the most direct way to the true goods, because thy mind was occupied with the view of these false goods.
tgt_text.1010: I beseech thee that thou wouldest show me, beyond all doubt, what the true happiness is.
tgt_text.1012: I will gladly, for love of thee.
tgt_text.1013: But I must, by some example, teach thee some re­ semblance of the thing, till the thing be better known to thee;
tgt_text.1014: in order that thou mayest clearly view the example, and then, by the resemblance of the true goods, thou mayest know the true goods, and forsake what is contrary to them, that is, the false goods:
tgt_text.1015: and then with the anxious thought of all thy mind, strive that thou mayest arrive at those goods, which for ever remain!
tgt_text.1016: WHEN Wisdom had ended this discourse, then began he again to sing, and thus said:
tgt_text.1017: Whosoever is desirous to sow fertile land, let him first draw out the thorns, and the furze, and the fern, and all the weeds which he observes to do injury to the field, in order that the wheat may grow the better.
tgt_text.1018: Also, this example is to be considered, that is, that to every man honeycomb seems the sweeter, if he, a little before, taste anything bitter.
tgt_text.1019: And, again, calm weather is the more agree­ able, if it a little before be stark storms, and north winds, and much rain and snow.
tgt_text.1020: And more agreeable also is the light of the day, for the horrible darkness of the night, than it would be if there were no night.
tgt_text.1021: So is also the true happiness much the more pleasant to enjoy, after the calamities of this present life.
tgt_text.1022: And, moreover, thou mayest much the sooner discover the true goods, and arrive at the knowledge of them, if thou first rootest out from thy mind the false goods, and removest them from the ground.
tgt_text.1023: After thou, then, art able to discover those, I know that thou wilt not desire any other thing be­ sides them.§
tgt_text.1024: I. WHEN he had sung this lay, he ceased the song, and was silent awhile, and began to think deeply in his mind'a thought, and thus said:
tgt_text.1025: Every mortal man troubles himself with various and manifold anxieties, and yet all desire, through various paths, to come to one end:
tgt_text.1026: that is, they desire, by dif­ ferent means, to arrive at one happiness;
tgt_text.1028: He is the beginning and the end of every good, and he is the highest happiness.
tgt_text.1030: This, methinks, must be the highest good, so that man should need no other good, nor moreover be solicitous beyond that:
tgt_text.1031: since he possesses that which is the roof of all other goods;
tgt_text.1032: for it includes all other goods, and has all of them within it.
tgt_text.1033: It would not be the highest good, if any good were external to it, because it would then have to desire some good which itself had not.
tgt_text.1035: It is very evident that this is the highest happiness, for it is both the roof and the floor of all good.
tgt_text.1036: What is that, then, but the best happiness, which gathers the other felicities all within it, and includes, and holds them within it:
tgt_text.1037: and to- it there is a deficiency of none, neither has it need of any;
tgt_text.1038: but they all come from it, and again all return to it:
tgt_text.1039: as all waters come from the sea, and again all come to the sea ?
tgt_text.1040: There is none in the little fountain which does not seek the sea, and again, from the sea it arrives at the earth, and so it flows gradually through the earth, till it again comes to the same fountain that it before flowed from, and so again to the sea.§
tgt_text.1042: Now this is an example of the true goods, which all mortal men desire to obtain, though they by various ways think to arrive at them.
tgt_text.1043: For every man has natural good in himself because every mind desires to obtain the true good:
tgt_text.1044: but it is hindered by the transitory goods, because it is more prone thereto.
tgt_text.1045: For some men think that it is the best happi­ ness that a man be so rich that he have need of nothing more:
tgt_text.1046: and they choose their life accordingly.
tgt_text.1047: Some men think that this is the highest good, that he be among his fellows the most honourable of his fellows, and they with all energy seek this.
tgt_text.1048: Some think that the supreme good is in the highest power.
tgt_text.1049: These desire, either for themselves to rule, or else to associate themselves in friendship with their rulers.
tgt_text.1050: Some persuade themselves that it is best that a man be illustrious and cele­ brated, and have good fame;
tgt_text.1051: they therefore seek this both in peace and in war.
tgt_text.1052: Many reckon it for the greatest good and for the greatest happiness, that a man be always blithe in this present life, and fulfil all his lusts.
tgt_text.1053: Some, indeed, who desire these riches, are desirous thereof, because they would have the greater power, that they may the more securely enjoy these worldly lusts, and also the riches.
tgt_text.1054: Many there are of those who desire power because they would gather overmuch money:
tgt_text.1055: or again, they are desirous to spread the celebrity of their name.§ III.
tgt_text.1056: On account of such and other like frail and perish­ able advantages, the thought of every human mind is troubled with solicitude and with anxiety.
tgt_text.1057: It then imagines that it has obtained some exalted good when it has won the flattery of the people;
tgt_text.1058: and methinks that it has bought a very false greatness.
tgt_text.1059: Some with much anxiety seek wives, that thereby they may, above all things, have children, and also live hap­ pily.
tgt_text.1060: True friends, then, I say, is the most precious thing of all these worldly felicities.
tgt_text.1061: They are not, indeed, to be reckoned as worldly goods, but as divine:
tgt_text.1062: for deceitful for­ tune does not produce them, but God, who naturally formed them as relations.
tgt_text.1063: For of every other thing in this world man is desirous, either that he may through it attain to power, or else some worldly lust:
tgt_text.1064: except of the true friend, whom he loves sometimes for affection and for fidelity, though be expect to himself no other rewards.
tgt_text.1065: Nature joins and cements friends together with inseparable love.
tgt_text.1066: But with these worldly goods, and with this present wealth, men make oftener enemies than friends.
tgt_text.1067: By these and by many such things it may be evident to all men, that all the bodily goods are inferior to the faculties of the soul.
tgt_text.1068: We indeed think that a man is the stronger, because he is great in his body.
tgt_text.1069: The fairness, moreover, and the vigour of the body, rejoices and delights the man, and health makes him cheerful.
tgt_text.1070: In all these bodily felicities, men seek simple happiness, as it seems to them.
tgt_text.1071: For whatsoever every man chiefly loves above all other things, that he persuades himself is best for him, and that is his highest good.
tgt_text.1072: When, therefore, he has acquired that, he imagines that he may be very happy.
tgt_text.1073: I do not deny, that these goods and this happiness are the highest good of this present life.
tgt_text.1074: For every man considers that thing best, which he chiefly loves above other things;
tgt_text.1075: and therefore he persuades himself that he is very happy if he can obtain what he then most desires.
tgt_text.1076: Is not now clearly enough shown to thee the form of the false goods, that is, then, possessions, dignity, and power, and glory, and pleasure ?
tgt_text.1077: Concerning pleasure, Epicurus the philosopher said, when he inquired concerning all those other goods, which we before mentioned;
tgt_text.1078: then said he that pleasure was the highest good, because all the other goods which we before mentioned gratify the mind and delight it, but pleasure alone chiefly gratifies the body only.
tgt_text.1080: But we will still speak concerning the nature of men, and concerning their pursuits.
tgt_text.1081: Though, then, their mind and their nature be now dimmed, and they are by that fall sunk down to evil, and thither inclined, yet they are desirous, so far as they can and may, of the highest good.
tgt_text.1082: As a drunken man knows that he should go to his house and to his rest, and yet is not able to find the way thither, so is it also with the mind, when it is weighed down by the anxieties of this world.
tgt_text.1083: It is sometimes intoxicated and misled by them, so far that it cannot rightly find out good.
tgt_text.1084: Nor yet does it appear to those men that they at all err, who are desirous to obtain this, that they need labour after nothing more.
tgt_text.1085: But they think that they are able to collect together all these goods, so that none may be excluded from the number.
tgt_text.1086: They therefore know no other good than the col-
tgt_text.1087: Meeting of all the most precious things into their power, that they may have need of nothing besides them.
tgt_text.1088: But there is no one that has not need of some addition, except God alone.
tgt_text.1089: He has of his own enough, nor has he need of anything but that which he has in himself.
tgt_text.1090: Dost thou think, however, that they foolishly imagine that that thing is best deserving of all estimation, which they may consider most desirable ?
tgt_text.1092: I know that it is not to be despised.
tgt_text.1093: How can that be evil, which the mind of every man considers to be good, and strives after, and desires to obtain ?
tgt_text.1096: Why is not power to be reckoned one of the highest goods of this present life ?
tgt_text.1097: Is that to be esteemed vain and useless, which is the most useful of all these worldly things, that is, power?
tgt_text.1098: Is good fame and renown to be accounted nothing?
tgt_text.1100: It is not fit that any one account it nothing;
tgt_text.1101: for every man thinks that best which he most loves.
tgt_text.1102: Do we not know that no anxiety, or difficulties, or trouble, or pain, or sorrow, is happiness ?
tgt_text.1103: What more, then, need we say about these felicities ?
tgt_text.1104: Does not every man know what they are, and also know that they are the highest good ?
tgt_text.1105: And yet almost every man seeks in very little things the best felicities ;
tgt_text.1106: because he thinks that he may have them all, if he have that which he then chiefly wishes to obtain.
tgt_text.1108: is, then, what they chiefly wish to obtain, wealth, and dignity, and authority, and this world's glory, and ostentation, and worldly lust.
tgt_text.1109: Of all this they are desirous, because they think that, through these things, they may obtain that there be not to them a deficiency of anything wished;
tgt_text.1110: neither of dignity, nor of power, nor of renown, nor of bliss.
tgt_text.1111: They wish for all this, and they do well that they desire it, though they seek it variously.
tgt_text.1112: By these things we may clearly perceive that every man is desirous of this, that he may obtain the highest good, if they were able to discover it, or knew how to seek it rightly.
tgt_text.1113: But they do not seek it in the most right way.
tgt_text.1114: It is not of this world.
tgt_text.1115: WHEN Wisd om had made this speech, then began be again to sing, and thus said:
tgt_text.1116: I will now with songs declare how wonderfully the Lord governs all creatures with the bridles of his power, and with what order he establishes and regulates all creatures, and how be has restrained and bound them with his indissoluble chains, so that every creature is kept within bounds with its kind, the kind that it was fashioned to, except men and some angels, sometimes depart from their kind.
tgt_text.1117: THus the lion, though she be very tame, and have fast chains, and greatly love, and also fear her master;
tgt_text.1118: if it ever happen that she tastes blood, she immediately forgets her new tamer, and remembers the wild manner of her parents.
tgt_text.1119: She'then begins roaring, and to break her chains, and bites first her leader, and afterwards whatsoever she may seize, both of men and of cattle.
tgt_text.1121: Though they be well tamed, if they return to the woods, they despise their teachers, and remain with their kind.
tgt_text.1122: Though their teachers then offer them the same meals with which they before allured them to become tame:
tgt_text.1123: they then care not for those meals, so that they may enjoy the wood.
tgt_text.1124: But it seems to them pleasanter, that the weald resound to them, and they hear the voice of other fowls.
tgt_text.1125: So is it also with trees, whose nature it is to stand up high.
tgt_text.1126: Though thou pull any bough down to the earth, such as thou mayest bend;
tgt_text.1127: as soon as thou lettest it go, so soon springs it up, and moves towards its kind.
tgt_text.1130: she after mid-day sink and incline to the earth, again she seeks her kind, and departs by unknown ways to her rising, and so.. hastens higher and higher, until she comes so far up aa' her highest nature is.
tgt_text.1133: and is joyful if it ever may come thereto.
tgt_text.1134: There is no creature formed which de­ sires not that it may come thither whence it before came, that is, to rest and to tranquillity.
tgt_text.1135: The rest is with God, and it is God.
tgt_text.1136: But every creature turns on itself like a wheel:
tgt_text.1137: and so it thus turns that it may again come where it was before, and be the same that it was before, as often as it is turned round may be what it before was, and may do what it before did.§
tgt_text.1138: I. When Wisdom had sung this lay, then began he again to speak, and thus said:
tgt_text.1139: 0 ye earthly men, though ye now make yourselves like cattle by your folly, ye nevertheless can in some measure understand, as in a dream, concerning your origin, that is God.
tgt_text.1140: Ye perceive the true beginning, and the true end of all happiness, though ye do not fully know it.
tgt_text.1141: And nevertheless nature draws you to that knowledge, but very manifold error draws you from that knowledge.
tgt_text.1142: Consider now whether men can arrive at the true goods through these present goods;
tgt_text.1143: since almost all men say that he is happiest who possesses all these earthly goods.
tgt_text.1144: Can, then, much money, or dignity, or all this present wealth, make any man so happy that he may need nothing more ?
tgt_text.1146: I know this, that they cannot.
tgt_text.1147: Why, is it not then from this very clear, that these present goods are not the true goods, because they cannot give what they promise ?
tgt_text.1148: But they pretend to do what they are not able to fulfil, when they promise to those who are willing to love them, the true felicities, and tell lies to them more than they perform to them;
tgt_text.1149: for they are de­ ficient in more of these felicities than they possess of them.
tgt_text.1150: Consider now concerning thyself, 0 Boethius, whether thou wert ever aught uneasy, when thou wert most prosperous ?
tgt_text.1151: or whether there were ever to thee a want of anything de­ sired, when thou hadst most wealth?
tgt_text.1152: or whether thy life were then all according to thy wish ?
tgt_text.1153: Then answered Boe­ tbius, and said:
tgt_text.1155: I was never yet at any time of so even mind, as far as I can remember, that I was altogether without care:
tgt_text.1156: that I was so without care that I bad no trouble:
tgt_text.1157: nor did all that I experienced ever yet please me, nor was it ever with me entirely as I wished, though I con­ cealed it.
tgt_text.1159: Wast thou not, then, poor enough, and unhappy enough, though it seemed to thee that thou wert rich;
tgt_text.1160: when thou either hadst that which thou wouldest not, or hadst not that which thou wouldest?
tgt_text.1162: All was to me as thou hast said.
tgt_text.1164: Is not every man poor enough in respect of that which he has not, when he is desirous to have it ?
tgt_text.1167: But if he is poor, he is not happy, for he desires that he may have what he has not, because he wishes to have enough.
tgt_text.1169: That is all true which thou sayest.
tgt_text.1171: Hadst thou not, then, poverty when thou wert richest?
tgt_text.1173: I know that thou sayest truth, that I had it.
tgt_text.1175: Does it not appear to me, then, that all the riches of this middle-earth are not able to make one man wealthy ?
tgt_text.1176: so wealthy that he may have enough, and may not need more?
tgt_text.1177: And nevertheless they promise it to every one who possesses them.
tgt_text.1179: Nothing is truer than what thou sayest.§ II.
tgt_text.1181: But why, then, art thou not an assenter to this ?
tgt_text.1182: Canst thou not see every day, that the stronger take riches from the weaker?
tgt_text.1184: every day such sorrow, and such contentions, and assemblies, and judgments;
tgt_text.1185: except that every one demands the spoil which is taken from him, or, again, covets that of another?
tgt_text.1188: so it is as thou sayest.
tgt_text.1190: On these accounts every man has need of help in addition to himself, that he may keep his riches.
tgt_text.1194: If he had nothing of that which he fears he may be obliged to lose, then he would not have occasion for any more help than himself.
tgt_text.1197: Then retorted Wisdom sharply, and said:
tgt_text.1198: 0, how inconsistent, in every man's custom and every man's will, does that thing appear to me, which I will now mention ;
tgt_text.1199: that is, that from whence they persuade themselves that they shall become happier, they from thence become poorer and weaker!
tgt_text.1200: For, if they have any little, then it behoves them to cringe for protection to those who have anything more.
tgt_text.1201: Whether they need, or whether they need not, they yet crave.
tgt_text.1202: Where, then, is moderation, or who has it, or when will it come, that it may entirely drive away miseries from the wealthy ?
tgt_text.1203: The more he has, the more men he must cringe to.
tgt_text.1204: Do the rich never hunger, nor thirst, nor become cold ?
tgt_text.1205: But I suppose thou wilt say that the rich have wherewith they may remedy all that.
tgt_text.1206: But though thou say so, riches cannot altogether remedy it, though they somewhile may.
tgt_text.1207: For it behoves them every day to add, what man every day lessens;
tgt_text.1208: because human want, which is never satisfied, requires each day something of this world's wealth, either of clothing, of meat, of drink, or of many things besides.
tgt_text.1209: Therefore no man is so wealthy that he needs not more.
tgt_text.1210: But covetousness neither knows limit, nor ever is bounded by necessity;
tgt_text.1211: but desires always more than it needs.
tgt_text.1212: I know not why ye confide in these perish­ able riches, when they are not able to remove your poverty from you, but ye increase your poverty whenever they come to you.§ III.
tgt_text.1213: When Wisdom had made this speech, then begau he again to sing, and thus singing said:
tgt_text.1214: What profit is it to the rich miser, that he gather an infinite quantity of these riches, and obtain abundance of every kind of jewel:
tgt_text.1215: and though he till his land with a thousand ploughs;
tgt_text.1216: and though all this middle-earth be subject to his power!
tgt_text.1217: He will not take with him from this middle-earth any more of it than he brought hither.§
tgt_text.1218: I. Two things may dignity and power do, if it come to the unwise.
tgt_text.1219: It may make him honourable and respectable to other unwise persons.
tgt_text.1220: But when he quits the power, or the power him, then is he to the unwise neither honourable nor respectable.
tgt_text.1221: Has, then, power the custom of extermi­ nating vices, and rooting them out from the mind of great men, and planting therein virtues ?
tgt_text.1222: I know, however, that earthly power never sows the virtues, but collects and gathers vices;
tgt_text.1223: and when it has gathered them, then it nevertheless shows, and does not conceal them.
tgt_text.1224: For the vices of great men many men see:
tgt_text.1225: because many know them, and many are with them.
tgt_text.1226: Therefore we always lament concerning power, and also despise it, when we see that it cometh to the worst, and to those who are to us most unworthy.
tgt_text.1227: It was on these accounts that formerly the wise Catulus was angry, and so immoderately censured Nonius the rich, be- cause he observed him to sit in an ornamented chair of state.
tgt_text.1228: It was a great custom among the Romans that no others should sit therein, except the most worthy.
tgt_text.1229: Then Catulus despised him, because he should sit therein;
tgt_text.1230: for he knew him to be very unwise, and very intemperate.
tgt_text.1231: Then began Ca­ tulus to spit upon him.
tgt_text.1232: Catulus was a consul in Rome, a very wise man.
tgt_text.1233: He would not have despised the other so greatly, if he had not possessed any rule, or any power.§ II.
tgt_text.1234: Canst thou now understand how great dishonour power brings on the unworthy when he receives it ?
tgt_text.1235: for every man's evil is the more public when he has power.
tgt_text.1236: But tell me now, I ask thee, Boethius, why thou hadst such manifold evil, and such great uneasiness in authority, whilst thou hadst it ?
tgt_text.1237: or why thou, again, didst unwillingly relinquish it ?
tgt_text.1238: Dost thou not know that it was for no other reasons but that thou wouldest not in all things be conformable to the will of the unrighteous king Theodoric;
tgt_text.1239: because thou didst find him in all respects unworthy of power, very shame­ less, and unrelenting, without any good conduct ?
tgt_text.1240: For we cannot easily say that the wicked are good, though they have power.
tgt_text.1241: Yet thou wouldest not have been driven from Theo­ doric, nor would he have despised thee, if his folly and his injustice had pleased thee, as well as it did his foolish favour­ ites.
tgt_text.1242: If thou now shouldest see some very wise man, who had very excellent dispositions, and was, nevertheless, very poor, and very unhappy, wouldest thou say that he were un­ worthy of power and dignity?
tgt_text.1245: If I found him such, I would never say that he were unworthy of power and dignity.
tgt_text.1246: But methinks that he would be worthy of all that is in this world.
tgt_text.1248: Every virtue has its proper ex­ cellence :
tgt_text.1249: and the excellence and the dignity which it has, it imparts immediately to every one who loves it.
tgt_text.1250: Thus wisdom is the highest virtue, and it has in it four other virtues;
tgt_text.1251: of which one is prudence, another temperance, the third is for­ titude, the fourth justice.
tgt_text.1252: Wisdom makes its lovers wise, and prudent, and moderate, aud patient, and just, and it fills him who loves it with every good quality.
tgt_text.1253: This they cannot do who possess the power of this world.
tgt_text.1254: They cannot impart any virtue to those who love them, through their wealth, if they have it not in their nature.
tgt_text.1255: Hence it is very clear that the rich in worldly wealth have no proper dignity:
tgt_text.1256: but the wealth is come to them from without, and they cannot from without have aught of their own.
tgt_text.1257: Consider, now, whether any man is the less honourable because many men despise him.
tgt_text.1258: But if any man be the less honourable, then is every foolish man the less honourable, the more authority he has, to every wise man.
tgt_text.1259: Hence it is sufficiently clear that power and wealth cannot make its possessor the more honourable.
tgt_text.1260: But it makes him the less honourable when it comes to him, if he were not before virtuous.
tgt_text.1261: So is also wealth and power the worse, if he be not virtuous who possesses it.
tgt_text.1262: Each of them is the more worthless, when they meet with each other.§ III.
tgt_text.1263: But I may easily instruct thee by an example, so that thou mayest clearly enough perceive that this present life is very like a shadow, and in that shadow no man can attain the true felicities.
tgt_text.1265: If any very great man were driven from his country, or goeth on his lord's errand, and so cometh to a foreign people where no man knows him, nor he any man, nor even knows the language, thinkest thou that his greatness can make him honourable in that land ?
tgt_text.1266: But I know that it cannot.
tgt_text.1267: But if dignity were natural to wealth, and were its own, or again, wealth were the rich man's own, then could not it forsake him.
tgt_text.1268: Let the man who possessed them be in whatsoever land he might, then would his wealth and his dignity be with him.
tgt_text.1269: But because the wealth and the power are not his own, therefore they forsake him;
tgt_text.1270: and because they have no natural good in themselves, therefore they go away like shadows or smoke.
tgt_text.1271: Yet the false opinion, and the imagination.
tgt_text.1272: of foolish men, persuades them that power is the highest good.
tgt_text.1274: When the great are either among, foreigners, or in their own country among wise men;
tgt_text.1275: then either to the wise, or to the foreigners, is his wealth for naught, when they learn that they were chosen for no virtue, but through the favour of foolish people.
tgt_text.1276: But if they in their power had anything of proper or natural good, then would they have that with them, even if they should lose the power.
tgt_text.1277: They would not lose the natural good, but that would always follow them, and always make them honourable, let them be in whatsoever land they might.
tgt_text.1279: Now thou mayest understand that wealth and power cannot make any man honourable in a foreign country.
tgt_text.1280: I wot, however, thou mayest think that they always can in their own country.
tgt_text.1281: But though thou mayest think it, I kuow that they cannot.
tgt_text.1282: It was formerly, through all the territories of the Romans, that consuls, and judges, and the treasurers, who kept the money, which they were every year to give to the soldiers, and the wisest senators, had the greatest honour.
tgt_text.1283: But now, either none of these exists, or they have no honour, if any one of them exists.
tgt_text.1284: So it is with respect to every one of those things which have not in them­ selves proper and natural good.
tgt_text.1285: One while it is to be cen­ sured, another while it is to be praised.
tgt_text.1286: But what of de­ lightful or of useful appears to thee, then, in wealth and in power;
tgt_text.1287: when they have enough of nothing, nor have anything of proper good, nor can give anything durable to their pos­ sessors PWHEN Wisdom had made this speech, then began he again to sing, and thus said:
tgt_text.1288: Though the wicked king Nero decked himself with all the most splendid clothes, and adorned him­ self with gems of every kind, was he not, nevertheless, to all wise men, loathsome and unworthy, and full of all vice and debauchery?
tgt_text.1289: Yet he enriched his favourites with great riches:
tgt_text.1290: but what was to them the better ?
tgt_text.1291: What wise man could say that he was the more honourable, when he had en­ riched him ?§
tgt_text.1292: I. WHEN Wisdom had sung this lay, then began be again to speak, and thus said:
tgt_text.1293: Dost thou think that the king's familiarity, and the wealth and the power which he gives to his favourites, can make any man wealthy or powerful ?
tgt_text.1296: What in this present life is pleasanter and better than the king's ser­ vice and his presence, and moreover wealth and power?
tgt_text.1298: Tell me, now, whether thou hast ever heard, that it always remained to any one who was before us ?
tgt_text.1299: or thinkest thou that any one who now has it, can always have it ?
tgt_text.1300: Dost thou not know that all books are full of examples of the men who were before us, and every one knows concerning those who are now living, that from many a king power and wealth go away, until he afterwards becomes poor?
tgt_text.1302: is that, then, very excellent wealth, which can preserve neither itself nor its lord, so that he may not have need of more help, lest they should both be lost ?
tgt_text.1303: But is not this your highest felicity-the power of kings ?
tgt_text.1304: And yet if to the king there be a want of anything desired, then that lessens his power, and augments his misery.
tgt_text.1305: There­ fore these your felicities are always in some respects infeli­ cities !
tgt_text.1306: Moreover kings, though they govern many nations, yet they do not govern all those which they would govern;
tgt_text.1307: but are very wretched in their mind, because they have not some of those things which they would have:
tgt_text.1308: for I know that the king who is rapacious has more wretchedness than power.
tgt_text.1309: Therefore a certain king, who unjustly came to empire, for­ merly said:
tgt_text.1310: 0, how happy is the man to whom a naked sword hangs not always over the head by a small thread, as to me it ever yet has done!
tgt_text.1311: How does it now appear to thee ?
tgt_text.1312: How do wealth and power please thee, when they are never with­ out fear, and difficulties, and anxieties ?
tgt_text.1313: Thou knowest that every king would be without these, and yet have power if he might.
tgt_text.1314: But I know that he cannot:
tgt_text.1315: therefore I wonder why they glory in such power.
tgt_text.1316: Does it seem to thee that the man has great power, and is truly happy, who always desires that which he cannot obtain ?
tgt_text.1317: Or thinkest thou that lie is really happy who always goes with a great company ?
tgt_text.1318: Or again, he who dreads both him that is in dread of him, and him that is not in dread of him ?
tgt_text.1319: Does it seem to thee that the man has great power who seems to himself to have none, even as to many a man it seems that he has none, unless he have many a man to serve him ?
tgt_text.1320: What shall we now say more concerning the king, and concerning his followers, except that every rational man may know that they are full miser­ able and weak ?
tgt_text.1321: How can kings deny or conceal their weak­ ness, when they are not able to attain any honour without their thanes' assistance?§ II.
tgt_text.1322: What else shall we say concerning thanes, but this, that it often happens that they are hereaved of all honour, and even of life, by their perfidious king?
tgt_text.1323: Thus we know that the wicked king Nero would hate his own master, and kill his foster-father, whose name was Seneca.
tgt_text.1325: When, therefore, he found that he must die, he offered all his possessions for his life, but the king would not accept of it, or grant him his life.
tgt_text.1326: When he learned this, he chose for himself the death, that they should let for him blood from the arm;
tgt_text.1328: We have also heard that Papinianus was to Antoninus the Cæsar, of all his favourites the most beloved, and of all his people had the greatest power.
tgt_text.1329: But he gave order to bind, and afterwards to slay him.
tgt_text.1330: Yet all men know that Seneca was to Nero, and Pa­ pinianus to Antoninus, the most worthy and the most dear;
tgt_text.1331: and they had the greatest power, both in their court and elsewhere, and nevertheless, without any guilt, they were destroyed!
tgt_text.1332: Yet they both desired, most earnestly, that the lords would take whatsoever they had, and let them live, but they could not obtain it:
tgt_text.1333: for the cruelty of those kings was so severe, that their submission could naught avail, nor in­ deed would their high-mindedness, howsoever they might do, have availed them either, but they were obliged to lose life.
tgt_text.1334: For he who does not take timely care for himself, will at length be destitute.
tgt_text.1335: How doth power and wealth now please thee, now thou hast heard that a man neither can have it without fear, nor can part with it though he wish ?
tgt_text.1336: What did the crowd of friends avail the favourites of those kings, or what avails it to any man ?
tgt_text.1337: For friends come with wealth, and again with wealth go away, except very few.
tgt_text.1338: But the friends who before, for wealth's sake, love any one, go away afterwards with the wealth, and then turn to enemies.
tgt_text.1339: But the few, who before loved him for affection and for fidelity, these would, nevertheless, love him though he were poor.
tgt_text.1341: What is a worse plague, or greater hurt to any man, than that be have, in his society and in his presence, an enemy in the likeness of a friend ?§ III.
tgt_text.1342: When Wisdom had made this speech, then began he again to sing, and thus said:
tgt_text.1343: Whosoever desires fully to pos­ sess power, ought to labour first that he may have power over his own mind, and be not indecently subject to his vices ;
tgt_text.1344: also let him put away from his mind unbecoming anxieties, and desist from complaints of his misfortunes.
tgt_text.1345: Though he reign over all the middle-earth, from eastward to westward, from India, which is the south-east end of this middle-earth, to the island which we call Thule, which is at the north-west end of this middle-earth, where there is neither night in summer nor day in winter;
tgt_text.1346: though he rule even all this, he has not the more power, if he has not power over his mind, and if he does not guard himself against the vices which we have before spoken about.§
tgt_text.1347: I. WHEN Wisdom had sung this song, then began he again to make a speech, and said:
tgt_text.1348: Worthless and very false is the glory of this world!
tgt_text.1349: Concerning this a certain poet formerly sung.
tgt_text.1350: When he contemned this present life, he said:
tgt_text.1353: why do foolish men call thee with false voice, glory, when thou art none!
tgt_text.1354: For man more frequently has great renown, and great glory, and great honour, through the opinion of foolish people, than he has through his deservings.
tgt_text.1355: But tell me now, what is more un­ suitable than this:
tgt_text.1356: or why men may not rather be ashamed of themselves than rejoice, when they hear that any one belies them ?
tgt_text.1357: Though men even rightly praise any one of the good, he ought not the sooner to rejoice immoderately at the people's words.
tgt_text.1358: But at this he ought to rejoice, that they speak truth of him.
tgt_text.1359: Though he rejoice at this, that they spread his name, it is not the sooner so extensively spread as he persuades him­ self;
tgt_text.1360: for they cannot spread it over all the earth, though they may in some land;
tgt_text.1361: for though it be praised in one, yet in another it is not praised.
tgt_text.1362: Though he in this land be cele­ brated, yet is he in another not celebrated..
tgt_text.1363: Therefore is the people's esteem to be held by every man for nothing;
tgt_text.1364: since it comes not to every man according to his deserts, nor in­ deed remains always to any one.
tgt_text.1366: if any one boast of it, how vain and how useless is the boast;
tgt_text.1367: for every one knows that all men come from one father and from one mother.
tgt_text.1368: Or again, concerning the people's esteem, and concerning their applause.
tgt_text.1369: I know not why we rejoice at it.
tgt_text.1370: Though they be illustrious whom the vulgar applaud, yet are they more illustrious and more rightly to be applauded who are dignified by virtues.
tgt_text.1371: For no man is really the greater or the more praiseworthy for the excel­ lence of another, or for his virtues, if he himself has it not.
tgt_text.1372: Art thou ever the fairer for another man's fairness ?
tgt_text.1373: A man is full little the better though he have a good father, if he himself is incapable of anything.
tgt_text.1374: Therefore I advise that thou rejoice in other men's good and their nobility, so far only, that thou ascribe it not to thyself as thine own.
tgt_text.1375: Be. cause every man's good, and his nobility, is more in the mind than in the flesh.
tgt_text.1376: This only, indeed, I know of good in nobility;
tgt_text.1377: that it shames many a man, if he be worse than his ancestors were;
tgt_text.1378: and therefore he strives with all his power to reach the manners of some one of the best, and his virtues.§ II.
tgt_text.1379: When Wisdom had finished this speech, then began he again to sing about the same, and said:
tgt_text.1380: Truly all men had a like beginning, for they all came from one father and from one mother:
tgt_text.1381: they are all, moreover, born alike.
tgt_text.1382: That is no wonder, because one God is father of all creatures;
tgt_text.1383: for he made them all, and governs them all.
tgt_text.1384: He gives light to the sun, and to the moon, and places all the stars.
tgt_text.1385: He has created men on the earth, joined together the soul and the body by his power, and made all men equally noble in their original nature.
tgt_text.1386: Why do ye then lift up yourselves above other men, on account of your birth, without cause, since ye can find none unnohle, but all are equally noble, if ye are willing to remember the creation, and the Creator, and more­ over the birth of every one of you ?
tgt_text.1387: But true nobility is in the mind, not in the flesh, as we have before said.
tgt_text.1388: But every man, who is altogether subject to vices, forsakes his Maker, and his first origin, and his nobility, and thence becomes de­ graded till he is unnoble.§
tgt_text.1389: I. WHEN Wisdom had sung this lay, then began he again to make a speech, and thus said:
tgt_text.1390: What good can we say of the fleshly vices?
tgt_text.1391: For whosoever will yield to them shall suffer great anguish and many troubles.
tgt_text.1392: For intemperance always nourishes vices, and vices have great need of repent­ ance, and repentance is not without sorrow and without anguish.
tgt_text.1394: how many diseases, and how great pain, and how great watching, and how great sadness, has he who pos­ sesses wicked lust in this world!
tgt_text.1395: And how much more thinnest thou they shall have after this world, as the re­ tribution of their deserts ?
tgt_text.1396: even as a woman brings forth a child, and suffers much trouble, after she formerly has ful­ filled great lust.
tgt_text.1397: Therefore I know not what joy the worldly lusts bring to their lovers.
tgt_text.1398: If any one say that he is happy who fulfils all his worldly lusts, wherefore will he not also say that the cattle are happy, for their desire is extended to no other things, but to gluttony and to lust.
tgt_text.1399: Very pleasant is it that a man have wife and children.
tgt_text.1400: But nevertheless many children are begotten for their parents' destruction.
tgt_text.1401: For many a woman dies by reason of her child, before she can bring it forth.
tgt_text.1402: And we have also learned that formerly a most unusual and unnatural crime happened, that the children conspired together, and lay in wait for the father.
tgt_text.1403: And moreover, what was worse, we have heard, long ago in ancient histories, that a certain son slew his father.
tgt_text.1404: I know not in what manner, but we know that it was an inhuman deed.
tgt_text.1405: Besides, every one may know, how heavy trouble to a man is the care of his children.
tgt_text.1406: I need not, however, say that to thee, for thou hast experienced it of thyself.
tgt_text.1407: Con­ cerning the heavy care of children, said my master Euripides, that it sometimes happened to the unhappy, that it would be better for him that he had not children, than that he had.§
tgt_text.1409: When Wisdom had ended this speech, then began he again to sing, and thus singing, said:
tgt_text.1411: the evil desire of unlawful lust disquiets the mind of almost every living man.
tgt_text.1412: As the bee shall perish when she stings anything angrily, so shall every soul perish after unlawful lust, unless the man turn to good.§
tgt_text.1413: I. WHEN Wisdom had sung this lay, then began he again to speak, and thus said :
tgt_text.1414: Therefore there is no doubt that this present wealth obstructs and hinders those men who are in­ tent upon the true felicities;
tgt_text.1415: and it can bring no one where it promised him, that is, to the highest good.
tgt_text.1416: But I can in a few words declare to thee with how many evils these riches are filled.
tgt_text.1417: What meanest thou, then, by covetousness of ., money;
tgt_text.1418: when thou no how else canst acquire it, unless thou steal it, or take it by force, or find it hid:
tgt_text.1419: and wheresoever it increases to thee, it decreases to others ?
tgt_text.1420: Thou wouldest,, then, be illustrious in dignity ?
tgt_text.1421: But if thou wilt have this, then must thou very meanly, and very humbly, flatter him who is able to help thee thereto.
tgt_text.1422: If thou wilt make thyself greater and more honourable than many, then must thou suffer thyself to be inferior to one.
tgt_text.1423: Is not this, then, some­ what of misery, that a man must so anxiously cringe to him who has the power of giving to him ?
tgt_text.1425: But thou never obtainest it without danger, on account of foreigners, and still more on account of thine own men and kindred.
tgt_text.1427: But thou canst not have it without care:
tgt_text.1428: for thou shalt have always something adverse and inconvenient.
tgt_text.1429: Thou wouldest, then, enjoy immoderate lust?
tgt_text.1430: But then thou art desirous to despise God's servants, inasmuch as thy vile flesh has the mastery of thee, not thou of it.
tgt_text.1431: How can any man conduct himself more wretchedly than when he subjects himself to his vile flesh, and will not to his rational soul?
tgt_text.1432: If, then, ye were greater in your body than the elephant, or stronger than the lion or the bull, or swifter than the tiger, that wild beast;
tgt_text.1433: and if thou wert of all men the fairest in beauty, and then wouldest studiously seek after wisdom, until thou couldest perfectly understand it;
tgt_text.1434: then mightest thou clearly perceive that all the powers and the faculties which we have before spoken about, are not to be compared with any one of the faculties of the soul.
tgt_text.1435: Indeed, wisdom is one single faculty of the soul, and yet we all know that it is better than all the other faculties, which we have before spoken about.§
tgt_text.1437: Behold now the amplitude, and the firmness, and the swift course of this heaven.
tgt_text.1438: Then may ye understand that it is absolutely nothing, compared with its creator, and with its ruler.
tgt_text.1439: Why then suffer ye it not to warn you, that ye should not admire and praise that which is less perfect, that is, earthly wealth ?
tgt_text.1440: Even as the heaven is better, and higher, and fairer than all which it includes, except men alone;
tgt_text.1441: so is man's body better and more precious than all his possessions.
tgt_text.1442: But how much thinkest thou, then, the soul better, and more precious than the body ?
tgt_text.1443: Every creature is to be honoured in its measure, and always the highest in the greatest degree.
tgt_text.1444: Therefore is the heavenly power to be honoured, and to be admired, and to be adored above all other things.
tgt_text.1445: The beauty of the body is very fleeting, and very frail, and very like the flowers of the earth.
tgt_text.1446: Though any one be as fair as Alcibiades, the noble youth, was:
tgt_text.1447: if any one be so sharp-sighted, that he can see through him, as Aristotle the philosopher said that wild beast was, which could see through everything, both trees, and even stones, which wild beast we call lynx;
tgt_text.1448: if, then, any one were so sharp-sighted that he could see through the youth whom we have before spoken about, then would he not appear to him so fair within as he outwardly seemed.
tgt_text.1449: Though thou seem fair to any one, it is not the sooner so;
tgt_text.1450: but the imperfection of their eyes hinders them, so that they cannot observe that they behold thee outwardly, not inwardly.
tgt_text.1451: But consider now very carefully, and inquire rationally, what these fleshly goods are, and these felicities which ye now im­ moderately desire.
tgt_text.1452: Then may ye evidently perceive that the fairness of the body, and its strength, may be taken away by three days' fever.
tgt_text.1453: I therefore say to thee all that I have be­ fore said to thee, because I would clearly prove to thee, in the conclusion of this chapter, that all these present goods cannot perform to their lovers that which they promise them, that is, the supreme good which they promise them.
tgt_text.1454: Though they collect together all these present goods, they have not the sooner perfect good therein;
tgt_text.1455: neither can they make their lovers as wealthy as they wish.§ III.
tgt_text.1456: When Wisdom had ended this speech, then began he again to sing, and thus singing, said:
tgt_text.1458: how grievous and how dangerous the error is which seduceth miserable men and leads them from the right way!
tgt_text.1460: Do ye seek gold on trees ?
tgt_text.1461: I know, however, that ye seek it not there, neither find ye it;
tgt_text.1462: for all men know that it grows not there, any more than jewels grow in vineyards.
tgt_text.1463: Do ye set your net on the highest hill, when ye are minded to fish ?
tgt_text.1464: But I know that ye set it not there.
tgt_text.1465: Do ye carry out your hounds and your net iuto the sea, when ye wish to hunt ?
tgt_text.1466: I think, however, that ye then place them upon hills and in woods.
tgt_text.1467: Truly it is wonderful that diligent men know that they must seek on the sea-shore and on river banks both white jewels and red, and gems of every kind;
tgt_text.1468: and they know also in what waters, and in what rivers' mouths they must seek fishes, and they know where they must seek all this present wealth, and incessantly seek it.
tgt_text.1469: But it is a very miserable thing that foolish men are so destitute of all judg­ ment, that they know not where the true felicities are bid, nor indeed have they any desire to seek them!
tgt_text.1470: But they think that in these frail and perishable things they can find the true happiness, that is, God!
tgt_text.1471: I know not how I can their folly all so plainly declare, and so greatly censure as I would, for they are more miserable, and more foolish, and more unhappy than I can explain.
tgt_text.1473: and when they have it, then think they, so unwise!
tgt_text.1474: that they have the true happiness!§
tgt_text.1475: I. ENOUGH I have now declared to thee concerning the resemblances and concerning the shadows of the true happi­ ness.
tgt_text.1476: But if thou canst now clearly understand the resem­ blances of the true happiness, then afterwards it is necessary that I show thee itself.
tgt_text.1478: Now I plainly perceive that there is not enough of every good in these worldly riches;
tgt_text.1479: nor is perfect power in any worldly authority;
tgt_text.1480: nor is true dignity in this world;
tgt_text.1481: nor are the greatest honours in this world's glory;
tgt_text.1482: nor is the highest pleasure in the fleshly lusts.
tgt_text.1484: Dost thou fully understand why it is so ?
tgt_text.1486: Though I understand it iu some mea­ sure, I would nevertheless learn it more fully and more dis­ tinctly from thee.
tgt_text.1488: It is sufficiently clear that good is single and indivisible, though foolish men divide it into many, when they erring seek the highest good in the worse creatures.
tgt_text.1489: But dost thou think that he has need of nothing more, who has the greatest power in this world ?
tgt_text.1490: Then answered I again, and said :
tgt_text.1491: I do not say that he has need of nothing more, for I know that no one is so wealthy that he needs not some addition.
tgt_text.1494: Though any one have power, if another have more, the weaker needs the aid of the stronger.
tgt_text.1496: It is all as thou sayest.
tgt_text.1498: Though any one call power and abund­ ance two things, it is nevertheless one.
tgt_text.1502: Thinkest thou now that power and abundance is to be despised ?
tgt_text.1503: or, again, more to be esteemed than other goods ?
tgt_text.1505: No man can doubt of this, that power and abundance is to be esteemed.
tgt_text.1507: Let us now, if it so seem to thee, make an addition to the power and the abundance;
tgt_text.1508: let us add dignity thereto, and then account the three as one.
tgt_text.1510: Let us do so, for it is true.
tgt_text.1512: Does the assem­ blage of these three things, then, seem to thee worthless and ignoble, when the three are united together?
tgt_text.1513: or whether, agaio, does it seem to thee of all things the most worthy and the most noble ?
tgt_text.1514: If thou knewest any man who had power over everything, and bad all dignity, even so far that he needed nothing more, consider, now, how honourable and how eminent the man would seem to thee ;
tgt_text.1515: and yet, though he bad the three, if he were not celebrated, then would there never- theless be to him a deficiency of some dignity .
tgt_text.1519: Is it not, then, sufficiently clear that we should add celebrity to the three, and make the four as one?
tgt_text.1523: Dost thou think that be is blithe who has all these four ?
tgt_text.1524: The fifth is pleasure, and that any one may do whatsoever he will, and need nothing more than he possesses ?
tgt_text.1526: I can never imagine, if be were such and bad all this, whence any trouble should come to him.
tgt_text.1528: But it must, then, be considered that the five things which we have before spoken about, though they are separately named in words, that it is all one thing when they are collected together, that is, power, and abundance, and glory, and dignity, and pleasure.§ II.
tgt_text.1529: These five things, when they are all collected together, then, that is God.
tgt_text.1530: For all the five no human being can fully have while he is in this world.
tgt_text.1531: But when these five things, as we before said, are all collected together, then is it all one thing, and that one thing is God:
tgt_text.1532: and he is single and un­ divided, though they before were, in many, separately named.
tgt_text.1536: Though God be single and undivided, as he is, human error divides him into many, by their vain words.
tgt_text.1537: Every man proposes to himself for the supreme good that which he chiefly loves.
tgt_text.1538: Then one loves this, and one another thing.
tgt_text.1539: That, then, is his good, which he chiefly loves.
tgt_text.1540: But when they divide their good into so many parts, then find they neither good itself, nor the part of good which they chiefly love.
tgt_text.1541: When they add it all together, they then have neither all of it, nor the part which they separated therefrom.
tgt_text.1542: For this reason every man finds not what he seeks, because he seeks it not rightly.
tgt_text.1543: Ye seek where ye cannot find, when ye seek all good in one good.
tgt_text.1547: When the man is poor, he is not desirous of power, but wishes for wealth, and flies from poverty.
tgt_text.1548: He labours not for this, how he may be most illustrious;
tgt_text.1549: nor, moreover, does any one obtain that which he labours not for.
tgt_text.1550: But he labours all his life for wealth, and foregoes many a worldly pleasure in order that he may acquire and keep wealth, because he is desirous of that above all other things.
tgt_text.1551: But if he obtain it, he then thinks that be has not enough, unless, he have also power be­ sides:
tgt_text.1552: for he thinks that he cannot keep the wealth without power.
tgt_text.1553: Nor, moreover, does there ever seem to him enough, until he has all that he desires.
tgt_text.1554: For wealth desires power, and power desires dignity, and dignity desires glory.
tgt_text.1555: After he is full of wealth, it then seems to him that he may have every desire if he have power:
tgt_text.1556: and he gives all the wealth for power, unless he is able to obtain it for less;
tgt_text.1557: and foregoes every other advantage, in order that he may attain to power.
tgt_text.1558: And then it often happens, that when he has given all that he had for power, he has neither the power, nor moreover that which he gave for it, but at length becomes so poor that he has not even mere necessaries, that is, food and clothing.
tgt_text.1559: He then is desirous of necessaries, not of power.
tgt_text.1560: We before spoke of the five felicities, that is, wealth, and power, and dignity, and renown, and pleasure.
tgt_text.1561: Now have we treated of wealth and of power;
tgt_text.1562: and the same we may say of the three which we have not treated of:
tgt_text.1563: that is, dignity, and renown, and pleasure.
tgt_text.1564: These three things, and the two which we before named, though any man think that in any one soever of them he can possess full happiness, it is not the sooner so, though they hope for it, unless they have all the five.
tgt_text.1566: What ought we then to do ?
tgt_text.1567: since thou sayest that we cannot in any one soever of these have the highest good, and full happiness:
tgt_text.1568: and we do not at all think that any one soever of us can obtain the five all together.
tgt_text.1570: If any one desire that he may have all the five, then desireth he the highest felicities;
tgt_text.1571: but he cannot fully obtain them in this world.
tgt_text.1572: For though he should obtain all the five goods, it nevertheless would not be the supreme good, nor the best happiness, because they are not eternal.
tgt_text.1574: Now I perceive clearly enough, that the best felicities are not in this world.
tgt_text.1576: No man needs in this present life to seek after the true felicities, nor think that here he can find sufficient good.
tgt_text.1580: I think that I have said enough to thee about the false goods.

tgt_text.1643: The nature of earth and of water is cold;

tgt_text.1649: Wonderful is thy counsel, which thou hast in both respects accomplished:
tgt_text.1650: both hast bounded the creatures between themselves, and also hast intermixed them:
tgt_text.1651: the dry and the cold earth under the cold and the wet water, that the soft and flowing water may have a floor on the firm earth, be­ cause it cannot of itself stand ;
tgt_text.1652: but the earth holds it, and in some measure imbibes, and by that moistening it becomes wet, so that it grows, and blossoms, and produces fruits.
tgt_text.1653: For if the water moistened it not, then would it become dry, and would be driven by the wind like dust or ashes.
tgt_text.1654: Nor could anything living enjoy the earth, or the water, or dwell in either for cold, if thou didst not a little mix them with fire.
tgt_text.1655: With wonderful skill thou hast caused it, that the fire burns not the water and the earth, when it is mixed with both:
tgt_text.1656: nor, again, the water and the earth entirely extinguish the fire.
tgt_text.1657: The water's own region is on the earth, and also in the air, and again above the sky.
tgt_text.1658: But the fire's own place is above all visible worldly creatures;
tgt_text.1659: and though it is mixed with all elements, nevertheless it cannot altogether overcome any one of the elements, because it has not leave from the Almighty.
tgt_text.1660: The earth, then, is heavier and thicker than other elements, because it is lower than any other creature except the sky:
tgt_text.1661: for the sky extends itself every day outwardly, and though it approaches it nowhere, it is in every place equally nigh to it, both above and beneath.
tgt_text.1662: Every one of the ele­ ments which we formerly spoke about has its own region apart, and yet is every one mixed with other;
tgt_text.1663: because no one of the elements can exist without another, though it be imperceptible in the other.
tgt_text.1664: Thus water and earth are very difficult to be seen or to be perceived by ignorant men in fire, and yet they are nevertheless mixed therewith.
tgt_text.1665: So is there also fire in stones and in water;
tgt_text.1666: very difficult to be seen, but it is nevertheless there.

tgt_text.1669: Thou hast established earth very wonderfully and firmly, so that it does not incline on any side, nor stand on any earthly thing, nor does anything earthly hold it that it may not sink;
tgt_text.1670: and it is not easier for it to fall downwards than upwards.
tgt_text.1671: Thou also movest the threefold soul in agreeing limbs;
tgt_text.1672: , so that there is not less of the soul in the least finger than in all the body.
tgt_text.1673: I said that the soul was threefold, because philo­ sophers say that she has three natures.
tgt_text.1674: One of these natures is, that she has the power of willing;
tgt_text.1675: the second is, that she is subject to anger;
tgt_text.1676: the third, that she is rational.
tgt_text.1677: Two of these natures beasts have, the same as men.
tgt_text.1678: One of them is will, the other is anger.
tgt_text.1679: But man alone has reason, and not any other creature.
tgt_text.1680: Therefore he has excelled all earthly creatures by thought and by understanding.
tgt_text.1681: For reason should govern both will and anger, because it is the peculiar faculty of the soul.
tgt_text.1682: So hast thou created the soul that she should always turn upon herself, as all this sky turns, or as a wheel turns round, inquiring about her maker, or about herself, or about these earthly creatures.

tgt_text.1684: But when she inquires about her­ self, then is she in herself.

tgt_text.1687: and causest them to shine very bright, and yet with very varied brightness, some brighter, some less bright, even as the stars, every one according to its desert.

tgt_text.2261: and in every land wicked men are now honoured, and the good have manifold punishments.
tgt_text.2262: Who can forbear lamenting and won­ dering at such a marvel, that ever such evil should take place under the government of Almighty God, when we know that be sees it, and wills all good.
tgt_text.2264: If it is as thou sayest, then is this more dreadful than any other prodigy, and is endless wonder:
tgt_text.2265: most like to this, that in a king's court gold and silver vessels should be despised, and men should esteem wooden ones.
tgt_text.2266: It is not as thou supposest.
tgt_text.2267: But if thou wilt call to mind all that which we have before said, then, with the help of God, concerning whom we are now speaking, thou wilt be able to understand that the good are always powerful, and the wicked have no power;
tgt_text.2268: and that virtues are never without praise or without reward, nor are vices ever unpunished;
tgt_text.2269: but the good are always happy, and the wicked unhappy.
tgt_text.2270: I can show thee very many examples of this which may encourage thee, so that thou mayest not know what thou any longer shouldest lament.
tgt_text.2271: But I will now teach thee the way which will lead thee to the heavenly city, whence thou formerly earnest, since thou knowest through ray instruction what the true happiness is, and where it is.
tgt_text.2272: But I must first give wings to thy mind, that it may the sooner raise itself up, before it begins to fly on high ;
tgt_text.2273: in order that it may, sound and untroubled, By to its native country, and leave behind it every one of the troubles which it now endures.
tgt_text.2274: Let it sit in my chariot, and be con­ ducted in my path;
tgt_text.2275: I will be its guide.§ II.
tgt_text.2276: When Wisdom had ended this speech, then began he again to sing, and said:
tgt_text.2277: I have very swift wings, so that I can fly over the high roof of heaven.
tgt_text.2278: But I must furnish thy mind with wings, that thou mayest fly with me:
tgt_text.2279: then mayest thou look down upon all these earthly things.
tgt_text.2280: When thou art able to fly over the sky, thou mayest behold the clouds under thee, and mayeat fly over the fire which is between the aky and the air;
tgt_text.2281: and mayest go with the sun between the stars, and then be in the sky, and afterwards near the cold star which we call Saturn'a star.
tgt_text.2283: It wanders above other stars, higher than any other heavenly body.
tgt_text.2284: After thou art elevated far above it, then wilt thou be above the swift sky, and wilt leave behind thee the highest heaven.
tgt_text.2285: After this thou mayeat have thy portion of the true light;
tgt_text.2286: There reigns one king who has power over all other kings.
tgt_text.2287: He regulates the bridle and the rein of all the circuit of heaven and earth.
tgt_text.2288: The only judge is steadfast and bright.
tgt_text.2289: He directs the chariot of all creatures.
tgt_text.2290: But if thou ever comest into the path, and to the place which thou hast now forgotten, then wilt thou say:
tgt_text.2292: hence I formerly came, and hence was I born:
tgt_text.2293: here I will now stand fast;
tgt_text.2295: But, I wot, if it ever happen to thee that thou wilt or must again explore the darkness of this world, then wilt thou observe unjust kings, and all the proud rich, to be very feeble, and very wretched exiles:
tgt_text.2296: the same whom this miserable people now most dreads!§
tgt_text.2299: 0 Wisdom, great is that and won­ derful which thou dost promise, and I, moreover, doubt not that thou canst perform it!
tgt_text.2300: But I beseech thee that thou wouldest not any longer hinder me, but teach me the way, for thou mayest perceive that I am desirous of the way.
tgt_text.2302: Thou must first understand that the good always have power, and the wicked never have any, nor any ability;
tgt_text.2303: for none of them comprehends that good and evil are always enemies.
tgt_text.2304: If, therefore, the good always have power, then the wicked never have any, because good and evil are very incon­ gruous.
tgt_text.2305: But I would inform thee somewhat more distinctly concerning each of them, that thou mayest the better believe what I shall sometimes tell thee concerning the one, and some­ times concerning the other.
tgt_text.2306: There are two things which every man's intention requires, that is, will and power.
tgt_text.2307: If, there­ fore, there is to any man a deficiency of either of the two, he cannot with the other effect anything.
tgt_text.2308: For no one will un­ dertake what he is unwilling to do, unless he needs must:
tgt_text.2309: and though be fully wills he cannot perform it, if he has not power of that thing.
tgt_text.2310: Hence thou mayest clearly'know, when thou seest any man desirous of that which he has not, that to him power is wanting.
tgt_text.2315: But if thou seest any one who can do what he desires to do, then there is no doubt to thee that he has power.
tgt_text.2317: I have no doubt of it.
tgt_text.2319: Every man is powerful so far as he exercises power:
tgt_text.2320: he has no power when he does not exercise power.
tgt_text.2324: Canst thou now call to mind what I before told thee, that is, that the mind of every man desires to arrive at the true happiness, though they pursue it differently ?
tgt_text.2327: it is clearly enough proved to me.
tgt_text.2329: Dost thou remember that I before said to thee, that it was all one, good and happi­ ness ?
tgt_text.2330: He who seeks happiness seeks good.
tgt_text.2332: I have it sufficiently fixed in my memory.
tgt_text.2334: All men, both good and evil, desire to come to good, though they desire it variously.
tgt_text.2336: That is true which thou sayest.
tgt_text.2338: It is sufficiently evident that good men are good because they find good.
tgt_text.2342: The good obtain the good which they desire.
tgt_text.2346: The wicked would not be wicked if they found the good which they desire;
tgt_text.2347: but they are wicked because they do not find it, and they do not find it because they do not seek it rightly.
tgt_text.2349: So it is as thou sayest.
tgt_text.2351: Therefore there is no doubt that the good are always powerful, and the wicked have no power, because the good, seek good rightly, and the wicked wrongly.
tgt_text.2353: He who thinks that this is not true, then believes be no truth.
tgt_text.2357: if two men are going to one place, and have equally great desire to arrive there, and one has the use of his feet, so that he may go where he will, as it were natural to all men that they could;
tgt_text.2358: and the other has not the use of his feet that he can go, and yet is desirous to go, and begins to creep the same way, whether of the two dost thou think the more powerful ?
tgt_text.2361: He is more powerful who goes than he who creeps, because he can more easily come whither he will than the other.
tgt_text.2362: Say what else thou wilt, every man knows that.
tgt_text.2364: In like manner it is with the good and with the wicked.
tgt_text.2365: Each of them desires naturally that he may come to the highest good.
tgt_text.2366: But the good is able to come whither he desires, because he desires it rightly, and the wicked cannot come to that which he desires, because he seeks it wrongly.
tgt_text.2367: I know not but thou mayest think dif­ ferently.
tgt_text.2369: I do not think at all differently from what thou sayest.
tgt_text.2371: Very rightly thou under­ standest it:
tgt_text.2372: and that is also a token of thy health;
tgt_text.2373: as it is the custom of physicians to say, when they see a sick man, if they perceive in him any healthy token.
tgt_text.2374: Methinks now that thy nature and thy habit contends very powerfully against error.§
tgt_text.2375: V. I have now found that thou art prompt to understand my doctrine:
tgt_text.2376: therefore I am desirous to collect for thee many arguments and many examples, so that thou mayest the more easily understand what I am about to say.
tgt_text.2377: Observe now, how feeble wicked meo are, when they cannot come thither where even irrational creatures are desirous to come;
tgt_text.2378: and how much, more feeble they would be if they had no natural inclination to it.
tgt_text.2379: Behold with how heavy a chain of folly and unbappi­ ness they are bound!
tgt_text.2380: Even children, when they can just go, and also old men, as long as they can go, are desirous of some honour and some praise.
tgt_text.2381: Children ride on their sticks, and play at various sorts of play, wherein they imitate old men.
tgt_text.2382: But the unwise are not willing to attempt anything from which they may expect to themselves praise or rewards.
tgt_text.2383: But they do what is worse;
tgt_text.2384: they run erring hither and thither under the roof of all things;
tgt_text.2385: and that which irrational crea­ tures know, unwise men do not know.
tgt_text.2386: Therefore the virtues are better than the vices.
tgt_text.2387: For every man must be convinced, whether he will, or whether he will not, that he is the most powerful who is able to arrive at the highest roof of all things, that is God;
tgt_text.2388: whom nothing is above, nor anything beneath, nor about, but all things are in him, iu his power.
tgt_text.2389: God is greatly to be loved.
tgt_text.2390: Didst thou not before say, that he was most powerful in walking who could go, if he would, to the end of this earth, so that no part of this earth were beyond it ?
tgt_text.2391: The same thou mayest conceive with regard to God, as we before said, that he is most powerful who can come to him, because he nowhere beyond that can come!§
tgt_text.2393: From all these arguments thou mayest understand that the good are always powerful, and the wicked are desti­ tute of all power and all ability.
tgt_text.2394: Why, then, dost thou think they forsake virtues aud follow vices ?
tgt_text.2395: But I suppose thou wilt say, that it is through ignorance that the are not able to distinguish them.
tgt_text.2396: But what wilt thou then say is worse than this want of reason ?
tgt_text.2397: Why do they allow themselves to be ignorant ?
tgt_text.2398: Why will they not inquire after virtues and after wisdom ?
