tgt_text.2399: But I know that drowsiness oppresses them, and overcomes them with sloth, and covetousness blinds them.
tgt_text.2400: We have before said, that nothing was worse than ignorance.
tgt_text.2401: But what shall we now say, if the intelligent have vices, and will not inquire after wisdom and after virtues ?
tgt_text.2402: I know, however, that thou wilt say that luxury and intemperance oppress them.
tgt_text.2403: But what is weaker than the man who is utterly overcome by the frail flesh, unless he afterwards de­ sist, and contend against vices as he best may ?
tgt_text.2404: But what wilt thou say if any creature will not contend against them, but with full will forsakes all good, and does evil, and is nevertheless intelligent ?
tgt_text.2405: I say that he is feeble, and more­ over altogether nothing!
tgt_text.2406: For whosoever forsakes the uni­ versal good of all goods, without doubt he is nothing.
tgt_text.2407: But whosoever desires that he may be virtuous, desires that he may be wise.
tgt_text.2408: Whosoever, then, is virtuous is wise:
tgt_text.2409: and he who is wise is good;
tgt_text.2410: he then who is good is happy;
tgt_text.2411: and he who is happy is blessed;
tgt_text.2412: and he who is blessed is a god, so far as we have before mentioned in this same book.
tgt_text.2413: But I rather think that foolish men will wonder at that which I have just now said, that is, that wicked men were nothing;
tgt_text.2414: because there is a greater number of them than of the others.
tgt_text.2415: But though they never believe it, yet it is so.
tgt_text.2416: We can never reckon the wicked man pure and sincere, any more than we can call or esteem a dead man living.
tgt_text.2417: Nor indeed is the living better than the dead, if he repent not of his evil.
tgt_text.2418: But he who lives recklessly, and will not preserve his nature, is not he nothing ?§ VII.
tgt_text.2419: I think, however, thou wilt say that this is not altogether so likely, because the wicked can do evil, though he cannot do good, and the dead can do neither.
tgt_text.2420: But I say to thee that the power of the wicked does not come from any virtues, but from vices.
tgt_text.2421: But if the evil were always good, then would they do no evil.
tgt_text.2422: It is not from power that any one is able to do evil, but it is from weakness.
tgt_text.2423: If that is true which one some time ago asserted, that evil is nothing, then he works nothing who works evil.
tgt_text.2425: Very true is that which thou sayest.
tgt_text.2427: Did we not prove be­ fore that nothing was more powerful than the highest good ?
tgt_text.2429: So it is as thou sayest.
tgt_text.2431: Yet it cannot do any evil.
tgt_text.2435: Does any one think that any man can be so powerful that he is able to do all that he wills ?
tgt_text.2437: No man thinks it who has his senses.
tgt_text.2439: But wicked men, nevertheless, can do evil.
tgt_text.2443: It is evident that they can do evil, and cannot do any good.
tgt_text.2444: That is because evil is nothing.
tgt_text.2445: But the good, if they have full power, are able to do whatsoever good they will.
tgt_text.2446: Therefore full power is to be reckoned among the highest goods;
tgt_text.2447: for both power and the other goods and excellences, which we long ago mentioned, are fixed in the highest good.
tgt_text.2448: As the wall of every house is fixed both to the floor and to the roof, so is every good fixed in God, for he is both the roof and floor of every good.
tgt_text.2449: Therefore is the power that man may do good, ever to be desired:
tgt_text.2450: for that is the best power, that any one is able and willing to do well, whether with less means or with greater, whichsoever he may have.
tgt_text.2451: For whosoever wills to do good, is desirous to have good, and to be with good.
tgt_text.2452: Therefore is Plato's saying very true, which he said:
tgt_text.2453: The wise alone can do the good which they desire;
tgt_text.2454: the wicked can only attempt what they desire.
tgt_text.2455: I know not, however, but thou wilt say that the good sometimes begin what they cannot accomplish.
tgt_text.2456: But I say that they always accomplish it.
tgt_text.2457: Though they may not perfect the work, they have nevertheless full will, and the sincere will is to be reckoned for the perfect work.
tgt_text.2458: Therefore they never fail of rewards either here or there, or both.
tgt_text.2459: If the wicked have will to work what they list, though it is not now perfect, they lose not also the will, but have its punishment either here or elsewhere, or both.
tgt_text.2460: So greatly does the evil will control them !
tgt_text.2461: For this reason they cannot obtain the good which they desire, because they seek it through this will, and not through the right way.
tgt_text.2462: The evil will has no fellowship with happiness.
tgt_text.2463: When Wisdom had finished this speech, then began he again to sing, and thus said:
tgt_text.2465: I. HEAR now a discourse concerning proud and unjust kings, whom we see sitting on the highest thrones;
tgt_text.2466: who shine in clothes of many kinds, and are surrounded by a great company of their thanes, who are adorned with belts and golden-hilted swords, and with manifold weapons, and terrify all mankind with their greatness.
tgt_text.2467: And he who governs them regards neither friend nor foe, any more than a mad hound;
tgt_text.2468: but is inconceivably lifted up in his mind, through unbounded power.
tgt_text.2469: But if any man should strip off from him the clothes, and deprive him of the retinue and the power, then wouldest thou see that he is very like to any one of those his thanes who serve him, unless he be worse.
tgt_text.2470: And moreover, if it by chance happen unto him that he at any time is deprived of the retinue, and of the clothes, and of the power, then it seems to him that he is brought to prison or to chains.
tgt_text.2471: Because from excess, and from immoderate clothing, and from dainty food, and from various drinks of the cup, the fury of lust is excited, and disquiets their minds very greatly:
tgt_text.2472: then increases also arrogance and wickedness;
tgt_text.2473: and when they are offended, then is the mind scourged with the heat of anger, until they are distracted with unhappiness, and so enslaved!
tgt_text.2474: After this takes place, the hope of revenge begins to deceive them, and whatsoever his anger wills his recklessness pro­ mises him.
tgt_text.2475: I said to thee long before, in this same book, that all creatures were naturally desirous of some good:
tgt_text.2476: but unjust kings can do no good, for the reason I have now given­ thee.
tgt_text.2477: That is no wonder, for they subject themselves to all the vices which I have already named to thee.
tgt_text.2478: Every one of them, therefore, necessarily must submit to the judgment of the lords, to whom be has already subjected himself;
tgt_text.2479: and what is still worse, that he will not even strive against them.
tgt_text.2480: If he were willing to attempt it, and then were able to per­ severe in the contest, then would he be free from his guilt.§
tgt_text.2482: When Wisdom had sung this lay, then began he again to speak, and thus said:
tgt_text.2483: Seest thou in how great, and in how deep, and in how dark a sink of vices the evil-willing are involved, and how the good shine brighter than the sun ?
tgt_text.2484: For the good are never destitute of the rewards of their good, nor the wicked ever of the punishments which they deserve.
tgt_text.2485: Everything which is done in this world has recompense.
tgt_text.2486: Let any one work what he may, or do what he may, he will ever have that which he earns.
tgt_text.2487: Moreover, it is not unjust, as was formerly the custom of the Romans, and still is in many na­ tions, that man should have a golden crown at the end of some course.
tgt_text.2488: Many people then come thereto, and all run equally, those who have confidence in their running;
tgt_text.2489: and whichsoever first arrives at the crown, then may he have it to himself.
tgt_text.2490: Every one desires that he may first arrive, and have it;
tgt_text.2491: but nevertheless it falls to one.
tgt_text.2492: So does all man­ kind in this present life,-runs and hastens, and is desirous of the highest good.
tgt_text.2493: But it is offered to no one man, but is offered to all men.
tgt_text.2494: Therefore it is needful to every one that he strive with all his power after the reward.
tgt_text.2495: Of the reward no good man is ever deprived.
tgt_text.2496: A man cannot rightly call himself good if he be destitute of the highest good, for no good servant is without good rewards.
tgt_text.2497: Let the wicked do what they may, the crown of good reward will always be pos­ sessed by the good for ever.
tgt_text.2498: The evil of the wicked cannot deprive the good of their good, and of their excellence.
tgt_text.2499: But if they had that good from without them, then might some one deprive them of it;
tgt_text.2500: either he who formerly bestowed it, or another man.
tgt_text.2501: But a good man then loses his rewards when lie forsakes his good.
tgt_text.2502: Understand, then, that to every man his own good gives good reward;
tgt_text.2503: that good which is in himself.
tgt_text.2504: What wise man will say, that any good man is des­ titute of the highest good?
tgt_text.2505: for he always labours after it.
tgt_text.2506: But meditate thou always on the great and the fair reward, for that reward is above all other rewards to be loved:
tgt_text.2507: and add that reward to the before-mentioned goods which I for­ merly recounted to thee in the third book.
tgt_text.2508: When they are added together, then mayest thou perceive that happiness and the highest good are all one, and that is G-od.
tgt_text.2509: And then thou mayest also perceive that every good man is happy, and that all happy men are gods, and have eternal reward of their good!§ III.
tgt_text.2510: Therefore no wise man needs to doubt that the evil have also eternal recompense of their evil, that is, eternal punishment.
tgt_text.2511: Though thou mayest think that any of them is happy here in respect of the world, he nevertheless has always his evil with him, and also the recompense of the evil, even.
tgt_text.2513: There is no wise man who is ignorant that good and evil are always discordant between themselves, and always are at variance in their wishes.
tgt_text.2514: And as the goodness of the good is his own good, and his own re­ ward, so is also the evil of the wicked his own evil, and his reward, and his own punishment.
tgt_text.2515: No man if he has punish­ ment, doubts that lie has evil.
tgt_text.2517: do the wicked think that they are exempted from punishments, and yet are full of all evil?
tgt_text.2518: Not only are they foul, but almost brought to nothing.
tgt_text.2519: Understand, therefore, from the good, how great punishment the wicked always have:
tgt_text.2521: and well retain those which I before mentioned to thee.
tgt_text.2522: Whatsoever has unity, that we say exists while it re­ mains together;
tgt_text.2523: and this unity we call good.
tgt_text.2524: Thus a man is a man whilst the soul and the body are together.
tgt_text.2525: But when they are separated, then is he not that which he was before.
tgt_text.2526: The same thou mayest conceive concerning the body, and concerning its limbs.
tgt_text.2527: If any of the limbs is off, then it is not full man, as it was before.
tgt_text.2528: So if any good man depart from good, then is he not any more fully good, if he at all depart from good.
tgt_text.2529: When it happens that the wicked leave off what they before did, they are not what they before were.
tgt_text.2530: But when men forsake good, and become wicked, then are they nothing but a resemblance;
tgt_text.2531: so that one may see that they formerly were men, but they have lost the best part of humanity, and kept the worst.
tgt_text.2532: They forsake the good of their nature, that is human manners, and have nevertheless the likeness of man while they live.
tgt_text.2534: But as the goodness of men raises them above human nature, so far that they are named gods;
tgt_text.2535: so also their wicked­ ness degrades them below human nature, so far that they are called evil, which we say is nothing.
tgt_text.2536: Therefore if thou shouldest meet a man so debased that he is turned from good to evil, thou canst not rightly name him man, but beast.
tgt_text.2537: If then thou observest with respect to any man, that he is a rapacious man, and a spoiler, thou shouldest not call him a man, but a wolf.
tgt_text.2538: And the fierce man who is a brawler, thou shouldest call a hound, not a man.
tgt_text.2539: And the deceitful, crafty man, thou shouldest call a fox, not a man.
tgt_text.2540: And the immo­ derately proud and angry man, who has great malice, thou shalt call a lion, not a man.
tgt_text.2541: And the dull man who is too slow, thou shouldest call an ass more than a man.
tgt_text.2542: And the excessively timid man who is more fearful than he needs, thou mayest call a hare more than a man.
tgt_text.2543: And to the inconstant and the light, thou mayest say, that they are more like the wind, or restless birds, than modest men.
tgt_text.2544: And to him whom thou observest that he is lying in the lusts of his body, thou mayest say, that he is most like to fat swine, which always desire to lie in foul mire, and will not wash themselves in pure waters;
tgt_text.2545: but if they sometimes rarely are made to swim, then cast they themselves again into the mire, and wallow therein.
tgt_text.2546: When Wisdom had ended this speech, then began he again to sing, and thus said:
tgt_text.2548: I. I CAN relate to thee, from ancient fables, a story very like to the subject which we have just now spoken about.
tgt_text.2549: It happened formerly in the Trojan war, that there was a king whose name was Ulysses, who had two countries under the Cæsar.
tgt_text.2550: The countries were called Ithaca and Retia, and the Cæsar's name was Agamemnon.
tgt_text.2551: When Ulysses went with the Cæsar to the battle, he had some hundred ships.
tgt_text.2552: Then were they some ten years in that war.
tgt_text.2553: When the king again returned homeward from the Cæsar, and they had conquered the land, he had not more ships than one;
tgt_text.2554: but that was a ship with three rows of oars.
tgt_text.2555: Then opposed him a great tempest and a stormy sea.
tgt_text.2556: He was then driven on an island out in the Wendel sea.
tgt_text.2557: Then was there the daughter of Apollo, the son of Jove.
tgt_text.2558: Jove was their king, and pretended that lie should be the highest god, and that foolish people believed him because he was of royal lineage, and they knew not any other God at that time, but worshipped their kings for gods.
tgt_text.2559: Then should the father of Jove be also a god, whose name was Saturn;
tgt_text.2560: and likewise all his kindred they held for gods.
tgt_text.2561: Then was one of them the Apollo whom we before mentioned.
tgt_text.2562: Apollo's daughter should be a goddess, whose name was Circe.
tgt_text.2563: She, they said, should be very skilful in sorcery;
tgt_text.2564: and she dwelt in the island on which the king was driven, about whom we before spoke.
tgt_text.2565: She had then a very great company of her servants, and also of other maidens.
tgt_text.2566: As soon as she saw the king driven thither, whom we before mentioned, whose name was Ulysses, then began she to love him, and each of them the other, beyond measure ;
tgt_text.2567: so that he for love of her neglected all his kingdom, and his family, and dwelt with her until the time that his thanes would no longer remain with him ;
tgt_text.2568: but for love of their country, and on ac­ count of exile, determined to leave him.
tgt_text.2569: Then began false men to work spells.
tgt_text.2570: And they said that she should by her sorcery overthrow the men, and cast them into the bodies of wild beasts, and afterwards throw them into chains and fetters.
tgt_text.2571: Some, they said, she should transform to lions, and when they should speak then they roared.
tgt_text.2572: Some should be wild boars, and when they should lament their misfortune then they grunted.
tgt_text.2574: These howled when they should speak.
tgt_text.2575: Some became that kind of wild beast that man calls tiger.
tgt_text.2576: Thus was all the company turned to wild beasts of various kinds;
tgt_text.2577: each to some beast, except the king alone.
tgt_text.2578: Every meat they refused which men eat, and were desirous of those which beasts eat.
tgt_text.2579: They had no resemblance of men either in body or in voice, yet every one knew his mind, as he before knew it.
tgt_text.2580: That mind was very sorrowful through the miseries which they suffered.
tgt_text.2581: Indeed, the men who believed these fictions, nevertheless knew that she by sorcery could not change the minds of men, though she changed the bodies.
tgt_text.2582: How great an excellence is that of the mind in comparison of the body!
tgt_text.2583: By these things, and the like thou mayest learn, that the excellence of the body is in the mind;
tgt_text.2584: and that to every man the vices of his mind are more hurtful.
tgt_text.2585: Those of the mind draw all the body to them, and the infirmity of the body cannot entirely draw the mind to it.
tgt_text.2588: I am convinced that that is true which thou before saidst, that is, that it would not be unfit that we should call evil-willing men cattle, or wild beasts, though they have the resemblance of man.
tgt_text.2589: But if I had such power as the Almighty God has, then would I not let the wicked injure the good so much as they now do.
tgt_text.2591: It is not permitted to them so long as thou supposest.
tgt_text.2592: But thou mayest be assured that their prosperity will very soon be re­ moved, as I will shortly inform thee, though I have not leisure now on account of other discourse.
tgt_text.2593: If they had not the vain power, which they think they have, then would they not have so great punishment as they shall have.
tgt_text.2594: The wicked are much more unhappy when they are able to accomplish the evil which they list, than they are when they are unable to do it;
tgt_text.2595: though these foolish men do not believe it.
tgt_text.2596: It is very wicked that any man wills evil, and it is still much worse that he is able to do it, for the evil will is dispersed like incense before the fire, if man is not able to accomplish the work.
tgt_text.2597: But the wicked have sometimes three misfortunes:
tgt_text.2598: one is, that they will evil;
tgt_text.2599: the second, that they are able to do it;
tgt_text.2600: the third, that they accomplish it.
tgt_text.2601: For God has decreed to give punish­ ments and miseries to wicked men for their wicked works.
tgt_text.2603: So it is as thou sayest;
tgt_text.2604: and yet I would wish, if I might, that they had not the unhappiness of being able to do evil.
tgt_text.2606: I think, however, that that power will be lost to them sooner than either thou or they would expect.
tgt_text.2607: For nothing is of long duration in this present life, though it seem to men that it be long.
tgt_text.2608: But very frequently the great power of the wicked falls very suddenly, even as a great tree in a wood makes a loud crash when men least expect;
tgt_text.2609: and through fear they are always very miserable.
tgt_text.2610: But if their wickedness makes them miserable, is not then the long evil always worse than the short P
tgt_text.2611: Though the wicked never died, I should still say that they were most miserable.
tgt_text.2612: If the miseries are all true, which we long ago discoursed about, that the wicked should have in this world, then is it evident that those miseries are infinite which are eternal.
tgt_text.2614: That is wonderful which thou sayest, and very difficult to be understood by foolish men.
tgt_text.2615: But I nevertheless perceive that it appertains well enough to the discourse which we were before holding.
tgt_text.2617: I am not now speaking to foolish men, but am speaking to those who desire to understand wisdom;
tgt_text.2618: for it is a token of wisdom that any one is willing to hear and understand it.
tgt_text.2619: But if any of the foolish doubt any of the reasonings which we have already uttered in this same book, let him show, if he can, some one of the arguments which is either false, or inapplicable to the subject about which we are inquiring;
tgt_text.2620: or thirdly, let him turn, understand, and believe that we argue rightly.
tgt_text.2621: If he will do none of these things, then he knows not what he means.§ III.
tgt_text.2622: But I can still teach thee another thing, which to foolish men will seem yet more incredible, and is nevertheless suitable enough to the argument which we are holding.
tgt_text.2626: It is this, that those wicked persons are much happier who in this world have great misery, and manifold punishment for their evil, than those are who have no suffering nor punishment in this world for their guilt.
tgt_text.2627: Let no one, however, think that I speak thus merely because I would reprove vices, and praise virtue, and by the example urge and persuade men to good conduct through fear of punishment:
tgt_text.2628: but I speak it still more for other reasons.
tgt_text.2630: For what other reasons wouldest thou speak it, except what thou hast just mentioned ?
tgt_text.2632: Dost thou recollect what we before said, that is, that the good always had power and happiness, and the wicked never had either ?
tgt_text.2636: But what thickest thou, if thou seest any man very unhappy, and yet perceivest something of good in him;
tgt_text.2637: is he as unhappy as the man who has no good in him ?
tgt_text.2639: He appears to me happier, who has something of good.
tgt_text.2641: But what then dost thou think con­ cerning him who has no good, if he has some addition of evil ?
tgt_text.2642: He, thou wilt say, is still more unhappy than the other, through the addition of evil.
tgt_text.2644: Why should not I think so ?
tgt_text.2646: Consider that it so appears to thee, and understand with inward mind that the wicked have always something of good among their evil, that is their punishment, which we may very easily, and justly reckon to them as good.
tgt_text.2647: But those whose evil is all unpunished in this world, have an evil heavier and more dangerous than any punishment in this world is;
tgt_text.2648: that is,, that their evil is un­ punished in this world, which is the most evident token of the greatest evil in this world, and of the worst recompense after this world.
tgt_text.2652: Therefore the wicked are more unhappy, because their wickedness is undeservedly forgiven them, than they are if their wickedness is recompensed according to their deserts.
tgt_text.2653: Therefore it is right that evil should be inflicted on the wicked, and it is wrong that they should be suffered to go unpunished.
tgt_text.2657: No man can deny that everything is good which is right, and everything evil which is wrong.
tgt_text.2659: I am very much troubled with this discourse, and wonder why so righteous a judge should bestow any unjust gift.
tgt_text.2663: Because thou before saidst that he did wrong, inasmuch as lie left the wicked unpunished.
tgt_text.2665: That is his glory, that he is so bountiful, and bestows so abundantly.
tgt_text.2666: It is a great gift that he waits till the wicked are sensible of their evil and turn to good.
tgt_text.2668: Now I understand that it is not an eternal gift which he gives to the wicked, but is rather the delay and waiting of the highest judge.
tgt_text.2669: On account of his waiting and forbearance, methinks he is the more despised ;
tgt_text.2670: and yet this argument pleases me well enough, and seems to me like enough to what thou before saidst.
tgt_text.2672: But I beseech thee, now, that thou wouldest tell me whether thou thinkest that the wicked have any punishment after this world;
tgt_text.2673: or the good any reward for their goodness ?
tgt_text.2675: Did I not say to thee before, that the good have recompense for their goodness both here and for ever;
tgt_text.2676: and the wicked also have recompense for their evil, both here, and also for ever ?
tgt_text.2677: But I will now divide the wicked from the wicked in two parts.
tgt_text.2678: For one'part of the wicked shall have eternal punishment, because they have deserved no mercy;
tgt_text.2679: and the other part shall be cleansed and proved iu the heavenly fire, as silver here is, because it has some deserving of some mercy, wherefore it may come after these troubles to everlasting honour.
tgt_text.2680: Still I could instruct thee more both concerning the good and concerning the evil, if I now had leisure.
tgt_text.2681: But I fear that I should neglect what we were be­ fore seeking after, that is, that we would argue so that thou mightest perceive that the wicked have no power, nor any honour, either in this world or in that to come.
tgt_text.2682: For for­ merly this appeared to thee the worst of all things, that thou thoughtest they had'too much;
tgt_text.2683: and thou always didst lament that they were not always punished:
tgt_text.2684: and I always said to thee, that they never are without punishment, though it ap­ pear not so to thee.
tgt_text.2685: But I know, however, that thou wilt lament that they have so long time permission to do evil;
tgt_text.2686: and I have always said to thee, that the time is a very little while ;
tgt_text.2687: and I now say to thee, that the longer it is, the more unhappy they are, and it would be to them the greatest un­ happiness of all, that the time continued till doomsday.
tgt_text.2688: And I said to thee also, that they would be more unhappy if their evil were unjustly passed over, than they would be if their evil were justly punished.
tgt_text.2689: Yet it so happens that thou thinkest those who have impunity are happier than those who are punished.§
tgt_text.2691: Nothing ever appears to me so true as thy arguments appear to me, at the times when I hear them.
tgt_text.2692: But if I turn myself to the judgment of this people, they not only are unwilling to believe this thy doctrine, but they will not even hear it.
tgt_text.2695: Thou knowest that the men who have unsound eyes cannot very easily look at the sun when she shines brightest, nor indeed do they choose to look on fire, or on anything bright, though the apple of the eye be left.
tgt_text.2696: In like manner the sinful minds are blinded by their evil will, so that they are not able to be­ hold the light of bright truth, which is the highest wisdom.
tgt_text.2697: But it is with them, as with the birds and the beasts which can see better by night than by day.
tgt_text.2698: The day blinds and darkens their eyes, and the darkness of the night enlightens them.
tgt_text.2699: Therefore the blinded minds think that this is the greatest happiness, that a man should be permitted to do evil, and his deed should be unpunished, For they are not desirous to inquire after every instruction, until they know what is right, but turn to their evil will, and seek after it.
tgt_text.2700: There­ fore I know not to what purpose thou teachest me to the foolish men who never inquire after me.
tgt_text.2702: but I speak to thee, because thou art inclined to seek after me, and labourest more in the pursuit than they do.
tgt_text.2703: I care not what they judge.
tgt_text.2704: I approve thy judgment more than theirs, for they all look with both eyes, as well with the eyes of the mind as with those of the body, on these earthly things, which excessively delight them.
tgt_text.2705: But thou alone sometimes lookest with one eye on the heavenly things, and with the other thou lookest as yet on these earthly things.
tgt_text.2706: For the foolish think that every man is as blind as they are, and that no man is able to see what they cannot behold.
tgt_text.2707: Such folly is most like to this;
tgt_text.2708: that a child should be born full sound and full healthy, and so flourishing in all excellences and virtues, during childhood and afterwards throughout youth, that he becomes capable of every art;
tgt_text.2709: and then a little before his middle-age, he should become blind in both eyes, and also the eyes of the mind should become so blinded, that he remembers nothing which he ever before saw or heard:
tgt_text.2710: and nevertheless he should think that he is as capable of everything as he ever was when most capable:
tgt_text.2711: and should think that it is with every man as it is with him ;
tgt_text.2712: and that it seems to every man as it seems to him.
tgt_text.2713: But though lie were so foolish as to think so, should we all think as he thinks ?
tgt_text.2714: I think, however, that we should not.
tgt_text.2715: But I wish to know what thou thinkest concerning the men of whom we before said, that it appeared to us that they were more like wild beasts than men ?
tgt_text.2717: Methinks, however, they have none.§ VI.
tgt_text.2718: I would now utter to thee a true observation, but I know that this people will not believe it:
tgt_text.2719: that is, that those persons whom men injure are happier than those are who injure them.
tgt_text.2720: Then wondered I at this, and said:
tgt_text.2721: I wish that thou wouldest explain to me how it can be so.
tgt_text.2723: Dost thou understand that every evil-willing man and every evil-doing man is deserving of punishment ?
tgt_text.2727: Is he not then evil-willing and evil-doing, who injures the innocent ?
tgt_text.2729: So it is as thou sayest.
tgt_text.2731: Dost thou think that they are miserable and unhappy, who are deserving of punishment?
tgt_text.2733: I not only think it, but know it very well.
tgt_text.2735: If thou wert now to judge, which wouldest thou judge more deserving of punishment, him who injured the innocent, or him who suffered the injury ?
tgt_text.2738: I would help him who was innocent, and oppose him who injured him.
tgt_text.2740: Then, in thy opinion, he is more miserable who does the evil, than he who suffers it.
tgt_text.2742: This I believe, that every unjust punishment is the evil of him who inflicts it, not of him who suffers it;
tgt_text.2743: there­ fore his evil makes him miserable.
tgt_text.2744: And I perceive that this is a very just observation which thou now makest, and very agreeable to those which thou madest before;
tgt_text.2745: but I never­ theless know that this people will not think so.
tgt_text.2749: But advocates now-a-days plead for those who have less need of it.
tgt_text.2750: They plead for those who are injured, and do not plead for those who do the injury.
tgt_text.2751: It were more needful to those who injure others who are innocent, that some one should plead for them before the magistrates, and pray that as great hurt might be done to them, as they had done to other innocent persons.
tgt_text.2752: As the sick man has need that some one should lead him to the physician, that he may cure him;
tgt_text.2753: so has he who does evil, that some one should lead him to the magis­ trates, that they may cut off and burn his vices.
tgt_text.2754: I do not say that it is wrong that men should help the innocent, and defend him;
tgt_text.2755: but I say that it is better that we should accuse the guilty ;
tgt_text.2756: and I say that the defence does no good either to the guilty or to him who pleads for him, if they wish that their evil should not he punished in proportion to its guilt.
tgt_text.2757: But I know that if the guilty had any spark of wisdom, and in any measure knew that they might make amends for their crimes by punishment, which came upon them here in this world, then they would not say that it was punishment, but would say that it was their purification and their amend­ ment;
tgt_text.2758: and would seek no advocate, but they would cheer­ fully suffer the magistrates to punish them according to their own will.
tgt_text.2759: Hence no wise man ought to hate any one.
tgt_text.2760: No one hates the good, except the most foolish of all.
tgt_text.2761: Nor is it right that we hate the wicked;
tgt_text.2762: but it is more right that we have mercy on him.
tgt_text.2763: This then is mercy to them, that we punish their vices according to their deservings.
tgt_text.2764: No, one ought to afflict a sick person who is troubled;
tgt_text.2765: but we should lead him to a physician, that he may cure him.
tgt_text.2766: When Wisdom had finished this discourse, then began he again to sing, and thus said:
tgt_text.2768: I. WHEREFORE vex ye your minds with evil hatred, as waves through the wind agitate the sea ?
tgt_text.2769: Or wherefore up­ braid ye your fortune, that she has no power?
tgt_text.2770: Or why cannot ye wait for natural death, when be every day hastens towards you ?
tgt_text.2771: Why cannot ye observe that lie seeks every day after birds, and after beasts, and after men, and forsakes no track till he seizes that which he pursues ?
tgt_text.2773: that unhappy men cannot wait till he comes to them, but antici­ pate him, as wild beasts wish to destroy each other!
tgt_text.2774: But it would not be right in men, that anyone of them should hate another.
tgt_text.2775: But this would be right, that every one of them should render to another recompense of every work accord­ ing to his deserts;
tgt_text.2776: that is, that one should love the good, as it is right that we should do, and should have mercy on the wicked, as we before said;
tgt_text.2777: should love the man, and hate his vices;
tgt_text.2778: and cut them off, as we best may.§ II.
tgt_text.2779: When he had sung this lay, then was he silent for some time.
tgt_text.2781: Now I clearly understand that true happiness is founded on the deservings of good men, and misery is founded on the deservings of wicked men.
tgt_text.2782: But I will yet say that methinks the happiness of this present life is no little good, and its unhappiness no little evil.
tgt_text.2783: For I never saw nor heard of any wise man who would rather be an exile, and miserable, and foreign, and despised, than wealthy, and honour­ able, and powerful, and eminent in his own country.
tgt_text.2784: For they say that they can the better fulfil their wisdom, and observe it, if their power be ample over the people that are under them, and also in some measure over those who are in the neigh­ bourhood round about them, because they are able to repress the wicked, and promote the good.
tgt_text.2785: For the good is always to be honoured, both in this present life and in that to come ;
tgt_text.2786: and the wicked, whom man cannot restrain from his evil, is always deserving of punishment, both in this world and in that to come.
tgt_text.2787: But I very much wonder why it should so fall out, as it now often does;
tgt_text.2788: that is, that various punishments and manifold misfortunes come to the good, as they should to the wicked;
tgt_text.2789: and the blessings which should be a reward to good men for good works, come to wicked men.
tgt_text.2790: Therefore I would now know from thee, how that course of events were approved by thee.
tgt_text.2791: I should wonder at it much less, if I knew that it happened by chance, without God's will, and without his knowledge.
tgt_text.2792: But the Almighty God has increased my fear and my astonishment by these things.
tgt_text.2793: For he some­ times gives felicities to the good, and infelicities to the wicked, as it were right that he always did.
tgt_text.2794: Sometimes again he per­ mits that the good have infelicities and misfortunes in many things;
tgt_text.2795: and the wicked have happiness, and it frequently happens to them according to their own desire.
tgt_text.2796: Hence I cannot think otherwise but that it so happens by chance, un­ less thou still more rationally show me the contrary.
tgt_text.2797: Then answered he, after a long time, and said:
tgt_text.2798: It is no wonder if any one think that something of this kind happens unde­ signedly, when he cannot understand and explain wherefore God so permits.
tgt_text.2799: But thou oughtest not to doubt that so good a creator and governor of all things, rightly made all that he has made, and rightly judges and rules it all, though thou knowest not why he so and so may do.§ III.
tgt_text.2800: When he had made this speech, then began he to sing, and said:
tgt_text.2801: Who of the unlearned wonders not at the course of the sky, and its swiftness;
tgt_text.2802: how it every day re­ volves about all this middle-earth ?
tgt_text.2803: Or who wonders not that some stars have a shorter circuit than others have, as the stars have which we call the waggon's shafts ?
tgt_text.2804: They have so short a circuit, because they are so near the north end of the axis, on which all the sky turns.
tgt_text.2805: Or who is not astonished at this, except those only who know it, that some stars have a longer circuit than others have, and those the longest which revolve midward about the axis, as Bootes does ?
tgt_text.2806: And that the star Saturn does not come where it before was till about thirty winters ?
tgt_text.2807: Or who wonders not at this, that same stars depart under the sea, as some men think the sun does when she sets ?
tgt_text.2808: But she nevertheless is not nearer to the sea than she is at mid-day!
tgt_text.2809: Who is not astonished when the full moon is covered over with darkness ?
tgt_text.2810: or again, that the stars shine before the moon, and do not shine before the sun ?
tgt_text.2811: At this and many a like thing they wonder, and wonder not that men and all living creatures have continual and useless enmity with each other.
tgt_text.2812: Or why wonder they not at this, that it sometimes thunders, and sometimes begins not?
tgt_text.2813: Or, again, at the strife of sea and winds, and waves and land ?
tgt_text.2814: or why ice is formed, and again by the shining of the sun returns to its own nature ?
tgt_text.2815: But the inconstant people wonder at that which it most seldom sees, though it be less wonderful;
tgt_text.2816: and thinks that that is not the old creation, but has by chance newly happened.
tgt_text.2817: But they who are very inquisitive and en­ deavour to learn, if God removes from their mind the folly with which it was before covered, then will they not wonder at many things which they now wonder at.
tgt_text.2819: When Wisdom had sung this lay, then was he silent a little while.
tgt_text.2821: So it is as thou sayest.
tgt_text.2822: But I am still desirous that thou wouldest instruct me somewhat more distinctly concerning the thing which has chiefly troubled my mind, that is, what I before asked thee.
tgt_text.2823: For it was always hitherto thy wont that thou wouldest teach every mind ab­ struse and unknown things.
tgt_text.2824: Then began he to smile, and said to me:
tgt_text.2825: Thou urgest me to the greatest argument, and the most difficult to explain.
tgt_text.2826: This explanation all philoso­ phers have sought, and very diligently laboured about, and scarcely any one has come to the end of the discussion.
tgt_text.2827: For it is the nature of the discussion and of the inquiry, that always when there is one doubt removed, then is there an innumerable multitude raised.
tgt_text.2828: So men in old tales say, that there was a serpent which had nine heads, and whenever any one of them was cut off, then grew there seven from that one head.
tgt_text.2829: Then happened it that the celebrated Hercules came there, who was the son of Jove.
tgt_text.2830: Then could not he imagine how he by any art might overcome them, until he surrounded them with wood, and then burned them with fire.
tgt_text.2831: So is this argument which thou askest about:
tgt_text.2832: with difficulty comes any man out of it, if he enter into it.
tgt_text.2833: He never comes to a clear end, unless he have an understanding as sharp as the fire.
tgt_text.2834: For be who will inquire concerning this ought first to know what the simple providence of God is, and what fate is, and what happens by chance, and what the divine knowledge is, and the divine predestination, and what the freedom of men is.
tgt_text.2835: Now thou mayest perceive how weighty and difficult all this is to explain.
tgt_text.2836: But I will nevertheless endeavour to teach thee a little of it, because I have conceived it to be a very powerful remedy for thy sorrow, if thou learn something of this, though it be long for me to teach.
tgt_text.2837: For it is near the time when I had intended to begin other work, and I have not yet finished this:
tgt_text.2838: and methinks, too, thou art rather weary, and these long discourses appear to thee too lengthy, so that thou art now desirous of my songs.
tgt_text.2839: I know, too, that they give thee pleasure.
tgt_text.2840: But thou must nevertheless bear with me for some time.
tgt_text.2841: I cannot so readily sing it, nor have I leisure, for it is a very long argument.
tgt_text.2843: Do as thou wilt.§ V. Then began he to speak very far about, as if he intended not that discourse, and nevertheless approached thitherward, and said:
tgt_text.2844: All creatures visible and invisible, still and moving, receive from the immovable, and from the steadfast, and from the singly-existing God, order, and form, andmeasure;
tgt_text.2845: and therefore it was so ordained, because he knew wherefore he made all that be made.
tgt_text.2846: Nothing of that which he has created is useless to him.
tgt_text.2847: God dwells always in the high city of his unity and simplicity.
tgt_text.2848: Thence he dis­ tributes many and various measures to all his creatures, and thence he governs them all.
tgt_text.2849: But that which we call God's providence and foreknowledge, is suchwhile it is with him, in his mind, before it is fulfilled,[ and so long as it is designed;
tgt_text.2850: but after it is fulfilled, then we call it fate.]
tgt_text.2851: Hence may every man know that these are both two names, and two things, providence and fate.
tgt_text.2852: Providence is the divine intelligence which is fixed in the high Creator, who foreknows all, how it shall come to pass, before it happens.
tgt_text.2853: But that which we call fate, is God's work which he every day works, both what we see, and what is invisible to us.
tgt_text.2854: But the divine provi­ dence restrains all creatures, so that they cannot slip from their order.
tgt_text.2855: Fate, then, distributes to all creatures, forms, and places, and times, and measures.
tgt_text.2856: But fate comes from the mind, and from the providence of Almighty God.
tgt_text.2857: He, therefore, works after his unspeakable providence, whatsoever he wills.§
tgt_text.2859: As every artificer considers and marks out his work in his mind before be executes it, and afterwards executes it all;
tgt_text.2860: this varying fortune which we call fate, proceeds after his providence and after his counsel, as he intends that it should be.
tgt_text.2861: Though it appear to us complicated, partly good, and partly evil, it is nevertheless to him singly good, because he brings it all to a good end, and does for good all that which he does.
tgt_text.2862: (Afterwards, when it is wrought, we call it fate;
tgt_text.2863: before, it was God's providence, and his predestination
tgt_text.2864: He therefore directs fortune, either through good angels, or througt the souls of men, or through the life of other creatures, or through the stars of heaven, or through the various deceits of devils;
tgt_text.2865: sometimes through one of them, sometimes through them all.
tgt_text.2866: But this is evidently known, that the divine predestination is simple and unchangeable, and governs everything according to order, and fashions everything.
tgt_text.2867: Some things, therefore, in this world are sub­ ject to fate others are not at all subject to it.
tgt_text.2868: But fate, and all the thirigs which are subject to it, are subject to the divine providence.
tgt_text.2869: Concerning this, I can mention to thee an example, whereby thou mayest the more clearly under­ stand which men are subject to fate, and which are not.
tgt_text.2870: All this moving and this changeable creation revolves on the immovable, and on the steadfast, and on the singly-existing God;
tgt_text.2871: and he governs all creatures as he at the beginning had, and still has determined.§
tgt_text.2873: As on the axle-tree of a waggon the wheel turns, and the axle-tree stands still, and nevertheless supports all the waggon, and regulates all its progress-the wheel turns round, and the nave, being nearest to the axle-tree, goes much more firmly and more securely than the fellies do—so the axle-tree may be the highest good which we call God, and the best men go nearest to God, as the nave goes nearest to the axle-tree;
tgt_text.2874: and the middle class of men as the spokes.
tgt_text.2875: For of every spoke, one end is fixed in the nave, and the other in the felly.
tgt_text.2876: So is it with respect to the middle class of men.
tgt_text.2877: One while he meditates in his mind concerning this earthly life, another while concerning the heavenly:
tgt_text.2878: as if he should look with one eye to the heavens, and with the other to the earth.
tgt_text.2879: As the spokes stick, one end in the icily, and the other in the nave, and the spoke is midward, equally near to both, though one end be fixed in the nave, and the other in the felly;
tgt_text.2880: so are the middle class of men in the middle of the spokes, and the better nearer to the nave, and the most numerous class nearer to the fellies.
tgt_text.2881: They are nevertheless fixed in the nave, and the nave on the axle-tree.
tgt_text.2882: But the fellies depend on the spokes, though they wholly roll upon the earth.
tgt_text.2883: So do the most numerous class of men depend on the middle class, and the middle class on the best, and the best on God.
tgt_text.2884: Though the most numerous class turn all their love towards this world, they are not able to dwell there, nor do they come to anything, if they are not in some measure fastened to God, any more than the fellies of the wheel can make any progress if they are not fastened to the spokes, and the spokes to the axle-tree.
tgt_text.2885: The fellies are farthest from the axle-tree, therefore they go the most roughly.
tgt_text.2886: The nave goes nearest the axle-tree, therefore it goes the most securely.
tgt_text.2888: As they place their love nearer to God, and more despise these earthly things, so are they more free from care, and areless anxious how fortune may vary, or what it maybring.
tgt_text.2889: Provided the navebe always thus secure, the fellies may rest on what they will.
tgt_text.2890: And yet the nave is in some measure separated from the axle-tree.
tgt_text.2891: As thou mayest perceive that the waggon is much longer secure, which is less separated from the axle-tree;
tgt_text.2892: so, of all men, those are most untroubled, with the difficulties either of this present life, or of that to come, who are fixed in God;
tgt_text.2893: but as they are farther separated from God, so are they more troubled and afflicted both in mind and in body.
tgt_text.2894: Such is what we call fate....§ VIII....
tgt_text.2895: With respect to the divine providence;
tgt_text.2896: as argument and reasoning is, compared with the intellect, and such the wheel is, compared with the axle-tree.
tgt_text.2897: For the axle-tree regulates all the waggon.
tgt_text.2898: In like manner does the divine providence.
tgt_text.2899: It moves the sky and the stars, and makes the earth immovable, and regulates the four elements, that is, water, and earth, and fire, and air.
tgt_text.2900: These it tempers and forms, and sometimes again changes their appearance, and brings them to another form, and afterwards renews them:
tgt_text.2901: and nourishes every production, and again hides and preserves it when it is grown old and withered, and again discovers and renews it whensoever he wills.
tgt_text.2902: Some philosophers how­ ever say, that fate rules both the felicities and the infelicities of every man.
tgt_text.2903: But I say, as all Christian men say, that the divine predestination rules ove him, not fate.
tgt_text.2904: And I Know that it decrees everything very rightly;
tgt_text.2905: though to unwise men it does not appear so.
tgt_text.2906: They think that everything which fulfils their desire, is God.
tgt_text.2907: It is no wonder, for they are blinded by the darkness of their sins.
tgt_text.2908: But the divine provi­ dence understands everything very rightly, though it seems to us, through our folly, that it goes wrongly;
tgt_text.2909: because we cannot perfectly understand it.
tgt_text.2910: He, however, ordains all very rightly, though to us it sometimes does not appear so.§ IX.
tgt_text.2911: All men, the good as well as the wicked, seek after the highest good.
tgt_text.2912: But the wicked are unable to come to the high roof of all goods for this reason, that they do not seek after it rightly.
tgt_text.2913: I know, however, that thou wilt on some occasion say to me, What injustice can be greater, than that he should permit it to come to pass, as it sometimes does, that to the good unmixed evil happens in this world, and to the wicked unmixed good;
tgt_text.2914: and at other times both mixed, as well to the good as to the wicked ?
tgt_text.2915: But I ask thee whether thou thinkest that any man is so discerning, that he is able to know every one aright, what he is, so that he may be neither better nor worse than he thinks him ?
tgt_text.2916: I know, however, that they cannot.
tgt_text.2917: Yet it is very often improperly the custom for some persons to say that a man is deserving of reward, while others say that he is deserving of punishment.
tgt_text.2918: Though any one may observe what another does, he cannot know what he thinks.
tgt_text.2919: Though he may know some part of his disposition, yet he cannot know it all.
tgt_text.2920: I can moreover relate to thee an example, whereby thou mayest more clearly understand this, though un­ wise men cannot understand it.
tgt_text.2922: Why does the good physician give to this healthy man mild and sweet drink, and to another healthy man bitter and strong ?
tgt_text.2923: And sometimes also to the sick;
tgt_text.2928: I know that every person who is unacquainted with the art will wonder at it, why they do so.
tgt_text.2929: But the physicians wonder not at it, because they know what the others are ignorant of.
tgt_text.2930: For they know how to discover and distinguish the infirmity of each -of them;
tgt_text.2931: and also the arts which should be used with respect to it.
tgt_text.2932: What is the health of souls, but virtue ?
tgt_text.2933: or what is their infirmity, but vices ?
tgt_text.2934: Who then is a better physician of the soul, than he who made it, that is, God ?
tgt_text.2935: He honours the good, and punishes the wicked.
tgt_text.2936: He knows what each is deserving of.
tgt_text.2937: It is no wonder, because he from the high roof sees it all;
tgt_text.2938: and thence disposes and metes to each according to his deserts.§
tgt_text.2939: X. This then we call fate;
tgt_text.2940: when the wise God, who knows every man's necessity, does or permits anything which we ex­ pect Dot.
tgt_text.2941: And yet I may give thee some examples, in few words, so far as human reason is able to understand the divine nature.
tgt_text.2942: That is, then, that we sometimes know man in one wise, and God knows him in another.
tgt_text.2943: Sometimes we judge that he is the best, and then God knows that it is not so.
tgt_text.2944: When anything comes to any person, either of good or of evil, more than it appears to thee that he deserves, the in­ justice is not in God, but the want of skill is in thyself, that thou canst not rightly understand it.
tgt_text.2945: Yet it often happens that men know a man in the same manner that God knows him.
tgt_text.2946: It often happens that many men are so infirm, both in mind and in body, that they cannot of their own accord do any good, or avoid any evil;
tgt_text.2947: and are, moreover, so impatient, that they cannot with resignation bear any troubles.
tgt_text.2948: There­ fore it often happens that God, through his mercy, wills not to impose on them any intolerable affliction, lest they should forsake their innocence, and become worse, if they are moved and troubled.
tgt_text.2949: Some men are full virtuous in all virtue, and full holy and righteous men.
tgt_text.2950: Then seems it to God unjust that he should afflict such;
tgt_text.2951: and moreover death, which is natural to all men to suffer, he makes more tranquil to them than to other men :
tgt_text.2952: as formerly a certain wise man said, that the divine power saved his darlings under the shadow of his wings, and protected them as carefully as man does the apple of his eye.
tgt_text.2953: Many so earnestly endeavour to please God, that they desire of their own accord to suffer manifold troubles ;
tgt_text.2954: because they desire to have greater honour, and greater fame, and greater dignity with God, than those have who live more pleasantly.
tgt_text.2956: Frequently also the power of this world comes to very good men, in order that the power of the wicked maybe overthrown.
tgt_text.2957: To some men God gives both good and evil mixed, because they earn both.
tgt_text.2958: Some he bereaves of their wealth very soon, when they first are happy, lest through long felicities they should too much exalt themselves, and thence become proud.
tgt_text.2959: He permits some to be vexed with severe trouble, that they may learn the virtue of patience by the long affliction.
tgt_text.2960: Some fear difficulties more than they need, though they may easily bear them.
tgt_text.2961: Some purchase the honourable fame of this present life by their own death;
tgt_text.2962: because they think that they have no other price worthy of this fame, except their own life.
tgt_text.2963: Some men were formerly unconquerable, so that no one could overcome them with any torment.
tgt_text.2964: These set an example to their successors that they should not be overcome by torments.
tgt_text.2965: In these it was evident that they, for their good works, had the strength that man might not overcome them.
tgt_text.2966: But the wicked, for their evil works, have been punished beyond measure, in order that the punishments might restrain others from daring to do so, and also might amend those whom they then afflict.
tgt_text.2967: It is a very clear token to the wise, that he ought not to love these worldly goods immoderately, because they often come to the worst men.
tgt_text.2968: But what shall we say concerning the present wealth which often comes to the good ?
tgt_text.2969: What is it else but a token of the future wealth, and a beginning of the reward which God has decreed to him for his good disposition ?
tgt_text.2970: I suppose also that God gives felicities to many wicked men because he knows their nature and their disposition to be such, that they would not for any troubles be the better, but the worse.
tgt_text.2971: But the good physician, that is God, heals their minds with the wealth, until they learn whence the wealth came to them, and the man submits to him lest he take away the wealth from him, or him from the wealth, and turns his manners to good, and forsakes the vices and the evil which he before through his poverty did.
tgt_text.2972: Some indeed are the worse if they have wealth, because they become proud ou account of the wealth, and enjoy it without moderation.§ XII.
tgt_text.2973: To many men also these worldly felicities are there­ fore given, that they may recompeuse the good for their good, and the wicked for their evil.
tgt_text.2974: For the good and the wicked are ever at variance with each other, and also sometimes the wicked are at variance between themselves, and moreover a wicked man is sometimes at variance with himself.
tgt_text.2975: For he knows that he does amiss, and bethinks himself of the retribu- tion, and yet will not cease therefrom, nor indeed suffer him­ self to repent of it;
tgt_text.2976: and therefore through Perpetual fear he cannot be at peace with himself.
tgt_text.2977: Frequently it also happens that the wicked forsakes his evil for hatred of some other wicked man;
tgt_text.2978: because he would thereby upbraid the other, by avoiding his manners.
tgt_text.2979: He labours then about this as he best may ;
tgt_text.2980: that is, he takes care to be unlike the other;
tgt_text.2981: for it is the custom of the divine power to work good from evil.
tgt_text.2982: But it is permitted to no man that he should be able to know all that God has decreed, or indeed to recount that which he has wrought.
tgt_text.2983: But in these things they have enough, to un­ derstand that the creator and the governor of all things, guides, and rightly made all that he made, and has not wrought, nor yet works any evil, but drives away every evil from all his realm.
tgt_text.2984: But if thou wilt inquire concerning the supreme government of the Almighty God,then wilt thou not perceive evil in anything, though it now seem to thee that here is much in this middle-earth.
tgt_text.2985: Since it is just that the good have good reward for their good, and the wicked have punishment for their evil;
tgt_text.2986: that is no evil which is just, but is good.
tgt_text.2987: But I perceive that I have wearied thee with this long discourse, wherefore thou art now desirous of songs.
tgt_text.2988: And now accept them, for it is the medicine and the drink which thou hast long wished for, that thou mayest more easily receive the instruction.§
tgt_text.2990: When Wisdom had ended this speech, then began he again to sing, and thus said:
tgt_text.2991: If thou desirest with pure mind to understand the supreme government, behold the stars of the high heaven.
tgt_text.2992: The heavenly bodies preserve the ancient peace in which they were created;
tgt_text.2993: so that the fiery sun does not touch that part of the heaven in which the moon moves;
tgt_text.2994: nor does the moon touch that part in which the sun moves, so long as she is therein.
tgt_text.2995: Nor does the star which we call Ursa ever come into the west, though all other stars go with the sky after the sun to the earth.
tgt_text.2996: It is no wonder, for it is very near to the upper end of the axis.
tgt_text.2997: But the star which we call the evening star, when it is seen westwardly, then betokens it the evening.
tgt_text.2998: It then goes after the sua into the earth's shade, till it runs off behind the sun, and comes up before the sun.
tgt_text.2999: Then we call it the morning star, because it comes up in the east, and announces the sun's ap­ proach.
tgt_text.3000: The sun and the moon have divided the day and the night very equally between them;
tgt_text.3001: and they reign very harmo­ niously through divine providence, and unceasingly serve the Almighty God till doomsday, God does not suffer them to be on one side of the heaven, lest they should destroy other creatures.
tgt_text.3002: But the peace-loving God regulates and adapts all creatures, when they exist together.
tgt_text.3003: Sometimes the wet flies the dry.
tgt_text.3004: Sometimes he mingles the fire with the cold.
tgt_text.3005: Sometimes the light and bright fire goes upwards, and the heavy earth is stationed beneath by the king's commaud.
tgt_text.3006: The earth brings yearly every fruit, and every production;
tgt_text.3007: and the hot summer dries and prepares seeds and fruits;
tgt_text.3008: and the fruitful harvest brings ripe corn.
tgt_text.3009: Hails, and snows, and frequent rain moisten the earth in winter.
tgt_text.3010: Hence the earth receives the seed, and causes it to grow in spring.
tgt_text.3011: But the creator of all things nourishes in the earth all growing fruits, and produces them all;
tgt_text.3012: and hides when he will, and shows when he will, and takes away when he will.
tgt_text.3013: While the creatures obey, the supreme creator sits on his throne.
tgt_text.3014: Thence he guides with reins all creatures.
tgt_text.3016: for he is king, and lord, and fountain, and origin, and law, and wisdom, and righteous judge.
tgt_text.3017: He sends all creatures on his errands, and be commands them all to come again.
tgt_text.3018: If the only steadfast king did not support all creatures, then would they all be dissolved and dispersed;
tgt_text.3019: and all creatures would come to nought.
tgt_text.3020: But they have in common one love in serving such a lord, and rejoice because he rules over them.
tgt_text.3021: That is no wonder, for they could not else exist, if they served not their author.
tgt_text.3022: Then ceased Wisdom the song, and said to me:
tgt_text.3023: § I. DOST thou now perceive whither this discourse tends ?
tgt_text.3027: I would say, that every fortune is good, whether it seem good to men, or whether it seem evil to them.
tgt_text.3029: I think that it perhaps may be so, though it sometimes ap­ pears otherwise to us.
tgt_text.3031: There is no doubt of this, that every fortune which is just and useful, is good:
tgt_text.3032: for every fortune, whether it be pleasant, or whether it be unpleasant, comes to the good for this reason, that it may do one of two things;
tgt_text.3033: that it may either admonish him, in order that he should do better than he did before;
tgt_text.3034: or reward him, because he before did well.
tgt_text.3035: And again, every fortune which comes to the wicked, comes on account of two things, whether it be severe or whether it be pleasant.
tgt_text.3036: If severe fortune come to the wicked, then it comes for retribution of his evil, or else for correction and for admonition, that he should not do so again.
tgt_text.3037: Then began I to wonder, and said :
tgt_text.3038: This is a thoroughly right explanation which thou givest.
tgt_text.3041: But I am desirous, if thou art willing, that we should turn ourselves a little while to this people's speech, lest they say that we speak above man's comprehension.
tgt_text.3045: Dost thou think that that is not good which is useful ?
tgt_text.3049: Every fortune is useful which does either of two things;
tgt_text.3054: Adverse fortune is good for those who contend against vices, and are inclined to good.
tgt_text.3058: What thinkest thou con­ cerning the good fortune, which often comes to good men in this world, as if it were a foretoken of eternal blessings ?
tgt_text.3059: Can this people say that it is evil fortune ?
tgt_text.3061: No man says that, but every one says that it is very good, as it moreover is.
tgt_text.3063: What thinkest thou of the more invisible fortune which often threatens to punish the wicked ?
tgt_text.3064: Does this people think that this is good fortune ?
tgt_text.3066: They do not think that this is good fortune, but think that it is very miserable.
tgt_text.3068: Let us beware that we think not as this people think.
tgt_text.3069: If we in this respect think what this people think, then shall we forsake all wisdom, and all righteousness.
tgt_text.3071: Why shall we ever the more forsake them ?
tgt_text.3073: Be- cause vulgar men say that every severe and unpleasant for­ tune is evil.
tgt_text.3074: But we should not believe it, since every fortune is good, as we before said, whether it be severe, or whether it be pleasaut.
tgt_text.3075: Then was I afraid, and said:
tgt_text.3076: That is true which thou sayest.
tgt_text.3077: I know not, however, who dares to mention it to foolish men, for no foolish man can believe it.§ III.
tgt_text.3078: Then replied Wisdom sharply, and said:
tgt_text.3079: Therefore no wise man ought to fear or lament, in whatever wise it may happen to him, or whether severe fortune or agreeable may come to him;
tgt_text.3080: any more than the brave man ought to lament about this, how often he must fight.
tgt_text.3081: His praise is not the less;
tgt_text.3082: but the opinion is, that it is the greater.
tgt_text.3083: So is also the wise man's reward the greater, if more adverse, and severer fortune comes to him.
tgt_text.3084: Therefore no wise man should be desirous of a soft life, if he makes account of any virtues, or any honour here in the world, or of eternal life after this world.
tgt_text.3085: But every wise man ought to contend, both against the severe fortune, and against the pleasant, lest he through the pleasant fortune should be presumptuous, or through the severe, despair.
tgt_text.3086: But it is necessary for him that he seek the.
tgt_text.3087: middle-way, between the severe fortune and the agreeable:
tgt_text.3088: that he may not desire more agreeable fortune, or greater security than is fit:
tgt_text.3090: because be is unable to bear excess of either.
tgt_text.3091: But it is in their nwn power, which of them they will choose.
tgt_text.3092: therefore, they desire to find the middle-way, theu ought they themselves to moderate to themselves the pleasant and the prosperous for­ tune.
tgt_text.3093: Then will God moderate to them the severe fortune;
tgt_text.3094: both in this world, and in that to come, so that they may easily bear it.
tgt_text.3098: Proceed ye all in the way which the illustrious examples of the good men, and of the men desirous of honour, who were'before you, point out to you.
tgt_text.3100: why are ye so useless, and so enervated ?
tgt_text.3101: Why will ye not inquire about the wise men, and about the men desirous of honour, what they were who were before you ?
tgt_text.3102: And why will ye not then, after ye have found out their manners, imitate them, as ye best may ?
tgt_text.3103: For they strove after honour in this world, and sought good fame by good works, and set a good example to those who should be after them.
tgt_text.3104: Therefore they now dwell above the stars, iu everlasting happiness, for their good works.
tgt_text.3105: Here ends the fourth book of Boethius, and begins the fifth.§ V. When Wisdom had ended this discourse, then said I:
tgt_text.3107: But I would now remind thee of the manifold instruction which thou before promisedst me, concerning the predestination of God.
tgt_text.3108: But I wish first to know from thee whether that be aught which we often hear, that men say concerning some things, that it will happen by chance.
tgt_text.3110: I would rather that I hastened towards this, that I might perform to thee what I before promised thee, and might teach thee as short a way, as I shortest might find, to thy native country. *
tgt_text.3111: But this is so far out of our way, out of the way which we intended to travel, that it would be more expedient to return, and un­ derstand what thou before askedst me.
tgt_text.3112: But I also fear that I should lead thee hither and thither in paths out of thy way, so that thou mightest not again find thy way.
tgt_text.3113: It is no wonder if thou shouldest grow weary, if I lead thee beside the way.
tgt_text.3116: but I shall be very glad if thou leadest me whither I desire thee.
tgt_text.3118: I will instruct thee by discourses, as I always did :
tgt_text.3119: and will say to thee, that it is naught that men say, that anything may happen by chauce.
tgt_text.3120: Because everything comes from certain things, therefore it has not happened by chance:
tgt_text.3121: but if it had come from nothing, then it would have happened by chance.§ VI.
tgt_text.3123: But whence came the name first?
tgt_text.3125: My beloved Aristotle has explained it in the book called Physica.
tgt_text.3129: Men said formerly, when anything happened to them unexpectedly, that it happened by chance:
tgt_text.3130: as if any one should dig the earth, and find there a hoard of gold, and then say, that it had happened by chance.
tgt_text.3131: I know, however, that if the digger had not dug the earth, or man had not before hid the gold there, then:
tgt_text.3132: he would not have found it.
tgt_text.3133: Therefore it was not found by chance.
tgt_text.3134: But the divine pre­ destination instructed whom he would that he should hide the gold, and afterwards whom he would, that he should find it.
tgt_text.3137: I perceive that this is as thou sayest:
tgt_text.3138: but I would ask thee whether we have any freedom, or any power, what we may do, and what we may not do ?
tgt_text.3139: or whether the divine predestination, or fate, compels us to what they will ?
tgt_text.3142: There is no rational creature which has not freedom.
tgt_text.3143: Whosoever has reason, is able to judge and discern what he ought to desire, and what he ought to shun.
tgt_text.3144: And every man has this freedom, that he knows what he wills, andwhat he wills not.
tgt_text.3145: And yet all rational creatures have not equal freedom.
tgt_text.3146: Angels have right judgments and good will;
tgt_text.3147: and whatever they desire they very easily obtain, because they desire nothing wrong.
tgt_text.3148: There is no created being which has freedom and reason except angels and men.
tgt_text.3150: the more as they lead their mind nearer to divine things;
tgt_text.3151: and they have so much the less freedom,as they lead the willof their miud nearer to this worldly honour.
tgt_text.3152: They have not any freedom when they, of their own accord, subject themselves to vices.
tgt_text.3153: Butas soon as they turn awaytheirmindfrom good, so soon they -become blind with folly.
tgt_text.3154: But one Almighty God exists in his high city, who sees every man's thought, and discerns his words and his deeds, and renders to every one according to his works.
tgt_text.3155: When Wisdom had made this speech, then began he to sing, and thus said:
tgt_text.3157: Homer the good poet, who with the Greeks was the best, he was Virgil's master;
tgt_text.3158: Virgil was with the Latin men the best, though Homer in his poems greatly praised the nature of the sun, and her excellences, and her brightness ;
tgt_text.3159: yet she cannot shine upon all creatures, nor those creatures which she may shine upon, can she shiue upon all equally, nor shine through them all within.
tgt_text.3160: But it is not so with the Almighty God, who is the maker of all creatures.
tgt_text.3161: He beholds and sees through all his creatures equally.
tgt_text.3162: Him we may call, without falsehood, the true sun.§ II.
tgt_text.3163: When Wisdom bad sung this lay, then was he silent a little while.
tgt_text.3165: A certain doubt has much troubled me.
tgt_text.3169: It isthis, that thou sayest that God gives to every one freedom as well to do good as evil, whichsoever he will:
tgt_text.3170: and thou sayest also that God knows everything before it comes to pass ;
tgt_text.3171: and thou sayest also, that nothing comes to pass unless God wills and permits it:
tgt_text.3172: and thou sayest that it must all proceed as he has ordained.
tgt_text.3173: Now I wonder at this, why he permits that wicked men have the freedom that they may do either good or evil, whichsoever they will, since he before knows that they will do evil.
tgt_text.3175: I can very easily answer thee this inquiry.
tgt_text.3176: How would it please thee, if there were some very powerful king, and he had not any free man in all his realm, but all were slaves ?
tgt_text.3178: I should not think it at all right, or moreover suitable, if men in a state of slavery should serve him.
tgt_text.3180: How much more unnatural would it be, if God had not in all his kingdom any free creature under his power?
tgt_text.3181: Therefore he created two rational creatures free, angels and men.
tgt_text.3182: To these he gave the great gift of freedom, that they might do either good or evil, whichsoever they would.
tgt_text.3183: He gave a very sure gift, and a very sure law with the gift, to every man until his end.
tgt_text.3184: That is the freedom, that man may do what he will;
tgt_text.3185: and that is the law, which renders to every man according to his works, both in this world, and in that to come, good or evil, whichsoever he does.
tgt_text.3186: And men may attain through this freedom whatsoever they will, except that they cannot avoid death.
tgt_text.3187: But they may by good works delay it, so that it may come later:
tgt_text.3188: and more­ over, they may sometimes defer it till old age, if they do not cease to have good will to good works, that is, good.
tgt_text.3190: Well hast thou set me right in the doubt, and in the trouble wherein I before was concerning freedom.
tgt_text.3191: But I am still disquieted with much more trouble, almost to despair.
tgt_text.3195: It is concerning the predestination of God.
tgt_text.3196: For we sometimes hear say, that everything must so come to pass as God at the beginning had decreed, and that no man can alter it.
tgt_text.3197: Now methinks that he does wrong, when he honours the good, and also when he punishes the wicked, if it is true that it was so ordained to them that they could not do otherwise.
tgt_text.3198: In vain we labour when we pray, and when we fast, or give alms, if we have not therefore more favour than those who in all things walk according to their own will, and run after their bodily lust.§ III.
tgt_text.3200: This is the old complaint, which thou hast long bewailed, and many also before thee:
tgt_text.3201: one of whom was a certain Marcus, by another name Tullius;
tgt_text.3202: by a third name he was called Cicero, who was a consul of the Romans.
tgt_text.3204: He was very much occupied with this same question:
tgt_text.3205: but he could not bring it to any end at that time, because their mind was occupied with the desires of this world.
tgt_text.3206: But I say to thee, if that is true which ye say, it was a vain command in divine books, which God commanded, that man should forsake evil and do good;
tgt_text.3207: and again the saying which he said, that as man labours more, so shall he receive greater reward.
tgt_text.3208: And I wonder why thou shouldest have for­ gotten all that we before mentioned.
tgt_text.3209: We before said that the divine predestination wrought all good, and no evil:
tgt_text.3210: nor de­ creed to work, nor ever wrought any.
tgt_text.3211: Moreover, we proved that to be good which to vulgar men seemed evil:
tgt_text.3212: that is, that man should afflict or punish any one for his evil.
tgt_text.3213: Did we not also say in this same book, that God had decreed to give freedom to men, and so did;
tgt_text.3214: and if they exercised the freedom well, that he would greatly honour them with eternal power;
tgt_text.3215: and if they abused the freedom, that lie would then punish them with death ?
tgt_text.3216: He ordained that if they at all sinned through the freedom, they afterwards through the freedom should make amends for it by repentance;
tgt_text.3217: and that if any of them were so hard-hearted that he did not repent, he should have just punishment.
tgt_text.3218: All creatures he bad made servile except angels and meu.
tgt_text.3219: Because the other creatures are servile, they perform their services till doomsday.
tgt_text.3220: But men and angels, who are free, forsake their services.
tgt_text.3221: How can men say that the divine predestination had decreed what it fulfils not ?
tgt_text.3222: Or how can they excuse themselves that they should not do good, when it is written that God will requite every man according to his works ?
tgt_text.3223: Wherefore, then, should any man be idle, that he work not?
tgt_text.3225: Thou hast sufficiently relieved me from the doubting of my mind by the questions which I have asked thee.
tgt_text.3226: But I would still ask thee a question, which I am perplexed about.
tgt_text.3230: I am well aware that God knows everything beforehand, both good and evil, before it happens, but I know not whether it all shall unchangeably happen, which he knows and has decreed.
tgt_text.3232: It need not all happen unchangeably.
tgt_text.3233: But some of it shall happen unchangeably, that is, what shall be our necessity, and shall be his will.
tgt_text.3234: But some of-it is so arranged that it is not necessary, and yet hurts not if it happen ;
tgt_text.3235: nor is there any harm if itdo not happen.
tgt_text.3236: Consider now concerning thyself, whether thou hast so tirmly designed anything, that thou thinkest that it never with thy consent may be changed, nor thou exist without it.
tgt_text.3237: Or whether thou again in any design art so inconsistent, that it aids thee, whether it happen, or whether it happen not.
tgt_text.3238: Many a one is there of the things which God knows before it may happen, and knows also that it will hurt his creatures if it happen.
tgt_text.3239: He does not know it, because he wills that it should happen, but because he wills to provide that it may not happen.
tgt_text.3240: Thus a good pilot perceives a great storm of wind before it happens, aud gives order to furl the sail, and moreover sometimes to lower the mast, and let go the cable, if he first restrain the perverse wind, and so provides against the storm.
tgt_text.3243: Very well hast thou assisted me in this argument;
tgt_text.3244: and I wonder why so many wise men have so greatly laboured with this question, and found so little cer­ tain.
tgt_text.3246: What dost thou so greatly wonder at, so easy as it is to understand?
tgt_text.3247: Dost thou not know that many a thing is not understood according as it is, but ac­ cording to the measure of the understanding which inquires after it ?
tgt_text.3248: Such is wisdom, that no man in this world can com­ prehend it such as it is.
tgt_text.3249: But every one strives, according to the measure of his understanding, that he might comprehend it if he could.
tgt_text.3250: But wisdom is able to entirely comprehend us such as we are, though we cannot entirely comprehend it such as it is.
tgt_text.3252: He sees all our works, both good and evil, before they are done, or even thought of.
tgt_text.3253: But he does not compel us the more, so that we necessarily must do good, nor prevent us from doing evil;
tgt_text.3254: because he has given us freedom.
tgt_text.3255: I can also show thee some examples, whereby thou mayest more easily understand this discourse.
tgt_text.3256: Thou knowest that sight, and hearing, and feeling, perceive the body of a man, and yet they perceive it not alike.
tgt_text.3257: The ears perceive that which they hear, and yet they perceive not the body altogether such as it is.
tgt_text.3258: The feeling may touch it, and feel that it is a body, but cannot feel whether it be black or white, fair or not fair.
tgt_text.3259: But the sight in the first instance, as the eyes look thereon, perceives all the form of the body.
tgt_text.3260: But I would still give some explanation, that thou mayest understand that which thou wast wondering at.§ V. Then said I:
tgt_text.3263: It is that the same man perceives in separate ways what he perceives in others.
tgt_text.3264: He perceives it through the eyes separately;
tgt_text.3268: Many living creatures are unmoving, as, for instance, shell-fishes are, and have, nevertheless, some portion of sense, for they could not otherwise live, if they bad no particle of sense.
