tgt_text.3273: But the moving beasts are more like to men, because they have all which the unmoving have, and also more;
tgt_text.3274: that is, that they imitate men :
tgt_text.3275: love what they love, and hate what they hate;
tgt_text.3276: and fly from what they hate, and seek what they love.
tgt_text.3277: But men have all that we before mentioned, and also, in ad­ dition thereto, the great gift of reason.
tgt_text.3279: On this account are the creatures thus formed, that the unmoving may not exalt themselves above the moving, or strive with them:
tgt_text.3283: But it is wretched that the greatest part of men do not look on that which is given them, that is reason:
tgt_text.3284: nor regard that which is above them, that is, what angels and wise men have, namely, intelligence.
tgt_text.3285: But most men imitate cattle, inasmuch as they follow worldly lusts, like cattle.
tgt_text.3286: But if we had any portion of undoubting intelligence, as angels have, then might we perceive that that intelligence is much better than our reason.
tgt_text.3287: Though we contemplate many things, we have little understanding free from doubt
tgt_text.3288: But to the angels there is no doubt of any of the things which they know ;
tgt_text.3289: therefore is their understanding as much better than our reason, as our reason is better than the understanding of cattle is, or any portion of that intellect which is given them, either to prone cattle, or to those not prone.
tgt_text.3290: But let us now elevate our minds, as we highest may, towards the high roof of the supreme intelligence, that thou mayest most readily and most easily come to thine own country, whence thou before earnest.
tgt_text.3291: There may thy mind and thy reason see plainly that which it now doubts about in everything, both concerning the divine foreknowledge, which we have often discoursed about;
tgt_text.3295: When Wisdom had ended this speech, then began he to sing, and thus said:
tgt_text.3296: Thou mayest perceive that many an animal moves variously upon the earth, and they are of very dissimilar form, and go differently.
tgt_text.3297: Some lie with the whole body on the earth, and so go creeping, because neither feet nor wings support them:
tgt_text.3301: and all, nevertheless, are inclined downwards towards the earth, and then seek either what they list, or what is needful for them.
tgt_text.3302: But man alone goes up­ right.
tgt_text.3303: This betokens that he ought more to direct his thought upwards than downwards, lest the mind should be inferior to the body.
tgt_text.3304: When Wisdom had sung this lay, then said he:
tgt_text.3305: THEREFORE we ought with all our power to inquire con­ cerning God, that we may know what he is.
tgt_text.3306: Though it may not be our lot that we should know what he is, we ought nevertheless, according to the measure of understanding which he gives us, to strive after it:
tgt_text.3307: for, as we have already mentioned, man must know everything according to the measure of his understanding, since we are not able to know everything such as it is.
tgt_text.3308: Every creature, however, whether rational or irrational, testifies this, that God is eternal.
tgt_text.3309: For never would so many creatures, and so great and so fair, submit themselves to an inferior being, and to less power than they all are, nor indeed to equally great.
tgt_text.3313: Thou askest me about a great thing, and difficult to understand.
tgt_text.3314: If thou wouldest understand it, thou must first have the eyes of thy mind clean and clear.
tgt_text.3315: I cannot conceal from thee anything which I know.
tgt_text.3316: Knowest thou that there are three things in this middle-earth ?
tgt_text.3317: One is temporary, which has both beginning and end;
tgt_text.3318: and I nevertheless know nothing of that which is temporary, neither its beginning nor its end.
tgt_text.3319: Another thing is eternal, and has beginning, and has no end;
tgt_text.3320: and I know when it begins, and I know that it never will end:
tgt_text.3321: that is, angels and men's souls.
tgt_text.3322: The third thing is eternal, without end, and without beginning, that is, God.
tgt_text.3323: Among the three is a very great difference.
tgt_text.3324: If we should inquire into the whole of it, then should we come late to the end of this book, or never!
tgt_text.3325: But one thing thou must necessarily first know, why God is called the highest eternity.
tgt_text.3329: Because we know very little of that which was before us, except by memory, and by inquiry;
tgt_text.3330: and still less of that which shall be after us.
tgt_text.3331: That alone is truly present to us, which at the time is:
tgt_text.3332: but to him all is present, both what was before, and what now is, and what after us shall be;
tgt_text.3333: it is all present to him.
tgt_text.3334: His riches increase not, nor, moreover, do they ever diminish.
tgt_text.3335: He never recollects any­ thing, because he never forgets anything.
tgt_text.3336: He neither seeks nor inquires after anything, because he knows it all.
tgt_text.3337: He searches for nothing, because he has lost nothing.
tgt_text.3338: He pur­ sues not anything, because nothing can fly from him.
tgt_text.3339: He fears nothing, because he has none more powerful, nor indeed any like him.
tgt_text.3340: He is always giving, and nothing of his ever decreases.
tgt_text.3341: He is always Almighty, because he always wills good and never any evil.
tgt_text.3342: There is not need to him of any­ thing.
tgt_text.3343: He is always seeing, he never sleeps.
tgt_text.3345: He is always eternal, for the time never was when he was not, nor ever will be.
tgt_text.3347: nor is he compelled to any work.
tgt_text.3348: By his divine power he is everywhere present.
tgt_text.3349: His greatness no man can measure;
tgt_text.3350: yet this is not to be understood bodily, but spiritually, even as wisdom is, and righteousness, for he is that himself.
tgt_text.3351: But what are ye then proud of, or why lift ye up yourselves against so high power ?
tgt_text.3352: For ye can do nothing against him.
tgt_text.3353: For the Eternal and the Almighty always sits on the throne of his power.
tgt_text.3354: Thence he is able to see all, and renders to every one with justice, according to his works.
tgt_text.3355: Therefore it is not in vain that we have hope in God;
tgt_text.3356: for he changes not as we do.
tgt_text.3357: But pray ye to him humbly, for he is very bountiful and very merciful.
tgt_text.3358: Lift up your minds to him with your hands, and pray for that which is right, and is needful to you, for he will not refuse you.
tgt_text.3359: Hate, and fly from evil as ye best may.
tgt_text.3361: Ye have great need that ye always do well, for ye always in the presence of the Eternal and Almighty God do all that ye do.
tgt_text.3362: I He beholds it all, and he will recompense it all.
tgt_text.3363: AMEN0 Lord God Almighty, Creator and Ruler of all creatures, I beseech thee by thy great mercy, and by the sign of the holy cross, and by the virginity of Saint Mary, and by the obedience of Saint Michael, and by the love of all thy saints, and by their merits;
tgt_text.3364: that thou wouldest direct me better than I have done towards thee:
tgt_text.3365: and direct me to thy will, and to my soul's need, better than I myself know:
tgt_text.3366: and make steadfast my mind to thy will, and to my soul's need:
tgt_text.3367: and strengthen me against the temptations of the devil;
tgt_text.3368: and re­ move from me impure lust, and all unrighteousness;
tgt_text.3369: and defend me against mine enemies visible and invisible;
tgt_text.3370: and teach me to do thy will;
tgt_text.3371: that I may inwardly love thee before all things, with pure mind, and with pure body;
tgt_text.3372: for thou art my Creator, and my Redeemer, my Help, my Com­ fort, my Trust, and my Hope.
tgt_text.3373: To thee be praise, and glory now and for ever, world without end.

tgt_text.3375: —Although this preface is written in the third person, yet there is no doubt that Alfred himself was the writer, for he explains his method of translating, alludes to "the various and manifold occupations which often busied him both in mind and body," beseeches the reader to " pray for him, and not to blame him if he should more rightly understand it than he could;

tgt_text.3378: —The invasions of Radagaisus and Alaric took place early in the fifth century, and, after many years of desolating wars, Theodoric, an Ostrogoth, said to he the fourteenth in lineal descent of the royal line of Amala, acquired possession of Rome.
tgt_text.3379: Theodoric was a Christian, but had been educated in the tenets of Arins.
tgt_text.3380: For many years he gave the fullest toleration to the profession of the Catholic Faith, and went so far as to behead one of his officers for becoming an Arian, saying, " If thou couldst not continue true to thy God, how canst thou prove faithful to me who am but a man ?"
tgt_text.3381: At length, however, apprehending danger to his throne, and suspecting the Catholics to be in league with his enemies, he withheld the toleration he had granted, and became a persecutor of the orthodox faith.
tgt_text.3382: The oppressions which he beheld, roused the patriotism of Boethius, a noble Roman, distin­ guished for his many and varied accomplishments.
tgt_text.3383: He entered into a cor­ respondence with the Emperor Justin, at Constantinople, and this being discovered, Theodoric caused him to be imprisoned in Ticinum, and while there, he composed this treatise.

tgt_text.0: ANICIUS MANLIUS SEVERI- NUS BOETHIUS lived in the last quarter of the fifth century A.D., and the first quarter of the sixth.
tgt_text.1: He was growing to manhood, when Theo- doric, the famous Ostrogoth, crossed the Alps and made himself master of Italy.
tgt_text.2: Boethius belonged to an ancient family, which boasted a connection with the legendary glories of the Republic, and was still among the foremost in wealth and dignity in the days of Rome's abase- ment.
tgt_text.3: His parents dying early, he was brought up by Symmachus, whom the age agreed to regard as of almost saintly character, and afterwards became his son- in-law.
tgt_text.4: His varied gifts, aided by an excellent education, won for him the reputation of the most accomplished man of his time.
tgt_text.5: He was orator, poet, musician, philosopher.
tgt_text.6: It is his peculiar distinction to have handed on to the Middle Ages the tradition of Greek philosophy by his Latin translations of the works of Aristotle.
tgt_text.7: Called early to a public career, the highest honours of the State came to him un- sought.
tgt_text.8: He was sole Consul in 510 A.D., and was ultimately raised by Theodoric to the dignity of Magister Officiorum, or head of the whole civil administration.
tgt_text.9: He was no less happy in his domestic life, in the virtues of his wife, Rusticiana, and the fair promise of his two sons, Sym- machus and Boethius ;
tgt_text.10: happy also in the society of a refined circle of friends.
tgt_text.11: Noble, wealthy, accomplished, universally esteemed for his virtues, high in the favour of the Gothic King, he appeared to all men a signal example of the union of merit and good fortune.
tgt_text.12: His felicity seemed to culminate in the year 522 A.D., when, by special and extraordinary favour, his, two sons, young as they were for so exalted an honour, were created joint Consuls and rode to the senate-house attended by a throng of senators, and the acclamations of the multitude.
tgt_text.13: Boethius himself, amid the general applause, de- livered the public speech in the King's honour usual on such occasions.
tgt_text.14: Within a year he was a solitary prisoner at Pavia, stripped of honours, wealth, and friends, with death hanging over him, and a terror worse than death, in the fear lest those dearest to him should be involved in the worst results of his downfall.
tgt_text.15: It is in this situation that the opening of the ' Consola- tion of Philosophy' brings Boethius before us.
tgt_text.16: He represents himself as seated in his prison distraught with grief, indignant at the injustice of his misfortunes, and seeking relief for his melancholy in writing verses descriptive of his condition.
tgt_text.17: Suddenly there appears to him the Divine figure of Philosophy, in the guise of a woman of superhuman dignity and beauty, who by a succession of discourses convinces him of the vanity of regret for the lost gifts of fortune, raises his mind once more to the contemplation of the true good, and makes clear to him the mystery of the world's moral government.

tgt_text.2291: Moreover, I do not approve the reason- ing by which some think to solve this puzzle.

tgt_text.2406: Man himself, likewise, is viewed in one way by Sense, in another by Imagination, in another way, again, by Thought, in another by pure Intelligence.

tgt_text.2409: The eye of Intelligence is yet more exalted;

tgt_text.2411: Wherein the main point to be considered is this :
tgt_text.2412: the higher faculty of comprehension em- braces the lower, while the lower cannot rise to the higher.
tgt_text.2413: For Sense has no efficacy beyond matter, nor can Imagina- tion behold universal ideas, nor Thought embrace pure form;

tgt_text.2470: Man alone, erect, aspiring, lifts his fore- head to the skies,
tgt_text.2471: And in upright posture steadfast seems earth's baseness to despise.
tgt_text.2472: If with earth not all besotted, to this parable give ear, Thou whose gaze is fixed on heaven, who thy face on high dost rear :
tgt_text.2474: haply lest it stain its heavenly worth, I And thine eyes alone look upward, while thy mind cleaves to the earth !'
tgt_text.2475: Since, then, as we lately proved, every- thing that is known is cognized not in accordance with its own nature, but in accordance with the nature of the faculty that comprehends it, let us now contem- plate, as far as lawful, the character of the Divine essence, that we may be able to understand also the nature of its know- ledge.'
tgt_text.2477: in this judgment all rational beings agree.
tgt_text.2478: Let us, then, con- sider what eternity is.
tgt_text.2479: For this word carries with it a revelation alike of the Divine nature and of the Divine know- ledge.
tgt_text.2480: Now, eternity is the possession of endless life whole and perfect at a single moment.
tgt_text.2481: What this is becomes more clear and manifest from a comparison with things temporal.
tgt_text.2482: For whatever lives in time is a present proceeding from the past to the future, and there is nothing set in time which can embrace the whole space of its life together.
tgt_text.2483: To-morrow's state it grasps not yet, while it has already lost yesterday's;
tgt_text.2484: nay, even in the life of to-day ye live no longer than one brief transitory moment.
tgt_text.2485: Whatever, therefore, is subject to the condition of time, although, as Aristotle deemed of the world, it never have either beginning or end, and its life be stretched to the whole extent of time's infinity, it yet is not such as rightly to be thought eternal.
tgt_text.2486: For it does not include and embrace the whole space of infinite life at once, but has no present hold on things to come, not yet accomplished.
tgt_text.2487: Accordingly, that which includes and possesses the whole fulness of unending life at once, from which nothing future is absent, from which nothing past has escaped, this is rightly called eternal;
tgt_text.2488: this must of necessity be ever present to itself in full self-possession, and hold the infinity of movable time in an abiding present.
tgt_text.2489: Wherefore they deem not rightly who imagine that on Plato's principles the created world is made co-eternal with the Creator, because they are told that he believed the world to have had no begin- ning in time,* and to be destined never to come to an end.
tgt_text.2490: For it is one thing for existence to be endlessly prolonged, which was what Plato ascribed to the world, another for the whole of an endless life to be embraced in the present, which is manifestly a property peculiar to the Divine mind.
tgt_text.2491: Nor need God appear earlier in mere duration of time to created things, but only prior in the unique simplicity of His nature.
tgt_text.2492: For the infinite progression of things in time copies this immediate existence in the present of the changeless life, and when it cannot succeed in equal- ling it, declines from movelessness into motion, and falls away from the simplicity of a perpetual present to the infinite dura- tion of the future and the past;
tgt_text.2493: and since it cannot possess the whole fulness of its life together, for the very reason that in a manner it never ceases to be, it seems, up to a certain point, to rival that which it cannot complete and express by attaching itself indifferently to any present moment of time, however swift and brief;
tgt_text.2494: and since this bears some resemblance to that ever- abiding present, it bestows on everything to which it is assigned the semblance of existence.
tgt_text.2495: But since it cannot abide, it hurries along the infinite path of time, and the result has been that it continues by ceaseless movement the life the complete- ness of which it could not embrace while it stood still.
tgt_text.2496: So, if we are minded to give things their right names, we shall follow Plato in saying that God indeed is eternal, but the world everlasting.'
tgt_text.2497: Since, then, every mode of judgment comprehends its objects conformably to its own nature, and since God abides for ever in an eternal present, His knowledge, also transcending all movement of time, dwells in the simplicity of its own change- less present, and, embracing the whole infinite sweep of the past and of the future, contemplates all that falls within its simple cognition as if it were now taking place.
tgt_text.2498: And therefore, if thou wilt carefully con- sider that immediate presentment whereby it discriminates all things, thou wilt more rightly deem it not foreknowledge as of something future, but knowledge of a moment that never passes.
tgt_text.2499: For this cause the name chosen to describe it is not pre- vision, but providence, because, since utterly removed in nature from things mean and trivial, its outlook embraces all things as from some lofty height.
tgt_text.2500: Why, then, dost thou insist that the things which are surveyed by the Divine eye are involved in necessity, whereas clearly men impose no necessity on things which they see?
tgt_text.2501: Does the act of vision add any necessity to the things which thou seest before thy eyes ?''
tgt_text.2503: And yet, if we may without unfitness compare God's present and man's, just as ye see certain things in this your temporary present, so does He see all things in His eternal present.
tgt_text.2504: Wherefore this Divine anticipation changes not the natures and properties of things, and it beholds things present before it, just as they will hereafter come to pass in time.
tgt_text.2505: Nor does it con- found things in its judgment, but in the one mental view distinguishes alike what will come necessarily and what without necessity.
tgt_text.2506: For even as ye, when at one and the same time ye see a man walking on the earth and the sun rising in the sky, distinguish between the two, though one glance embraces both, and judge the former voluntary, the latter necessary action:
tgt_text.2507: so also the Divine vision in its universal range of view does in no wise confuse the characters of the things which are present to its regard, though future in respect of time.
tgt_text.2508: Whence it follows that when it perceives that something will come into existence, and yet is perfectly aware that this is unbound by any necessity, its apprehension is not opinion, but rather knowledge based on truth.
tgt_text.2509: And if to this thou sayest that what God sees to be about to come to pass cannot fail to come to pass, and that what cannot fail to come to pass happens of necessity, and wilt tie me down to this word necessity, I will acknowledge that thou affirmest a most solid truth, but one which scarcely anyone can approach to who has not made the Divine his special study.
tgt_text.2510: For my answer would be that the same future event is necessary from the standpoint of Divine knowledge, but when considered in its own nature it seems absolutely free and unfettered.
tgt_text.2511: So, then, there are two neces- sities—one simple, as that men are neces- sarily mortal;
tgt_text.2512: the other conditioned, as that, if you know that someone is walking, he must necessarily be walking.
tgt_text.2513: For that which is known cannot indeed be other- wise than as it is known to be, and yet this fact by no means carries with it that other simple necessity.
tgt_text.2514: For the former necessity is not imposed by the thing's own proper nature, but by the addition of a condition.
tgt_text.2515: No necessity compels one who is voluntarily walking to go forward, although it is necessary for him to go forward at the moment of walking.
tgt_text.2516: In the same way, then, if Providence sees anything as present, that must necessarily be, though it is bound by no necessity of nature.
tgt_text.2518: God views as present those coming events which happen of free will.
tgt_text.2519: These, accordingly, from the standpoint of the Divine vision are made necessary conditionally on the Divine cognizance;
tgt_text.2520: viewed, however, in themselves, they desist not from the absolute freedom naturally theirs.
tgt_text.2521: Accordingly, without doubt, all things will come to pass which God fore- knows as about to happen, but of these certain proceed of free will;
tgt_text.2522: and though these happen, yet by the fact of their existence they do not lose their proper nature, in virtue of which before they happened it was really possible that they might not have come to pass.'
tgt_text.2523: What difference, then, does the denial of necessity make, since, through their being conditioned by Divine knowledge, they come to pass as if they were in all respects under the compulsion of neces- sity ?
tgt_text.2524: This difference, surely, which we saw in the case of the instances I formerly took, the sun's rising and the man's walk- ing ;
tgt_text.2525: which at the moment of their occur- rence could not but be taking place, and yet one of them before it took place was necessarily obliged to be, while the other was not so at all.
tgt_text.2526: So likewise the things which to God are present without doubt exist, but some of them come from the necessity of things, others from the power of the agent.
tgt_text.2527: Quite rightly, then, have we said that these things are necessary if viewed from the standpoint of the Divine knowledge;
tgt_text.2528: but if they are considered in themselves, they are free from the bonds of necessity, even as everything which is accessible to sense, regarded from the standpoint of Thought, is universal, but viewed in its own nature particular.
tgt_text.2529: "But," thou wilt say, " if it is in my power to change my purpose, I shall make void providence, since I shall perchance change something which comes within its fore- knowledge."
tgt_text.2531: Thou canst indeed turn aside thy purpose;
tgt_text.2532: but since the truth of providence is ever at hand to see that thou canst, and whether thou dost, and whither thou turnest thyself, thou canst not avoid the Divine foreknowledge, even as thou canst not escape the sight of a present spectator, although of thy free will thou turn thyself to various actions.
tgt_text.2535: Shall the Divine knowledge be changed at my discretion, so that, when I will this or that, providence changes its knowledge correspondingly ?"'
tgt_text.2537: ''True, for the Divine vision anticipates all that is coming, and transforms and reduces it to the form of its own present knowledge, and varies not, as thou deemest, in its foreknowledge, alternating to this or that, but in a single flash it forestalls and includes thy mutations without altering.
tgt_text.2538: And this ever-present comprehension and survey of all things God has received, not from the issue of future events, but from the simplicity of His own nature.
tgt_text.2539: Hereby also is resolved the objection which a little while ago gave thee offence-that our doings in the future were spoken of as if supplying the cause of God's knowledge.
tgt_text.2540: For this faculty of knowledge, embracing all things in its immediate cognizance, has itself fixed the bounds of all things, yet itself owes nothing to what comes after.
tgt_text.2541: 'And all this being so, the freedom of man's will stands unshaken, and laws are not unrighteous, since their rewards and punishments are held forth to wills un- bound by any necessity.
tgt_text.2542: God, who fore- knoweth all things, still looks down from above, and the ever-present eternity of His vision concurs with the future character of all our acts, and dispenseth to the good rewards, to the bad punishments.
tgt_text.2543: Our hopes and prayers also are not fixed on God in vain, and when they are rightly directed cannot fail of effect.
tgt_text.2544: Therefore, withstand vice, practise virtue, lift up your souls to right hopes, offer humble prayers to Heaven.
tgt_text.2545: Great is the necessity of righteousness laid upon you if ye will not hide it from yourselves, seeing that all your actions are done before the eyes of a Judge who seeth all things.
tgt_text.2547: The Con- solation of Philosophy,' Boethius died by a cruel death.
tgt_text.2548: As to the manner of his death there is some uncertainty.
tgt_text.2549: Accord- ing to one account, he was cut down by the swords of the soldiers before the very judgment-seat of Theodoric;
tgt_text.2550: according to another, a cord was first fastened round his forehead, and tightened till his eyes started';
tgt_text.2551: he was then killed with a club.
